DOC.HEAD: NEA Firms Stand Against Academic Tracking, Says Minorities Suffer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 10:30 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Grouping students based on past performance keeps underachievers down and lumps minorities into classes that can prevent them from realizing their potential, the nation's largest teachers union says. So-called academic tracking should be abolished, a National Education Association report issued today said. Academic tracking has become a hot educational issue as U.S. students continue to test poorly in basic subjects. The report was issued in conjunction with the annual convention of the union representing 2 million educators. Opponents complain that minorities are too often placed into low ability and special education classes. Proponents argue tracking is needed so high achievers can move rapidly. NEA vice president Robert Chase said it would be ``foolhardy and unrealistic to expect that tracking can be eliminated overnight,'' but he said the union will offer strategies to better arrange class groupings. The report, based on a commissioned Johns Hopkins University study, said students can benefit from tracking, but only under very specific conditions. Students should be grouped only for specific skills, like reading, rather than by general ability, it said. Also, group assignments should be frequently reassessed. The report said most schools track students by segregating them all or most of the day based on general achievement or behavior, rather than by abilities in specific subjects. The study found that groupings in elementary and secondary schools are hard to break out of and are likely to create racially identifiable classes. Also, the study said minorities are significantly underrepresented in so-called ``gatekeeper classes,'' prerequisites to higher level courses. Without these courses, the study noted, many students are prevented from pursuing careers in advanced fields like science and engineering. Two years ago, the union adopted a resolution calling for an end to academic tracking ``based on socio-economic status, race, or sex.'' Today's report came from a task force appointed then to study the issue further.

DOC.HEAD: Santiago's Archbishop Asks Faithful To Pray For Rain
DOC.TEXT: The archbishop of this smog-choked city has asked Roman Catholic faithful to pray for rain to relieve air pollution. In a statement published by local newspapers Friday, Monsignor Carlos Oviedo asked Catholics to pray ``for the needed rain and to actively cooperate with the measures being ordered by the (city's) anti-pollution commission.'' Authorities say a downpour is badly needed to clean the air, which has been thick for several weeks with fumes from motor vehicles and factories. Since last week, the government has imposed a series of emergency measures that include banning 40 percent of all cars, trucks and buses from downtown. Hospitals have reported a sharp increase in cases of respiratory disease. No significant rainfall has been recorded in the Santiago area since last year. Besides aggravating the smog problem, the dry weather also threatens to produce a water shortage, authorities say.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Shares Credit With Gorbachev for NATO Initiative
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is sharing credit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev for NATO's decision to tone down its war-fighting doctrine, saying the embattled Soviet leader is entitled to declare ``I've been right'' in dealing with the West. Bush said Gorbachev can boast that the 16-nation NATO alliance agreed to overhaul its strategy in direct response to Soviet-sanctioned democratic changes in Eastern Europe. At the same time, Bush observed, ``It was the United States' draft that shaped the new direction for NATO.'' Gorbachev ``should get on the offensive'' against Soviet critics who are angry over the collapse of the Warsaw Pact and the pullback of Red Army troops, Bush suggested Friday at the conclusion of NATO's two-day summit. Bush was in high spirits as he flew here for two days of diplomatic meetings and Texas-style celebrations before opening the annual economic summit of the seven largest industrial powers Monday. The president jetted to Houston on a 10-hour nonstop flight from London and the NATO meeting, which swiftly agreed to his blueprint for changes in Western military doctrine to reflect the reduced military threat from Moscow. Relaxing against the side of a seat on Air Force One, Bush could barely conceal his delight. ``You saw what happened to U.S. influence today,'' he said, pointing to the NATO communique which incorporated his proposals. Despite his upbeat mood, Bush refused anew to declare the Cold War over. ``I've tried to avoid code words,'' he said at a post-summit news conference. ``The Cold War being over is something that I'd rather not comment on. ``I don't think we're dealing in terms of victory and defeat,'' he continued. ``We're dealing in terms of how do we stabilize and guarantee the peace and security of Europe.'' Acting on Bush's suggestions, NATO agreed to shrink its arsenal of battlefield nuclear weapons _ in tandem with Soviet action _ and relegate them to highly unlikely last-resort use. The NATO leaders also said that ``once negotiations begin on short-range nuclear forces, the alliance will propose, in return for reciprocal action by the Soviet Union, the elimination of all its nuclear artillery shells from Europe.'' They also decided to field smaller and restructured ground forces, in the newest sign that NATO's 40-year job of containing potential Soviet-bloc aggression was nearing a successful end. At his news conference, Bush said that Gorbachev could point to the NATO meeting and say, ``They have now changed their doctrine because of steps that I, Mr. Gorbachev have taken.'' ``If I were him,'' Bush said, ``I'd say, `I've been right.''' The president said he would discuss the NATO meeting with Gorbachev in a telephone call over the next couple weeks. Aboard his plane, the president said he recently received a communication from Gorbachev. But Bush merely winked and smiled when asked to elaborate. Despite prodding from some allies, Bush said he was not ready to join West Germany and perhaps others in rushing financial aid to Moscow to prop up Gorbachev and his sickly economy. Financial assistance for the Soviet Union is expected to be a major topic of discussion at the economic summit. ``I have some big problems with that one and I think the American people do,'' Bush said. ``If the Germans decide they want to do that, that's their business,'' he said. ``But I have made very clear to those who have spoken to me about this that at this juncture, we have some serious problems, and I've not been under any false colors about that at all.'' He said, for example, the Soviet Union is spending too much money on its military. Bush also complained that Moscow is paying a $5 billion subsidy to Cuba each year ``to sustain a totalitarian regime that is highly critical of the Soviet Union from time to time.'' While objecting to direct financial aid, Bush said, ``Perhaps there are ways we can assist them as we go forward with credit or other matters before we go to direct government loans.''

DOC.HEAD: List Of Major Industrial Accidents Along Texas Coast
With PM-Plant Explosion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of some of the worst industrial accidents along the Texas coast over the past half century: _ July 5, 1990: Seventeen die in an explosion at the Arco Chemical Co. plant in Channelview, near Houston. _ Oct. 23, 1989: An explosion at the Phillips Petroleum Co. plastics plant on the Houston Ship Channel killed 23 and injured 130. _ Nov. 5, 1985: Two men were killed when the Warren Petroleum plant at Mont Belvieu exploded. An additional 150 workers reached safety only minutes before the facility, owned by Chevron U.S.A., ignited in a ball of flame hundreds of feet high. _ Oct. 13, 1981: Six workers were killed in a explosion of a polyethylene plant owned by Dow Chemical Co. in Freeport. _ Dec. 27, 1977: An explosion at the Farmer's Export Co. grain elevator on the Galveston docks took the lives of 18 workers. Grain dust, ignited by a spark, caused a flash fire. _ Feb. 22, 1976: An explosion and fire at the Goodpasture Inc. grain elevator killed nine. _ Nov. 8, 1959: The tanker Amoco Virginia exploded and burned while docked at the Hess Terminal on the ship channel. Eight people were killed. _ April 16, 1947: The worst industrial accident in U.S. history occurred when the French ship Grandcamp exploded while docked at Texas City. The vessel was loaded with ammonia nitrate fertilizer. The next day, another fertilizer-laden ship, the High Flyer, also blew up. Authorities said 576 people were killed and 5,000 were injured.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Envoy Courts Gorbachev With Bush-drafted Initiative
DOC.TEXT: Bearing the offer of a non-aggression pact and a pledge to cut German forces, NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner is heading for Moscow on the alliance's most hopeful mission yet for allaying Soviet fears about German unification and decades of East-West enmity. A day after Woerner arrives in the Soviet capital on July 14, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl will also meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The visits reflect a stepped-up drive by the Western allies to develop new ties and pacts with the Soviet Union following NATO's dramatic revamping of its longstanding military strategy at a summit which ended Friday in London. ``The London Declaration transforms our relationship with old adversaries,'' declared President Bush, who drafted the new doctrine. ``To those governments who confronted us in the Cold War, our alliance extends the hand of friendship.'' In a communique, the 16 NATO leaders pledged to reduce sharply both nuclear and conventional defenses in Europe and said they held ``no aggressive intentions'' toward the Soviet Union. They promised they ``will never in any circumstance be the first to use force.'' In Moscow, Gorbachev said he was ready to accept an invitation from the London summit to address a NATO meeting, probably in December. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze welcomed the summit's outcome, saying the ``decisions ...move in the right direction and pave the way to a safe future for the entire European continent.'' Bush, headed for Houston aboard Air Force One when informed of Shevardnadze's comments, replied: ``That's very interesting. And very positive.'' But it remained unclear whether the alliance's solemn pledges would be enough to persuade Gorbachev to drop his objections to a united Germany being a member of NATO. ``I would like to see the tangible response be an acceptance of the concept that a unified Germany in NATO is not only good but that it certainly is no threat to them,'' said Bush. Kohl called the commitment to cut German troop levels ``an indispensable signpost along the path leading to German unity.'' ``This is a wide-ranging offer,'' said Kohl of NATO's new stance. ``This is NATO offering a hand.'' The NATO leaders committed themselves to decide on a troop level for a unified Germany by the autumn. The new reduced level will then become part of the next round of negotiations with the Soviets on lower overall troop levels for both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Bonn's defense minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, has agreed to cut more than 160,000 from the current combined forces of West and East Germany, down to 400,000. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has said an even greater cut _ to 350,000 troops _ is acceptable. At the summit, the allies also agreed to the eventual elimination of all nuclear artillery shells in Europe in return for ``reciprocal action'' from the Soviet Union. And they decided to field smaller and restructured ground forces. In a switch in strategy that upset France and had made Britain uneasy, the NATO leaders relegated nuclear weapons to being weapons of ``last resort.'' French President Francois Mitterrand objected, saying NATO should stick to its longtime doctrine that it might use nuclear weapons to repel an overwhelming Soviet conventional attack. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher came round to the concept after insisting that the communique stress NATO retains the option of using nuclear weapons. She also said ``last resort'' was sufficient now that the crumbling Warsaw Pact has lost the ability to mount a surprise attack. ``At long last we have the chance to make for the first time in history military aggression in Europe materially impossible and also politically meaningless,'' declared Woerner.

DOC.HEAD: Colombians Ordered to Register With Police
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco, in an effort to track down drug traffickers and criminals, has decreed that all Colombians must register with police. Newspaper columnists criticized the Friday decree, saying the information could be used by drug traffickers to locate people. Colombia's top ranking army and police officers have repeatedly said the security forces include informants to the drug traffickers. The presidential decree noted that ``members of the armed forces have been retired or charged in cases where they have been linked to illegal acts.'' Friday's decree requires the head of each family to inform police of the names of family members, their address, telephone number and places of work.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl, Andreotti Spurn Rodeo for Cup
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is the second world leader to delay his arrival for the seven-nation economic summit because of more pressing business _ the World Cup soccer finals. Even before his country was eliminated from the tournament, Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti pushed back his arrival in order to present the trophy to the winning team after Sunday's final match. Now with his country in the finals, Kohl has decided he would rather be in the stands in Rome watching his team play Argentina than attending a rodeo hosted by President Bush for the Western leaders in Houston. Both Kohl and Andreotti now plan to arrive in Houston early Monday, only hours before the official arrival ceremonies at Rice University.

In a bow to the black-tie set, President Bush and his wife have decided to attend a Houston Grand Opera performance of ``Carousel.'' The president had long before set up a Sunday entertainment schedule that reinforced a quite different notion of Texas culture: a rodeo and barbeque topped by a rare out-of-Nashville performance by the Grand Ol' Opry. But on Thursday, to the excitement of the Grand Opera staff _ not to be confused with the Nashville bunch _ Bush added a matinee of the Rodgers and Hammerstein production to his schedule.

Speaking of the rodeo. When Bob Tallman was told that he had been chosen to be the announcer for Sunday's rodeo, he told a friend, ``I''ll be there if they have to take me in a wheelchair.'' They do. At a Nevada rodeo last month, Tallman was showing the crowd how to ``spur a bucking horse out'' when a paper plate flew out of the stands and spooked his horse. In the ensuing fall, Tallman broke his shoulder and fractured a leg in three places. So when Bush and his VIP entourage see a 45-minute rodeo demonstration Sunday, Tallman will be at the mike _ announcing the event from his wheelchair.

Lady Bird Johnson may be remembered as the first lady whose love of flowers enriched the nation's capitol, but for the next week, Barbara Bush can lay claim to her own beautification program. In honor of Mrs. Bush, the Garden Club of Houston donated hundreds of pots of white periwinkles to dot the campus of Rice University, where the summit leaders will meet. The garden club had hoped the flowers could be made a permanent addition to the university landscape, but unfortunately Rice officials turned down that offer, saying they did not have the staff to water them after the summit is over.

Watchout, Houston. Gridlock is just around the next freeway bend. Many of the city's main arteries will be shut down for blocks of time during the summit as the world leaders make their way to important meetings. That's enough to make commuters grumble. Now the Federal Aviation Administration and the Secret Service are restricting traffic helicopters for security reasons. ``This is going to be the worst traffic in Houston's history,'' John Winder of Metro Traffic said Friday. ``Probably for the first time we are going to approach gridlock. And that's without the normal stuff.'' ``It's going to be a mess,'' added Gary Elliott of a competing service called Traffic Central. Restrictions that took effect Friday evening barred aircraft from flying below 3,000 feet within an area about eight miles around Rice University, site of the economic summit. Traffic reporters normally fly between 300 feet and 1,500 feet.

And if the summit is just too much to handle, the Houston Chronicle had this advice: ``Get out of town,'' the lifestyle section said. The Friday Chronicle published a list of interesting things to do _ away from the summit city. Visit Austin. Or Corpus Christi. Or Galveston.

DOC.HEAD: A Political Chronology of Albania
With PM-Albania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronological look at some of the political changes in Albania following World War I:

1925 _ Albania is declared a republic and Ahmet Beg Zogu is elected president. 1928 _ Zogu is proclaimed King Zog. 1939 _ Albania is occupied by Italy. 1943 _ Nazi German forces occupy the country. 1944 _ The Communist-led National Liberation Front, established in 1941 with help from the Yugoslav Communists, takes power. 1945 _ Elections are held based on a single slate of candidates sponsored by the Communists headed by Enver Hoxha. 1946 _ King Zog is deposed and the People's Republic of Albania is proclaimed. 1949 _ Albania, seeking protection from Yugoslav expansionism, joins the Moscow-based Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon. 1955 _ Albania joins the Warsaw Pact. 1961 _ The Soviet Union denounces Albania's ties with the Beijing government and breaks off relations. 1962 _ Albania withdraws from Comecon and turns increasingly to China for support. 1968 _ Albania withdraws from the Warsaw Pact. 1972 _ Albania becomes disenchanted with the Beijing government after relations improve between China and the United States. 1978 _ China formally terminates all economic and military support. 1982 _ The government stops an attempted coup by Albanian exiles. While not directly involved, the pretender to the throne of Albania admits knowing the rebels' leader. 1985 _ Hoxha dies and is replaced by Ramiz Alia, who vows to continue Hoxha's policies. 1989 _ Despite the reforms sweeping away the repressive governments of Eastern Europe, Alia continues with the hard-line Communist government. May 5, 1990 _ Greece recalls its ambassador from Albania after accusing Albanian security officials of pursuing an asylum-seeker into the Greek Embassy, beating him, and dragging him away. May 8 _ In a clear break with its long policy of isolation, Albania says it wants to join a 35-nation security group, the Conference on Secuerity and Cooperation in Europe, and will allow freer travel for its citizens. May 10 _ U.N. Secretary-General president Javier Perez de Cuellar arrives for an unprecedented meeting with Albanian officials. June 6 _ Albania pledges to adopt basic reforms, short of free elections, and seek equal status with the 35 nations that signed the Helsinki security and human rights accords. Tuesday _ Riots break out in Tirana when Albanians seek sanctuary in foreign embassies in an apparent attempt to flee the repressive regime. Wednesday _ Foreign diplomats in Albania ask a meeting with the government to discuss the fate of hundreds of Albanians seeking refuge in foreign embassies. Friday _ Police attack demonstrators near the embassy district. Alia offers no ``generosity'' for asylum-seekers, now said to number up to 4,000.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Are Top Of The Pops in Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The lights of Damascus twinkled through the windows of a French nightclub. British businessmen sipped Danish beer poured by Palestinian waiters. A singer warbled her way through ``Georgia On My Mind.'' The performer was Polish, of course. Poles may be struggling with economic troubles at home, but in the Middle East, musicians from the Eastern European nation are in high demand. They seem to be everywhere: Playing Scottish music at a Burns Night dinner in Jordan. Hammering out rock favorites in Dubai saloons. Playing Chopin in Syrian piano bars. In a Kuwait hotel steakhouse, a Polish band romped through a more or less American classic: ``Dee starrs at night are shining bright, deep in dee harrt of Taxes.'' The singer's accent was closer to Warsaw than West Texas. But the fiddle player could toss a bow with the best in Austin. Even the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro was carrying a complement of Polish dancers when it was hijacked in 1985. Polish entertainers have acquired the sort of reputation for low cost and quality that Polish industry is striving to win. ``We're good ... and we're not too expensive,'' said Beata Lewtak, hired to sing with a Jordanian band at an Amman hotel. Robert Lillis, assistant general manager of Amman's Intercontinental Hotel, agreed. ``It's cheaper for us to hire Poles than to hire other European or American musicians,'' he said. ``We know what we're getting with the Poles,'' he said. ``The standard of music and the range of music are excellent.'' This victory on the musical free market is a legacy of Poland's crumbling Socialist system. Ms. Lewtak and most other Polish musicians are graduates of special music academies, which give intensive training grounded in the classics. Many musicians began playing jazz and rock outside class, often to the disapproval of their elders. ``In the '50s, jazz was forbidden in Poland,'' said Tadeusz Toczyski, who played recently at the Meridien Hotel in Damascus. But now schools have begun to teach the new styles. ``I like jazz best,'' said Tadeusz Kasproak, whose Veto Band played at Amman's Intercontinental. ``But when I'm playing with an electronic automatic drummer, it's impossible.'' Many touring bands find themselves playing everything from light classical music to disco to regional songs. ``This kind of job is the most difficult because you have to be good enough to play any kind of music they want,'' said Toczyski, from Krakow. ``In Poland you can find a lot of good musicians. For many years, the main reason that Polish musicians went out was to make the money to buy electronic instruments,'' Toczyski said. Kasproak and his band rely heavily on costly foreign instruments such as keyboards and synthesizers. He has traveled off and on for almost a decade. ``Nobody in Poland can afford such equipment,'' said Kasproak, who plays guitar, trombone and piano. Kasproak, his vocalist wife Anna and keyboardist Andryej Niescior, all from Lublin, played in Finland, Hungary and Yugoslavia before coming to Jordan. But many musicians said they were worried by hardships at home. Poland ended 40 years of Communist Party rule last year. The Solidarity-led government has implemented market reforms that have fueled unemployment and inflation. ``What has changed for us is only the prices,'' Ms. Lewtak said. ``Before I had a lot of money. Now I have nothing.'' She also said working abroad brought its own hardships. ``I have my husband, my daughter at home. All the time I think of them,'' she said. ``In time,'' Kasproak said, ``maybe work will be good for us in Poland.''

DOC.HEAD: Boston Discovers Missing Chapter in Immigrant History: A Mass Grave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Beneath a naked bluff on a mile-long Boston Harbor island known chiefly for its antiquated jail lie the unmarked graves of about 4,100 early immigrants whose American dreams ended in death. Most were famine-weakened Irish who fled their starving country in the mid-1800s only to be deemed ``undesirable'' and detained on Deer Island, where they died and until now were largely forgotten. ``They symbolize all immigrants that have come to Boston and to America,'' Mayor Raymond Flynn said this week. ``They may have been poor, probably didn't have any family and weren't among the elite. ``But still every respect should be afforded to their memory.'' Residents of Boston, home to more Irish-Americans per capita than any other U.S. city, are resurrecting the city's missing chapter. Deer Island's low-security jail is scheduled to close in 1991 and local business, labor and other groups plan to have the gravesite landscaped by 1995, the 150th anniversary year of the potato famine. The mayor has announced plans to erect a Celtic cross on the island and a statue near Fanueil Hall as part of the city's ``Great Hunger Memorial Project,'' the nation's first memorial to Irish famine victims _ and victims of hunger around the world. The graves on the island about four miles from Boston's wharves came to Flynn's attention several months ago, after construction workers turned up bones at a new sewage treatment plant site. ``You think of them getting this far, coming across the Atlantic and being able to look over and see the city ... only to end up in an anonymous pauper's grave,'' said Francis J. Costello, the mayor's adviser on Irish-American Affairs. ``We have to put a proper finish on this.'' Many of the thousands of immigrants held on Deer Island eventually made it to a new life on the mainland. But thousands more were buried in shallow, lime-lined trenches that held eight or 10 bodies each. Their anonymous graves tell the story of immigrants who saw but never reached America's shores. Ireland's population of 8 million was cut in half by fatal disease, starvation and emigration after a devastating plant disease hit the country's staple potato crop in 1845. During the next 10 years, more than 152,000 Irish fled to Boston, many of them tenant farmers forced to move on when they no longer could afford to pay rent. The Yankees were unprepared for the influx of penniless, weak and diseased immigrants, many of whom were near death after a month or more aboard the crowded ``coffin ships'' they had taken across the Atlantic. ``As a precautionary measure to ward off a pestilence that would have been ruinous to the public health and business of the city,'' a quarantine hospital was established on Deer Island, according to a Massachusetts Senate document dated 1848. Paupers and inmates also were held on the island because officials deemed them, like the Irish and a fraction of immigrants from other countries, ``undesirable within the core urban area,'' according to city documents. ``It was really a human dump heap,'' said Dennis P. Ryan, author of ``Beyond The Ballot: A Social History of the Boston Irish.'' Several rough-hewn wooden crosses stood for years on the bluff near the graves, but by about 1970 they had disappeared or disintegrated. A lone white Celtic cross also was erected amid the yellow rapeseed, but that too is gone. ``It wasn't a deep dark secret,'' said Deborah Cox, president of the Public Archaeology Laboratory Inc. in Pawtucket, R.I. ``I think it was just one of those things people don't pay attention to and then eventually forget,'' said Cox, whose company surveyed Deer Island before construction began on the new sewage treatment plant in late 1988. Boston's archivist, Edward Quill, has begun researching death records and handwritten weekly logs kept by physicians at Deer Island's quarantine hospital. For years the records have gathered dust, now they'll be available to genealogists and other researchers. Several Flynns have turned up among the 872 names Quill has traced. ``It could well have been any immigrant group that has come to our country,'' said Mayor Flynn. ``That's why we need a symbol, a decent resting place ... so their history won't be forgotten.''

DOC.HEAD: Carreras, Domingo and Pavarotti Sing Together for First Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The world's three greatest tenors _ ``they each have a Stradivarius in their throat,'' says maestro Zubin Mehta _ have set aside egos to sing together for the first time. Jose Carreras, Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti _ in alphabetical order, please _ will sing tonight under the stars and amid the ruins of the Baths of Caracalla in a charity sendoff to the World Cup soccer championship. ``Music and sport are the most universal things in the world,'' Domingo said at a news conference Friday. The concert is scheduled to follow the consolation match between the national squads of host team Italy and England to determine third place in the monthlong competition. The champion will be the winner of Sunday's game in Rome between Argentina and West Germany. If the Italy-England game, in Bari, goes into overtime, the tenors will have to wait in the wings until the last kick. Both events will be broadcast live to hundreds of millions of television spectators around the world. The three tenors, who will be accompanied by two orchestras led by Mehta, made a big show of their camaraderie at the news conference at a Rome hotel near the Pantheon. ``It's a great challenge for each of us to sing near the other two,'' Carreras said. ``I don't think it's a competition. On the contrary, it's an honor.'' With photographers and camera crews stumbling over each other to capture the three together, Domingo extended a hand, and the other two tenors and Mehta each put a hand on top of the others. The stout Pavarotti wiped sweat off his forehead with a handkerchief, poured a glass of mineral water for Carreras, sitting at his side, and affectionately patted him on the head at one point. After an opening orchestral rendition of Giuseppe Verdi's ``I Vespri Siciliani,'' the tenors will each get a turn, appearing first in alphabetical order to avoid possible offense to egos, then alternating the order. Each man has four solos, with Pavarotti getting the final turn with Nessun Dorma (Nobody Sleep!), from Giacomo Puccini's ``Turandot.'' Nessun Dorma ends with a crescendo of ``vincero, vincero, vincero,'' (I shall win), which Pavarotti sang in a commercial for Italian state television's coverage of the World Cup and in a concert in Milan in late May to inaugurate the competition. An avid soccer fan, Pavarotti's home team, Italy, failed last week to make the finals, ``and my heart is bleeding,'' he said. For the concert's promoters, the winning moment will be the show's last 20 minutes, when the three tenors will sing together a medley of popular songs, including ``O Sole Mio.'' ``How do you think I feel?'' leading the three tenors, Mehta asked. ``It's a dream.'' With the tenors providing enough sonic booms, organizers said, air traffic officials at Rome's Leonardo da Vinci airport agreed to re-route flight paths so planes won't be flying over the 1,800-year-old ruins of the public baths. There are only 6,000 seats amid the ruins, where several operas are performed during the summer, and about 100,000 would-be concert-goers were left disappointed, organizers said. ``There was more pressure to get a ticket to the concert than to the final of the World Cup on Sunday evening,'' Rome Mayor Franco Carraro said. Sales of tickets _ ranging from $25 to $335 _ yielded $1 million, organizers said. The three tenors agreed to sing without pay and will donate to charity their share of revenues _ from television showings, ticket sales as well as sales of videos, cassettes and albums from the concert, which will be recorded. ``Our pay is being together in this marvelous musical _ and human _ circumstance,'' Pavarotti said. Domingo, born in Spain but raised in Mexico, said four Mexican villages devastated by an earthquake in 1985 will benefit from his share. Carreras, who battled back from leukemia, said he'll donate his proceeds to foundations fighting the disease. Pavarotti's share will help benefit sufferers of a variety of diseases as well as a marrow transplant center in Pesaro, Italy. Pavarotti said the three agreed to do it in part because Carreras, back to the stage after his illness, ``is so exceptional, and because the soccer championship is such an important moment. It wouldn't have been possible in any other moment.''

DOC.HEAD: China Aid and Rice Put Japan on Spot at Houston Summit
With PM-Economic Summit, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Japan goes to the Houston economic summit with a distinctly Asian view on two issues _ rice and aid to China _ and with the aim of exerting more influence in world affairs. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu left for the United States Friday and was to hold talks with President Bush on trade and security matters before the seven-nation summit starts Monday. In his 11 months as prime minister, Kaifu, 59, has sought to ease trade tensions with the United States, Japan's main ally, while at the same time improving Tokyo's relations with Europe and exerting influence at a rate commensurate with Japan's economic power. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe, waving charts he will show in Houston, said Japan advanced from 9 percent of world economic output in 1980 to 14 percent last year, while the U.S. share crept from 23 percent to 24 percent. ``Japan's responsibility worldwide is increasing,'' said Watanabe, who was forced to admit last year that Japan didn't have a policy on Eastern Europe because it was so remote from Japanese concerns. The collapse of communism brought a quick change in Tokyo, however, and Japan has pledged $1.95 billion in aid to Poland and Hungary. ``What was remote decades ago can affect the world, and Japan has some responsibility ... to act in concert with other responsible nations,'' Watanabe said at a briefing for foreign journalists. Despite its new political interest in Europe, Japan is conscious of being the only Asian country at the summit. It will voice some distinctly Asian concerns at the meeting with leaders from the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy and Canada. ``We are very much interested in drawing the attention of the other summiteers to what is happening and not happening in this part of the world,'' Watanabe said. He cited problems in China, Tibet, Mongolia, Cambodia and the Korean peninsula. Kaifu is exected to argue at the summit for an end to the punitive ban on development loans to China, and if his six colleagues don't agree, Japan may go ahead alone with its own plan for massive loans to Beijing. At last year's summit in France, China's brutal suppression of a pro-democracy movement was a vivid memory. The summit participants agreed on sanctions including a ban on high-level contacts with Chinese officials and a freeze on development loans. Japan has been China's main source of credit and had planned $5.2 billion in a five-year program of loans. Now, Kaifu and other Japanese government officials say, it's time to open the credit window again to avoid isolating China or contributing to economic unrest there. ``China has to know our moral reaction (to last year's violence) but, if they go into misery and confusion, who's going to suffer?'' Watanabe said. Farm trade is expected to come up at the summit ahead of the December deadline for agreement on the so-called Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Washington has proposed a gradual phasing-out of farm subsidies, which are high not only in Japan but also in Europe and the United States. Japan's official position is that it is willing to negotiate rice when its partners put their farm subsidies on the table. Kaifu's Cabinet decided Friday on only a tiny decrease in the subsidy it pays rice producers, signaling that Japan is not changing its policy on agricultural trade for now. Japan bans rice imports, to the dismay of rice farmers in the United States and Thailand, on grounds that it is the national staple food. Self-sufficiency in rice is a matter of national security, the government says. Yet within Japan the official position increasingly is coming under attack, even from Old Guard figures in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita recently commended what he called the courage of the opposition Clean Government Party in suggesting the import ban should be eased. There had been suggestions to cut the subsidy by 4 percent or more. But farmers with small operations are an important constituency of the governing conservative party, and Friday's 1.5 percent cut was widely seen as a move to maintain their loyalty.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana House Overrides Governor's Abortion Bill Veto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4 with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Senate adjourning without acting on bill, Senate backer conceding not enough votes to override; picks up 5th graf pvs, `The measure ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana House on Friday night voted to override Gov. Buddy Roemer's veto of the nation's strongest state abortion bill, which contains no exceptions for rape or incest. The vote was 73-31, three more votes than were needed for a House veto override. The state Senate still had to deal with the veto Roemer issued earlier in the day. Senators voted 21-18 to adjourn late Friday rather than vote on an override. Sen. Allen Bares conceded on the floor that the bill's backers didn't have the 26 votes needed to override. The adjournment gave abortion opponents three days to lobby the Senate. By law, the Legislature must end its current session Monday night. If the Senate also votes to override, it would be the first override of a gubernatorial veto this century. The measure would send doctors who perform abortions to jail for up to 10 years and fined them up to $100,000. It was written for the purpose of challenging the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. Also Friday, anti-abortion activists in Michigan filed petitions with more than 330,000 signatures to initiate a bill that would require girls to have a parent's consent before obtaining an abortion. Roemer signed the veto Friday morning, according to his staff attorney, John Kennedy. In his veto message, Roemer called the issue ``one of the most wrenching and divisive issues to be faced by this Legislature.'' He also responded to charges by backers of the bill that he has changed his position on abortion since he was a congressman, running for governor, in 1987. ``As a member of Congress, I consistently voted to curb abortion on demand and to protect the life of a fetus,'' Roemer wrote in the veto message. ``I initially voted for the exception to save the life of a mother, but over the years of struggling with this issue I became acutely aware of the need to except those instances where conception occurred because of rape or incest. ``Women cannot and should not be forced to bear the consequences of these traumatic, illegal acts.'' Roemer has repeatedly said he sides with anti-abortion forces but cannot allow a bill without rape and incest exceptions to become law. At an afternoon news conference, the bill's author, state Rep. Woody Jenkins, cited statistics showing that of more than 15,000 abortions performed in Louisiana in 1987, only one was done to end a pregnancy that resulted from rape. ``He's for killing 15,000 unborn children a year in Louisiana just to make sure that one child conceived in rape is also killed,'' said Jenkins. Robin Rothrock, leader of an abortion rights coalition, said earlier she remained confident that the Senate would sustain Roemer's veto. ``In the Senate we believe that we still have the 15,'' Rothrock said, referring to 15 senators who voted against the measure when it passed the Senate with 24 votes. An override requires a two-thirds vote in each chamber _ 26 in the Senate and 70 in the House. The House passed the bill last week with 74 votes. In Michigan, the Legislature will have 40 days to pass the veto-proof measure, once the petition signatures are validated. Failure of the measure would put the issue on the November 1992 statewide ballot as a public referendum. Lawmakers passed a similar measure earlier this year but couldn't override Democratic Gov. James Blanchard's veto. A majority of House and Senate members signed the petitions, said Michigan Right to Life president Barbara Listing. The bill would require girls 17 and younger to have a parent's consent for an abortion or to ask a judge for a waiver on the grounds that she is mature enough to make her own decision or the abortion would be in her best interest.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor's Alleged Drug Buys Detailed
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry bought crack cocaine two dozen times in three months and had the drugs delivered to hotels, a city government office building or picked them up himself, his alleged supplier says. ``I took him three $30 bags of crack cocaine; that was his usual,'' Lydia Pearson testified Friday regarding a 1988 visit to a Washington hotel where she had been summoned by Barry. On one occasion, she said, she delivered her application for a city job along with drugs. Pearson, an acknowledged drug addict, told jurors in the mayor's cocaine and perjury trial that she supplied Barry with crack ``about 25 times'' from July to September in 1988. She met Barry through former model Rasheeda Moore, a childhood friend of Pearson who has given five days of testimony at the trial. Pearson said Moore and Barry used an upstairs bedroom at her home three times before their romantic relationship ended in June 1988. When Barry would leave, Moore would be too high from smoking crack to accompany him down the stairs, she said. Moore ``had begun to run up a tab'' for drugs and Moore said the mayor was the one paying it off, the witness added. After the affair with Barry ended, Moore ``said that she was going to get him,'' Pearson testified, suggesting a possible motive for Moore's cooperation with the government. Moore testified that she was concerned for the mayor's health, came forward because she wanted to tell the truth and wasn't seeking revenge against Barry. After Moore and the mayor broke up, Barry would telephone Pearson to ask whether ``everything is all right'' and he would then tell her when he would stop by, Pearson testified. His chauffer-driven limousine would pull up at her home and Barry would come inside, she said, and ``I would give him the bags'' of crack ``and he would give me the money.'' Pearson said she also delivered crack to Barry in a city government office building, along with an application for a city job. ``He gave me the money'' for the crack and ``I gave him the'' application, she testified. She said the meeting took place in the office of Barry campaign manager Anita Bonds, who was not there at the time. Pearson eventually did work in a public housing job for the city, but recently left because of her cocaine addiction. She has enrolled in drug rehabilitation programs three times over the years. Pearson said she never saw Barry use drugs. Meanwhile Friday, Barry announced that he would not endorse any of the five Democrats vying for his job in this November's election. He urged his loyalists to back the candidate of their choice. Barry announced on June 13 that he would not seek a fourth term. The 54-year-old mayor is accused of 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Tests Begin to Locate Space Shuttle Hydrogen Leaks
DOC.TEXT: Critical tests to ferret out the mysterious hydrogen leak that has grounded America's space shuttle fleet are starting this weekend. Rockwell International, the contractor that built the space shuttles, will test pipes and valves from space shuttle Columbia today and Sunday at the company plant in Downey, Calif. Engineers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, meanwhile, are preparing a leak test on Atlantis, a space shuttle on a launch pad. William Lenoir, NASA associate administrator for space flight, said Friday the goal of the tests is to find where a leak developed in the maze of pipes and valves used to load liquid hydrogen aboard the shuttles. Leaks found in May on Columbia and last week on Atlantis caused the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to ground all three of the nation's winged spacecraft. The third craft, Discovery, is scheduled to fly in October if the leak problem is solved. Meanwhile Friday, an investigative board concluded two days of closed-door hearings here on another major NASA problem, the focusing flaw that disabled the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. NASA said the panel, led by Lew Allen, director of the space agency's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, was to determine how a manufacturer ground and polished the wrong prescription into one of two focusing mirrors on the telescope. The mistake has caused the instrument to see the universe as a fuzzy blur. The mirrors were manufactured by the Hughes Danbury Optical Co. of Danbury, Conn., under a $440 million contract that included $11 million in performance awards. A report to be published Monday in Aviation Week and Space Technology magazine quotes unnamed sources as saying NASA was offered Air Force facilities to test the telescope mirrors 10 years ago, but the space agency turned down the offer. But another trade publication, Space Business News, says in a story to be published Monday that NASA was blocked from using Defense Department facilities to test the Hubble mirrors because the same contractor also was making optics for Air Force spy satellites. Space Business News quotes James Beggs, who was NASA administrator when the Hubble was being built, as saying that ``the Air Force wouldn't let us in'' to test the Hubble mirrors or to even oversee their manufacture. Efforts to reach Beggs by telephone for comment were unsuccessful. Lenoir told reporters there is still no estimate about how long the space shuttles will be grounded. It all depends on how long it takes to find and fix the hydrogen leaks, he said. A leak discovered on Atlantis during a test on the launch pad last week is similar to one discovered in May on Columbia when that craft was being loaded with liquid hydrogen in preparation for launch. Columbia was rolled back to the hangar and engineers removed the elaborate plumbing fixture called the umbilical that is used to load hydrogen into the shuttle rocket propellant tank. The fixture was sent to the Rockwell plant in Downey for testing. On Sunday, Rockwell engineers plan to pump helium, then liquid nitrogen and finally the much colder liquid hydrogen through the umbilical. ``If it does leak, we should be able to pinpoint it,'' Lenoir said. A more vigorous test is planned for Atlantis next Friday when liquid hydrogen is pumped into the spacecraft's tank at a high rate of flow. Plastic bags will be placed over the various valves, pipes and seals that are suspected of leaking. Gas captured in the bags will be analyzed to determine the hydrogen content, Lenoir said. ``If we get through all of that and we still can't find a leak, then in all honesty, we don't know where we'll go,'' he said. Engineers earlier suspected that the leaks may have been caused by a slightly crooked installation of propellant tanks on both Atlantis and Columbia, but Lenoir said an analysis of the misalignment determined it could not be responsible for the leak. At Rockwell International's assembly plant in Palmdale, Calif., meanwhile, power surged Friday for the first time into Endeavour, the newest member of America's space shuttle fleet. A NASA announcement called the power-up ``a major milestone'' in testing of the new shuttle's electrical system. The spacecraft is scheduled to be completed in April 1991 and make its first flight in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Konishiki To Compete in Next Sumo Tournament
DOC.TEXT: Despite a painful left ankle, American sumo wrestler Konishiki will compete in an upcoming summer tournament in pursuit of his dream of attaining the 2,000-year-old sport's highest rank. A member of Konishiki's Takasago stable, or training house, said Friday that the 513-pound Samoan-American intended to participate in the Nagoya summer tournament beginning Sunday. ``It's a real shame. He (Konishiki) would have liked to have gone in with his full strength,'' the stablemate said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The 26-year-old Konishiki, whose given name is Salevaa Fuauli Atisanoe, has a good chance of becoming a yokozuna, or grand champion, if he achieves a high score during the 15-day tournament. Konishiki, who is sumo's heaviest wrestler, has been prone to leg injuries. After being the first foreigner to reach sumo's second highest rank of ozeki in 1987, he injured his right knee and performed poorly in several consecutive tournaments.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: KAILUA-KONA, Hawaii (AP) _ Rep. Joe Kennedy plunged into shark-infested waters to help rescue two anglers tossed overboard by a 485-pound marlin, the congressman and his charter boat skipper say. A bloody 300-pound marlin caught earlier by the rescued couple had drawn the sharks, said the eldest son of the late Sen. Robert Kennedy. ``I don't know if we got many points for intelligence,'' he told the Boston Herald in a telephone interview Thursday. ``It was tiger shark city.'' The aquatic heroics came Sunday as the Massachusetts Democrat took part in a fishing tournament. The crew of his boat heard a radio distress call about three miles off Kailua-Kona and spotted a man and a woman hanging onto an overturned fishing boat, said Chuck Harlan, captain of the charter boat. Kennedy and others on the charter boat leapt in the water to save the couple, Harlan said. After the rescue, Harlan grabbed a fishing pole still hooked to the 485-pound marlin, and the fish eventually was caught. Kennedy, 37, said of the incident, ``It was classic `The Old Man and the Sea' stuff.''

Rodney Dangerfield's lawsuit against Caesars Palace is headed for trial after settlement negotiations stalled, attorneys said. The tie-straightening comic known for his refrain ``I get no respect,'' claims that his eyes were burned in a steam bath accident at Caesars in 1988 and that he was forced to cancel a series of shows at the casino. Attorneys for both sides met in federal court Thursday in an effort to settle the lawsuit. Caesars attorney Bruce Aguilera said Friday the two sides failed to reach an agreement, and a trial date would be set in the case Aug. 1. Dangerfield seeks $225,000 in disputed contract money, reimbursement for medical and legal bills and unspecified punitive damages.

Sixty-one-year-old Rep. John Conyers and his 25-year-old wife of one month have become parents. Monica Ann Esters, gave birth to a son Thursday at Grace Hospital. The mother and baby were in good condition Friday, a hospital spokeswoman said. Conyers, a 25-year congressional veteran, wed Esters in a private ceremony June 4. The marriage is Conyers' first. Esters worked in Conyers' Washington office two years ago and as a photographer on his unsuccessful 1989 mayoral campaign.

Britain's Prince Edward was welcomed to Manitoba with a 21-gun salute before reviewing local troops and listening to warm words from elected officials. The goodwill visit by the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II follows her Canadian visit last week. He addressed members of the Manitoba legislature Friday. ``It will be, as they say in my profession, a hard _ if not impossible _ act to follow,'' said the prince, who has built a career in the theater. Manitoba Province Premier Gary Filmon announced the government was setting up a prize in the prince's honor for Royal Winnipeg Ballet School students. Edward has worked several years for a theater company run by British composer Andrew Lloyd Webber. He recently announced he's quitting to establish his own theater.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Blanchard; an AMs separate on Wyeth moved as a0625.
DOC.TEXT: Nathaniel Wyeth, the brother of artist Andrew Wyeth and the inventor of the plastic soda bottle, died Wednesday at age 78. The cause of death was not disclosed. Wyeth was best known for developing the polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, bottle, in the early 1970s. The bottle is used for carbonated beverages, wine, liquor and food because of its light weight and impact resistance. It was patented in 1973, and more than 6 million are produced annually around the world. He began his career at Du Pont Co. in 1936 in the Wilmington, Del., company's engineering department. Wyeth held numerous other positions before being named the company's first engineering fellow in 1963. In 1975, he was named as the first senior engineering fellow, the company's highest technical position. Wyeth invented 25 processes and products that spanned a wide range, including plastics, textile fibers, electronics and mechanical systems. He is survived by his wife, Jean, five sons, his brother, three sisters, three stepsons and a stepdaughter.

Harold S. Hirsch, who founded White Stag Manufacturing Co. and was a prominent Portland civic leader and philanthropist, died Wednesday from cancer at age 82. In 1929, Hirsch used a corner of his family's Hirsch-Weis Co. factory and a couple of its sewing machines to begin making apparel for downhill skiing. His venture grew into a division of his family's company and became known as White Stag. He is a member of the U.S. Ski Hall of Fame.

Hirsch also headed a National Alliance of Businessmen's program to spur the hiring of minority workers and worked with Reed College, the University of Oregon and Dartmouth College. He is survived bu his wife of 41 years, Elizabeth; a son; a daughter; a stepson; a stepdaughter; a sister, and four grandchildren.

Frank Casado, a restaurateur and activist who managed to draw politicians and celebrities to a homey eatery called Lucy's El Adobe Cafe, died Thursday of congestive heart failure at age 66. Casado and his wife, Lucy, purchased a one-room storefront restaurant across the street from the old Paramount Studios complex in 1964. Soon they were feeding the famous and the soon-to-be famous. A co-founder of the Mexican American Political Association, Casado hosted frequent meetings among Mexican American activists and politicians at Lucy's. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. was a regular at the restaurant and appointed Casado to the South Coast Regional Coastline Commission. As an adviser and fund-raiser for various politicians, Casado briefly considered running for mayor against Tom Bradley.

Susan Tate King, who used her radio show that aired opposite ``Tokyo Rose'' to try to encourage U.S. servicemen in World War II, died Sunday at age 75. The cause of death was not disclosed. For 18 months during the war, she played opposite ``Tokyo Rose,'' with a radio show aimed at boosting the morale of U.S. servicemen in the Pacific while the Japanese announcer tried to discourage them.

Walter ``Lightning Bug'' Rhodes, who once played guitar for Wilson Pickett and had recently begun a comeback tour, was found dead Wednesday in a motel swimming pool at age 50. Rhodes was just 6 when he began playing guitar. Besides Pickett, he performed with such soul and blues stars as Joe Tex, Otis Redding and B.B. King. His own hits include ``Strollie Bun'' in 1958 and ``It's Not What You Do'' in 1971. Rhodes and his band performed in May at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival and were to play a concert in September at Lincoln Center in New York. Also in the works were concerts in Switzerland and an album featuring 10 of Rhodes' songs, due for release in the fall.

Paul Wynne, a television news reporter who turned the camera on himself and his battle with AIDS in the highly acclaimed ``Paul Wynne's Journal,'' died Thursday of the disease at age 46. Wynne hosted the weekly show that began airing in January. ``Paul Wynne's Journal'' gained notoriety as a straightforward, lively show that won a local Friends of the Human Rights Commission Award in June. A broadcast specialist in the Army, he left in 1969 and came to San Francisco to work as a press agent for KGO. He worked for KQED-TV as an arts critic from 1972 to 1975, then moved to KPIX-TV where he was an entertainment contributor for ``Evening Magazine'' from 1976 to 1981. Wynne moderated a weekly public affairs program for young people at KPIX, and hosted the Emmy Award-winning children's special ``Comin' at Ya'' in 1979. He returned to KGO in 1981, and worked as an entertainment reporter until 1984.

Ruth Becker Blanchard, who survived the Titanic disaster as a 12-year-old passenger, died Friday at age 90. Blanchard died of the complications of old age, said Don Lynch, a spokesman for the Titanic Historical Society of Indian Orchard, Mass. Twelve-year-old Ruth Becker was asleep when the Titanic struck an iceberg on April 14, 1912. She was one of 705 survivors from the ship that carried about 2,200 people. She married, moved to Kansas and raised three children before teaching grade school in Benton Harbor, Mich. for 20 years. She retired to California. Blanchard refrained from any ocean voyages following the Titanic disaster until March of this year, when she went on a cruise to Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Company Apologizes for Use of Forced Labor
DOC.TEXT: A major Japanese construction company has apologized for using hundreds of Chinese slave laborers during World War II, company officials said. Officials of Kajima Corp. ``made a deep apology'' to six former workers and two surviving relatives, Kajima spokesman Minori Kurita said Friday. During the Thursday meeting, the officials also promised to open talks on compensation with the former workers or their surviving relatives. In December, a group of Chinese employed between 1944 and 1945 at a construction site in northern Japan demanded the company apologize and compensate for cruel treatment of 986 Chinese workers. Of those, 418 died. Japan ruled northeastern China, Taiwan, and the Korean peninsula before and during World War II, taking over a million people to Japan as forced laborers.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested For Sneaking into Reagan's Bel-Air Estate
DOC.TEXT: A man was charged Friday with threatening Ronald Reagan after scaling the fence at the former president's Bel-Air home, the Secret Service said. Gregory Stuart Gordon, 32, of Los Angeles, was arrested on the Reagan property on Wednesday, said Assistant Special Agent Joseph Perez. Gordon, who Perez said was unemployed, was being held without bail on charges of threatening to kill or inflict bodily harm on a former president. Perez refused to give details about the intrusion. KCAL-TV, quoting unidentified sources, reported Friday that Gordon had entered the Reagan residence while the Reagans were home. The station said Nancy Reagan saw the intruder, but the former president was in another wing. A man who gave his name as Gregory Gordon called The Associated Press on Thursday night, claiming he had scaled the fence at the mansion before he was seized by Secret Service agents. He said he was calling from the county's Harbor-UCLA Medical Center, where he had been taken for a psychiatric evaluation. The caller said he jumped the fence because he wanted publicity. He said he believes Reagan is the anti-Christ ``and I'm the second coming of Christ.'' The 35-year-old, single-story mansion stands behind a wall and security fence on a hillside. Other security measures include surveillance cameras. The estate's address was changed from 666 to 668 St. Cloud Drive because of superstition surrounding the number 666, believed by some to be a symbol of the devil. The home on about an acre of land was bought for the Reagans by friends in 1986 for $2.5 million. Neighbors include Elizabeth Taylor and Zsa Zsa Gabor.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes Near Spanish Bank, Three Injured
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in front of a Spanish bank, injuring three passers-by with flying glass, police said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing, which occurred shortly before midnight Friday on the pavement in front of the Banco de Bilbao Viscaya, shattering windows. The condition of the three victims was not immediately known. The attack came six days after a bomb exploded outside a building housing the offices of three major airlines: Spain's national carrier, Iberia Airlines; British Airways; and South African Airways. Last year, ETA, a Basque separatist group in Spain claimed responsibility for several bomb attacks on Spanish targets in the Netherlands. Several people were injured in those attacks, none seriously.

DOC.HEAD: Military Jet Crashes Killing Two
DOC.TEXT: An Italian air force jet crashed and burned in southern Italy, killing both pilots, the Defense Ministry said. It was the second fatal crash of an Italian military plane in two days. The pilot and a student pilot were killed in the Friday crash of the Italian-made MB-339 jet outside the southern city of Lecce, the ministry said. On Thursday a Lockheed F-104 fighter jet crashed outside the Sicilian city of Catania, killing the pilot. Authorities said the exact cause of both crashes was not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats, GOP Joust Over Soviet Threat
DOC.TEXT: With cuts in U.S. defense spending at issue, Democrats and Republicans on the House Armed Services Committee are drawing battle lines over how much of a military threat the Soviet Union continues to pose. The 17 Democrats on the committee's special Defense Policy Panel concluded in a report released Friday that the Soviet conventional threat to the United States and its Western allies is ``greatly diminished and cannot be revived.'' Based on that assessment, reductions in defense spending are in order, they said. ``Old assumptions about the Soviet threat don't jibe with reality anymore,'' Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., said. ``Many of the changes are irreversible, and that means we can cut selectively without jeopardizing our security.'' But the 15 Republicans on the panel rejected that view as overly optimistic. ``Endorsing this report is tantamount to believing that the Soviet Union is already militarily impotent and not a global power to be reckoned with. Such a view is more wishful thinking than a reflection of reality,'' said Rep. William Dickinson of Alabama, ranking Republican on the committee. The GOP members, in a dissent included in the 310-page report, cited the absence of a U.S.-Soviet treaty to scale back conventional forces in Europe, the unclear future of a unified Germany and the economic and political instability in Eastern Europe. The report cited the testimony of CIA Director William Webster, who told the Armed Services Committee on March 1 that the lessening Soviet conventional threat would ``be increasingly difficult to reverse.'' Planned withdrawal of Soviet troops from Europe, as announced by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in December 1988, will continue as long as the Kremlin leader remains in power, the report said. Even if Gorbachev is replaced, his successor would be forced to follow the same policies, it said, quoting a U.S. intelligence assessment. ``In short, there has been too much change in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe for the reduction in the threat to be reversed,'' the report said. The Republicans said the House-approved budget that calls for $296 billion in defense spending for the 1991 fiscal year, beginning Oct. 1, would carve too much out of the U.S. military. President Bush has proposed spending $303 billion on defense in fiscal 1991. ``We believe that the House defense spending figure, which in percentage terms cuts defense spending three times more than the president's budget does, is imprudent,'' the GOP members said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Targeting 100 S&Ls for Priority Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is expanding the priority list of savings and loans to be investigated from 20 to 100, officials say. Justice Department prosecutors said Friday they will concentrate on these institutions as they push ahead with investigations of scandals that have swept the thrift industry, the officials said. The list was drawn up at a three-day meeting in Indianapolis three weeks ago and represents an expansion of a roster of 20 priority savings and loans, William Fulwider, a spokesman for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said. He said over the last several years over 20,000 ``referrals'' concerning possible criminal activity involving 350 savings and loans have been sent to the Justice Department in the burgeoning scandal. ``Justice was getting all these criminal referrals but no prioritization,'' Fulwider said. ``They didn't know which ones ... we thought they should really go after and concentrate on.'' The expanded list was drawn up in late June at about the time President Bush called for doubled spending on savings and loan fraud and proposed to create ``rapid response teams'' to combat the problem. The administration has been under fire from Democrats on Capitol Hill who say that it should have done more to jail savings and loan officials guilty of fraud and recover more of the estimated hundreds of billions of dollars lost. The administration has been pointing to 791 fraud convictions last year as well as the recovery of $100 million in stolen funds and 530 active investigations this year. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, were expected to appear on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee for a hearing into savings and loan enforcement plans. The initial list of 20 priority institutions was developed shortly after Ryan took office in April and met with Thornburgh. It was produced by a group of enforcement officials from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., the Resolution Trust Corp., the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Justice Department. Authorities from the same agencies drew up the expanded list along with representatives from federal agencies from around the country, officials said. They said it would be improper to disclose the names of the institutions on the list. Some of them already have been seized by the government and some have not, Fulwider said. Officials said the list was presented several days ago to James G. Richmond, the Justice Department's newly appointed special counsel for savings and loan fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Poets Gather for Month of Writing
DOC.TEXT: Word of a monthlong English course with no grades, no required papers, no interruptions and no tuition was sheer poetry for 10 promising writers who usually have more than verse and meter on their minds. Poets often can't find time to write because they must find ways to put food on the table, said John Wheatcroft, director of Bucknell University's Seminar for Younger Poets. So Bucknell invites the 10 best young writers it can find, puts them up for a month each summer and lets them work. The writers completed their four-week course Friday night with a meal they cooked at a farm along the Susquehanna River and a poetry reading in Bucknell's 105-year-old poetry center. ``I'm very grateful for this. I've never had a time in my life devoted exclusively to poetry,'' said Lisa Sornberger, who recently returned to school at Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic, Conn. Before her return, she was recreation director at a home for retarded adults. ``There's never enough time, so I squeeze writing in when I can,'' she said. ``I write mostly in the car while I'm driving. I've tried to keep a tape recorder, but it picks up too much road noise.'' To keep the poets off the streets, Bucknell began inviting them to its campus six years ago. Usually, 50 to nearly 100 apply for the program, submitting two letters of recommendation, a letter of self-introduction and 15 pages of poetry. Only 10 writers are selected. ``We're not trying to teach a body of information. We're not even trying to teach a skill,'' Wheatcroft said. ``We're giving them an opportunity to develop themselves as poets. We provide them with the environment and ambience for that.'' An anonymous evaluation from a participant in one of the first five programs likened the seminar to a religious retreat ``in that everything felt sacred ... except that the religion was poetry.'' Sornberger wrote seven new pieces this year, but none is a completed poem, she said. Amy Hickman of Anderson, S.C., who goes to Goucher College in Baltimore, finished three and revised several she had done before arriving at Bucknell. For her reading Friday night, Hickman prepared ``Charlie and Ruby June's Champale Party,'' in which the heroes party in the back of a pickup truck, knocking back rum and Slurpees. Sornberger read ``Aunt Stella,'' ``a composite of a lot of women I love.'' Even with an unpromising financial future from poetry, Hickman and Sornberger said they couldn't quit writing it without losing part of themselves. ``For instance, when I'm not writing much, I get very tense, very on edge,'' Hickman said. ``Writing poetry is like making order of the world. It's sort of being like people who are obsessively neat.'' Jobs and other classwork are the main culprits stealing time from would-be poets, Wheatcroft said. ``Usually, princes subsidized poets and in some countries the state subsidizes them. In this country, most poets have had some other job,'' Wheatcroft said. T.S. Eliot was in banking and William Carlos Williams was a pediatrician, for example. ``In undergraduate work, usually students must divide themselves over four courses, split their heads four different ways,'' he said. ``We wanted to provide them with a month to see what they could do.''

DOC.HEAD: Tough Times To Get Tougher For Philippine President
DOC.TEXT: The acquittal of Imelda Marcos dealt a setback to embattled President Corazon Aquino, but looming political battles and talks on the future of U.S. bases promise rougher days ahead. Problems have beset her administration from all sides. During the past six weeks, Communist rebels have killed two U.S. serviceman and kidnapped a Peace Corps volunteer. Foreign business groups complain that poor infrastructure and government policies are driving away international investors. Annual inflation is running in double digits, and the stock market is sluggish. Mrs. Aquino's formation of a new political movement has angered her supporters in Congress. Now, the acquittal of Mrs. Marcos on federal racketeering charges by a New York jury Monday has invigorated the dwindling ranks of supporters of her late husband, ousted President Ferdinand Marcos. Surveys show Filipinos are losing faith not only in Mrs. Aquino. Confidence is also dropping in all institutions she proudly cited as evidence she restored democracy after a 1986 uprising toppled Marcos' authoritarian regime. Despite the problems, Amando Doronila, editor of The Manila Chronicle, said he was impressed by Mrs. Aquino's ``steely'' calm during an interview this week. Many Filipinos are convinced that recent events have eroded Mrs. Aquino's support in both this country's Congress and the United States. Congressional supporters are angry over Mrs. Aquino's decision to organize a new political movement, Kabisig or ``arm-in-arm,'' to promote social programs. Critics see the movement as a bid by the Cabinet to bypass the legislature in the distribution of patronage. On Thursday, House Speaker Ramon Mitra, an Aquino stalwart, said the country did not need ``another poorly conceived program'' and blamed the government's failures on ``incompetent Cabinet secretaries.'' Rightly or wrongly, many Filipinos believe the U.S. connection has been frayed. Filipino nationalists rail constantly at ``American intervention.'' But Washington's blessing _ real or perceived _ is seen as a strong political card, and government opponents take heart when they believe that support is waning. Many Filipinos are convinced that U.S. backing is ebbing, even though U.S. jets helped put down a December coup that nearly toppled the government. That view is based on several events that U.S. officials insist are coincidental. They include an offer by the U.S. military to fly dependents home after Communist rebels killed two airmen near Clark Air Base on May 13. There were few takers, but Manila newspapers made banner headlines of the American ``evacuation.'' Last month, the United States withdrew all 261 Peace Corps members because of fears Communist rebels planned to kill or kidnap volunteers. Although one volunteer, Timothy Swanson, was reportedly kidnapped, commentators and government officials say Washington overreacted. Presidential spokesman Tomas Gomez said Washington has an ``obligation'' to help correct the unfair image of instability it had created. In addition, the American Chamber of Commerce in the Philippines recently complained of 57 ``anti-foreign investor'' bills pending in Congress. It said the government appeared hostile to investment. Mrs. Marcos' acquittal was seen as another sign that Washington was no longer interested in accommodating Mrs. Aquino. Ambassador Nicholas Platt has repeatedly stated support for Mrs. Aquino. However, Filipinos remember Washington gave similar assurances to Marcos before dumping him for Mrs. Aquino. ``All in barely a week, we saw how the Americans failed the popular expectations of the Aquino government,'' wrote columnist Art Borjal in The Philippine Star, a pro-administration daily. ``The general feeling is that the Americans are tightening the screws on the Aquino administration.'' Such views will doubtless complicate talks on the future of the six U.S. military bases by encouraging the Philippines to take a hard-line stand on compensation and other issues. Talks resume next month. The lease on the bases expires in September 1991. Any new agreement must be approved by two-thirds of the 23-member Senate. As a sign of its mood, the Senate has agreed to consider a resolution barring U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage because of ``anti-Filipino'' remarks during earlier talks.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiations Set on New U.S.-Singapore Defense Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Negotiations will resume next week on final details of an agreement expanding U.S. access to military facilities in Singapore, the Pentagon says. The proposed deal would not give the United States its own military base in Singapore, but it would greatly expand U.S. military activity in the Southeast Asian city-state, Lt. Cmdr. Edward H. Lundquist, a Pentagon spokesman said Friday. Lundquist said no U.S. planes or ships would be based there permanently, but a small contingent of American military personnel _ probably fewer than 200 _ would be stationed at the Singapore facilities to keep them ready for U.S. use. Lundquist stressed that the proposed use of Singapore military facilities would not be a substitute for the larger U.S. forces at Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Base in the Philippines. A military bases agreement between the United States and the Philippines expires next year, and the administration is seeking to negotiate some form of continued use of those facilities. If the Singapore deal is concluded, U.S. F-16 fighter planes based elsewhere in Asia would be allowed to conduct occasional training missions in Singapore, and Navy ships could use Singapore's strategically located port, Lundquist said.
DOC.HEAD: Administration Proposes Voluntary Seafood Inspection Program
DOC.TEXT: The administration is planning to enhance current seafood inspections with a voluntary program paid for by companies whose products could earn an official government seal. The new program would use industry controls and government inspections ``to provide additional assurances to consumers that fish and fish products are safe, wholesome and properly labeled,'' officials said Friday. The program was proposed by the Food and Drug Administration and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The FDA has a seafood inspection program that requires examinations of processors, shippers, packers and repackers, labelers, warehouses and importers of fish and fish products. That program would continue separately. NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service runs a voluntary, fee-for-service seafood inspection program, which uses a government inspection mark. That program would continue to provide grading services, but continuation of other parts of the program would depend on the extent to which companies switch to the new system, officials said. The new plan would be based on inspections at various critical points at which health risks, such as spoilage and bacterial growth, can be controlled, the FDA said. Companies would pay a fee for inspections and could earn an official mark or seal they could display on their product's label.
DOC.HEAD: Complaints Against Airlines At Record Low
DOC.TEXT: Consumer complaints to the government about airlines hit a five-year low in May, the Transportation Department says. The department received 689 complaints for the month compared to 826 in April and 805 in May 1989, the department said. It said the peak of 7,280 came in August 1987 and the trend since then has been downward. Federal officials believe the trend reflects improved performance by the airlines, department spokesman Hal Paris said Friday. Reports of mishandled baggage, however, were up slightly. The May average was 5.92 complaints for every 1,000 bags handled compared to 5.85 for April. The most common complaints concerned cancelled or delayed flights. May statistics showed 80.8 percent of all flights operated within 15 minutes of their scheduled time, compared to 82.2 percent in April. Delays caused by mechanical problems were not included. Southwest Airlines had the lowest complaint rate among major carriers for May, with 0.47 per 100,000 passengers. TWA had the highest with 4.62. America West was first in on-time arrivals, with 91.8 percent, followed by Alaska, Eastern, Pan Am, Southwest, Northwest, USAir, Delta, American, United, Continental and TWA. The department took over the job of counting complaints in 1985 from the now defunct Civil Aeronautics Board. The only complaints counted are those telephoned or mailed directly to the department in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Looking to West for Credits to Help Reforms
With PM-Economic Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is hoping the industrial powers will open their pocketbooks to Moscow, but there were indications a quick aid fix may not be in the cards. The issue of Western aid to bolster Soviet reforms will be discussed at the meeting of seven industrial nations beginning Monday in Houston. It was also a topic at a two-day meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in London, but no decisions were made on the matter. President Bush said at the close of the NATO meeting that he had ``big problems'' with a German-French Soviet aid plan that could total billions of dollars. Bush cited concerns including the American people's objections to Soviet assistance to Cuba. NATO sources said Gorbachev, in a letter to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher appealing for aid, said he hoped for ``positive conclusions'' at the London and Houston summits. The letter did not mention any particular aid figure, the sources said. Gorbachev has already had some success in attracting Western help. West Germany has granted an unconditional loan of $3.1 billion, and European leaders agreed at a Dublin summit in late June to grant significant sums to the Soviet Union. ``We view this step as an illustration of the desire to support reform policies started by President Mikhail Gorbachev,'' West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said last week.
