Some have suggested that West Germany's motives are not entirely altruistic, however. The Communist Party daily Pravda said in a recent commentary that Bonn was trying to ``grease'' Moscow into agreeing to allow a united Germany to belong to NATO, something the Western allies want. ``This act by the West German government must be explained above all by efforts of the West German government to buy from the USSR the desired position on the issue of unification of the two Germanys,'' said Kommersant, a Soviet economic weekly of the cooperative movement that seeks to foster independent businesses. Whatever the motives of the donors, there is little doubt that the Soviet Union could use some Western cash. Moscow's balance-of-payment deficit now tops $2 billion, with nearly half that sum owed to West German companies and creditors. Soviet citizens are also unhappy about the short supply of consumer goods. Economists both at Gosplan, the central agency responsible for running the economy, and at the reformist Institute for World Socialist Economies have concluded outside aid is essential for the transition to a market economy. But that transition carries the price of hardship on the population. That means more discontent, which puts even more pressure on Gorbachev. Gorbachev has said the country must develop some kind of market economy. But many delegates to the Communist Party congress under way in Moscow oppose private property and individual ownership of factories _ two basic precepts of a free-market economy. In addition, Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov has balked at freeing prices _ another key step toward a market economy. Soviet officials have not said exactly what they would do with any Western money. ``For now the question of how the Soviet Union is going to utilize the means it has received is open,'' Kommersant said. Then there's the problem of how much money it would really take to stabilize the Soviet economy. Estimates range from $5 billion to $20 billion _ huge sums compared to what Eastern European countries have gotten from the West to restructure their economies.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator
Chef Upset with Food, Throws Plates
DOC.TEXT: All was not idyllic at Cafe Paradiso when a chef started throwing plates because he was apparently upset over the quality of mussels for a main dish, a newspaper reported today. The display at the restaurant began with the shattering of a single dish and built up into a frenzy of plate-throwing _ some with meals, some without, the Evening Post reported. Distressed kitchen staff ducked the barrage Friday night while patrons craned for a prime viewing position, the paper said. Relative calm returned after 10 minutes when the chef walked out the back door. One staff member said the outburst was prompted by ``troubles with the mussel mains.''

DOC.HEAD: Princeton's Men-Only Clubs Go the Way of the Packard
DOC.TEXT: To F. Scott Fitzgerald, they were ``breathlessly aristocratic'' clubs frequented by ``an impressive melange of brilliant adventurers and well-dressed philanderers.'' To Sally Frank, Princeton University's men-only eating clubs are part of an old-boy network that discriminates against women. Fitzgerald venerated the Tiger Inn and the Ivy and Cottage clubs in the 1920 novel ``This Side of Paradise.'' Almost 60 years later, Ms. Frank sued the three organizations, seeking membership in the Ivy League school's men-only clubs. After an 11-year battle during which she was vilified by other students, Ms. Frank, a 1980 Princeton graduate, prevailed last week when the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered the clubs to open their doors to the opposite sex. Ms. Frank, now a 31-year-old law professor at the New York University Law School, said she fought for so long because she believed the battle had implications beyond the Gothic-style ivy-shrouded campus. ``You always have clubs that call themselves private across the nation where major business and political leaders are members and people take tax deductions for their members,'' Ms. Frank said. ``We know that important business contacts are made in those places and public policy decisions are often made over the dinner table,'' she said. ``The case is part of the broader struggle to stop discrimination in those kinds of organizations.'' The century-old eating clubs, which are near campus, serve meals to more than 75 percent of Princeton's juniors and seniors. They do not provide living quarters. The clubs have competitive standards for admission, and students pay membership fees. The cachet of the clubs made a deep impression on Princeton alumnus Fitzgerald, who described the Ivy Club as ``detached and breathlessly aristocratic.'' In his romantic vision, the University Cottage Club attracted ``brilliant adventurers and well-dressed philanderers,'' while the Tiger Inn preferred the ``broad-shouldered and athletic'' type. Such distinctions did not sit well with Ms. Frank, who was raised in Bayonne and said her sense of social justice grew out of the Chicago Eight trial and the Kent State shootings. At 12, she boycotted non-union lettuce, and at age 13 she worked for presidential candidate George McGovern. She said she had no inkling that her attempt to join men-only clubs in an institution that first accepted women in 1969 would spark such a ruckus. ``I thought that they would be intelligent about it and that they would see it as an issue and argue or debate it,'' Ms. Frank said. ``I expected some hot repartee.'' Instead, a club member poured beer on her, she was booed at alumni rallies, and her face was painted with a mustache on ``Frankbuster'' T-shirts that said ``Better Dead Than Co-Ed.'' Things have changed at Princeton since the lawsuit was filed in 1979. The Cottage Club settled in 1986 and now accepts women. The Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn, the only two of the 13 eating clubs to cling to male-only membership, had voted earlier this year to admit women, but two more rounds of voting were needed next year for the decision to become effective. In court, the Tiger Inn and Ivy Club had argued they were private associations and therefore exempt from state anti-discrimination laws. But the Supreme Court said it was ``disingenuous'' for the clubs to pretend they could exist apart from the school. The clubs, the court said, are places of public accommodation. The Tiger Inn president has promised to take the case to the U.S. Supreme Court. Princeton's clubs are the first at an Ivy League school to be ordered to admit women. The Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination ruled in March that it had no jurisdiction to decide the case of a woman seeking admission to the Fly Club, one of Harvard's nine all-male social clubs. Yale's most exclusive secret society, Skull & Bones, of which George Bush is a member, recently voted to continue excluding women. In a gauge of how far Princeton has come, the Alumni Council last month gave Ms. Frank an award for her efforts in encouraging coeducation. ``It felt really warm and nice,'' she said. ``What the award meant to me was that just because you are a dissenter, it doesn't mean you are not loyal.''

DOC.HEAD: Greek Government Loses Court Bid To Stop Marbles Sale
DOC.TEXT: The Greek government has lost a last-minute court bid to block a sale by Sotheby's auctioneers of a collection of ancient Greek marble statues and pottery. The Greek government had sought to prevent the Cycladic Marbles, as the collection is known, from being split up. ``We are very disappointed,'' Victoria Solomonidis, cultural attache at the Greek Embassy in London, said after Friday's ruling by the High Court in London. The judge, Sir John Mummery, said if the Greek government wants to keep the collection intact it can bid for the marbles and pottery itself at the auction in London on Monday. ``If the government's real interest is to prevent dispersal of the collection, then it is within its power to do so by attending the auction ... and bidding for and purchasing the items,'' he said. Sotheby's sale catalog lists 180 auction lots of marble statues, pottery, drinking vessels, vases and other items. Ms. Solomonidis declined to comment on the judge's suggestion that the Greek government buy the collection. The Greeks say the collection, which dates between 2600 B.C. and 2200 B.C., was looted from the uninhabited Greek island of Keros in the late 1950s or the 1960s. British news reports called the collection as rare and valuable, but no sum was mentioned in the court proceedings. Lawyers for the Greek government on Thursday obtained a High Court injunction temporarily banning Sotheby's from moving any of the collection. But Mummery ruled Friday against continuing the injunction, a move that would have forced Sotheby's to cancel the sale. The judge noted that the Greek government had waited until the last possible moment to press its claim, rather than seeking to establish ownership during the years since the sculptures were allegedly stolen. The present owner is the 77-year-old widow of Professor Hans Erlenmeyer of Switzerland. She was approached by the Greek government when the collection was first listed for auction on her behalf, but she refused to withdraw it. The sale is being held to raise cash for the Erlenmeyer Foundation, which was established in 1981 in Basel in Switzerland. It works for causes ranging from environmental protection and conservation of natural resources to safeguarding animal rights. It was not the first time the Greeks have contested ownership of ancient treasures. Britain has repeatedly refused Greek government demands for the return of the priceless sculptures known as the Elgin Marbles, which adorned the Acropolis in Athens 2,500 years ago. A British diplomat, Lord Elgin, removed them in the early 1800s. The British government says the Elgin Marbles belong to the British Museum in London, which bought them from Lord Elgin in 1816. Britain maintains that Elgin acquired the sculptures legally at a time when Greece was ruled by Ottoman Turkey. Greece says he stole them.

DOC.HEAD: Boat Capsizes, Killing 40
DOC.TEXT: A boat crammed with vacationers capsized in a lake in southwestern Pakistan, killing as many as 40 people and injuring eight others, newspapers reported today. At least 60 people, most of whom returning home Friday at the end of a three-day Moslem holiday, were packed into a small wooden boat that plies Hanna Lake, near Pakistan's southwestern city of Quetta, the government-run Pakistan Times said. Several survivors swam to shore, according to the Pakistan Times. Others were rescued by a second boat in the area, the Islamabad-based Muslim newspaper said. Neither the boat's capacity nor its type was known. Pakistan's official news agency said 18 bodies had been recovered when the search ended late Friday ninght. It was excpected to resume today, Associated Press of Pakistan said.

DOC.HEAD: Inspection Prompts Suspension of Nuclear Materials Handling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 4 grafs to CLARIFY that plutonium operations already had been halted and new suspension applies to handling of other nuclear materials; pick up 4th graf pvs, `Nelson said investigators ...'
DOC.TEXT: Officials at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant suspended handling of all nuclear materials because of lax security, a U.S. Department of Energy official said Friday. Plutonium operations at the plant were halted in November while safety and management improvements were made at the plant. The new ban applies to other Rocky Flats nuclear operations, virtually all of which are classified. The suspension went into effect Thursday night following an annual inspection by members of the DOE's Albuquerque, N.M., operations office, according to Rocky Flats DOE manager Robert M. Nelson. The plant 16 miles northwest of Denver is the nation's only source of plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. Nelson said investigators discovered security at the plant could be breached. Investigators were sent in during the past few weeks to try to smuggle out pieces of metal such as plutonium and other security-sensitive materials, he said. Nelson said the only line of defense that failed was a metal detector such as that used at airports, and there were other lines of defense that caught the materials. ``It wasn't like they could smuggle it off the plant site,'' he said. Nelson said the deficiencies developed because workers were wearing steel-toed shoes required by federal regulations that kept setting off the metal detectors. He said workers at the plant became frustrated at having to remove their shoes to pass through the detectors, and security became lax. He said there was no danger because of the security lapses, and the problems have been corrected. He said workers are now wearing fiberglass-toed shoes that don't trip the monitors. ``Maybe we overreacted when we shut down the plant,'' he said. ``They only made it through one line of defense. But to me, that's enough to stop everything.'' Nelson said other violations were found, but none were ``showstoppers.'' They included things like improper access to classified documents and improper handling of chemicals, but he wouldn't be more specific.

DOC.HEAD: New Quake Jolts Northwestern Iran
DOC.TEXT: Another earthquake hit quake-shattered Gilan province in northwestern Iran on Friday night, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, on Saturday quoted Tehran University's Geophysics Center as saying the quake registered 5.9 on the Richter scale. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. IRNA said the quake hit the city of Rudbar at 11:05 p.m. local time (3:35 p.m. EDT) Friday. It also was felt in Tehran, 185 miles to the southeast, and in Rasht, capital of the Gilan province which is only 30 miles north of Rudbar. On June 21 an earthquake registering between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale killed at least 40,000 people and injured about 60,000 by Iranian estimates. About half a million were left homeless. The region has been hit by numerous aftershocks. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake measuring 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage and one registering 6 can cause severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's President-Elect Reaffirms Economic Shakeup Plans
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Alberto Fujimori has returned home largely empty-handed from a weeklong trip to the United States and Japan, but he has reaffirmed his plans to shake up Peru's reeling economy. Fujimori, speaking at an airport news conference after arriving Friday, said he will raise taxes, free up foreign exchange rules and privatize many state companies. The measures will help attract foreign lenders, he said. ``Peru with only its own resources will not be able to escape its crisis,'' said Fujimori, who succeeds President Alan Garcia on July 28. Inflation in Peru tops 2,000 percent per year. Four of five people lack steady work. The government is bankrupt and has been selling gold bars to import food. Fujimori appeared tired after the flight from Tokyo. He was met by about 100 supporters waving banners and playing music. In Japan, Fujimori met with government officials and Emperor Akihito. In New York he met with the leaders of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. The only aid Fujimori was promised on his trip was $4.6 million in agricultural credit from the Japanese government. Other aid will be contingent upon introduction of an approved adjustment plan, Fujimori said. Fujimori, winner of a June 10 presidential runoff, has been sharply criticized by Peru's strong left-wing parties for reversing a campaign pledge not to apply an economic ``shock'' program. At the airport, the president-elect said the ``adjustments will not affect the majority of the population.''

DOC.HEAD: Berrigan to Speak at Service for Homeless Advocate
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf to ADD that Snyder told co-workers IRS was investigating him.
DOC.TEXT: Anti-war priest Phillip Berrigan, who inspired fellow prisoner Mitch Snyder to a life of social activism, will be among prominent speakers at the homeless advocate's funeral at a shelter in the shadow of the Capitol. Arrangements for the outdoor service Tuesday were being completed Friday as officials determined Snyder, 46, apparently hanged himself this week in despair over problems in his 15-year relationship with fellow homeless advocate Carol Fennelly. Others scheduled to speak include two-time Democratic presidential candidate Jesse Jackson, District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry, comedian-activist Dick Gregory and actor Martin Sheen, who portrayed Snyder in a television movie. Six weeks before his suicide, Snyder told members of his Community for Creative Non-Violence that the Internal Revenue Service was investigating Snyder in connection with royalties he received for the movie that starred Sheen, The New York Times reported today. CCNV spokeswoman Shannon Whight told the newspaper that all the money went into the community, which calls itself non-profit but as a political protest, has not asked the government for tax-exempt status. Ms. Whight said she was uncertain about any other details regarding any IRS probe of Snyder. Snyder had credited Berrigan and his brother, Daniel Berrigan, also a Roman Catholic priest, with helping him change his life after his imprisonment for auto theft 20 years ago. Snyder met the Berrigans at the federal prison in Danbury, Conn., where the brothers were serving time for burning draft cards to protest the Vietnam War. Snyder adopted their methods of social activism and non-violent protest, first joining the anti-war movement and then picking up the cause of homelessness after he moved to the nation's capital in 1973. Snyder's body was discovered Thursday hanging from an electrical cord in his room at the 1,400-bed shelter he created in a former government building a few blocks from the Capitol. He had won the building from the Reagan administration in 1984, using a hunger strike and national publicity as his weapons. Dr. Georges Benjamin, the city's public health commissioner, ruled Friday that Snyder's death was the result of ``asphyxiation by hanging'' and said there was no evidence of foul play. Police called it ``an apparent suicide'' and said a note containing ``suicidal references'' was found near Snyder's body outlining problems in his personal relationship with Fennelly, his partner in running the Community for Creative Non-Violence. Fennelly declined to discuss the situation saying, ``This just isn't the time.'' Snyder was remembered by Jackson at a church memorial service on Friday as ``a man of justice'' who worked tirelessly to assist the downtrodden. Jackson told about 600 mourners that Snyder was a man who heard and answered a ``moral call'' to help the homeless. ``The fact that birds have a home, foxes have a home, and yet men and women, veterans of foreign wars, mothers and fathers, working poor people, have no place to lay their head _ he found that to be a moral disgrace,'' Jackson said.

DOC.HEAD: Students Celebrate After President Resigns, General Strike Appears Averted
DOC.TEXT: Striking students chanted ``Victory! Victory!'' and the premier appealed for calm after Socialist President Petar Mladenov bowed to popular pressure and resigned. Mladenov's announcement Friday night appeared to avert a general strike the students had planned for Monday against the government led by ex-Communists. The students and the political opposition had demanded Mladenov's resignation after a videotape revealed he suggested tanks be used to stop anti-government demonstrators in December. Mladenov's letter of resignation was read on television news Friday night, meeting a deadline set by the students in an ultimatum earlier in the day. Mladenov, who was instrumental in ousting Bulgaria's longtime strongman Todor Zhivkov, said he was resigning because he did not want ``to become the cause for an escalation of tensions in the country,'' BTA reported. Premier Andrei Lukanov appealed for order in the wake of the resignation so that Parliament could hold its first session Tuesday in a calm atmosphere. The students had conducted a 26-day sit-in to push their demands for democratic change after the former Communists won last month's parliamentary elections, the first free balloting in Bulgaria in 58 years. They called for a general strike Monday if Mladenov had not resigned by then. Atanas Kirchev, a student leader, said the students would probably declare an end to their strike, BTA reported. It said students celebrated the resignation with victory chants. Students, teachers and parents from across the country had joined in the student strike in Sofia, and the growing split in public opinion led to fears of violence similar to that which has rocked neighboring Romania in recent months. Mladenov, in a nationwide television address on Wednesday, implicitly admitted having called for the use of tanks during the December demonstrations. Earlier, he had said a videotape in which he was heard to say ``Let the tanks come'' was doctored. But experts said it was authentic. The videotape was broadcast on TV on an election program by the main opposition alliance, the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces, three days before the June 17 parliamentary runoff elections. The film was made Dec. 14, when about 50,000 angry demonstrators converged on Parliament to demand that the Communist Party give up its monopoly on power. The protesters later dispersed peacefully and tanks were not called in. Mladenov came to prominence in November when he and other reform-minded party members ousted hard-liner Zhivkov after 34 years. Mladenov, who had served as foreign minister for 18 years, replaced Zhivkov as Communist Party leader and president. He immediately began taking cautious steps toward reform and opened a dialogue with opposition groups that quickly organized. In April, the Communists changed their name to the Socialist Party and won 211 of the 400 seats in parliament in the June elections. The Union of Democratic Forces won 144 seats. Mladenov was to have served until the parliament drew up a new democratic constitution, in about 18 months. Most of the original demands of the students, on strike since June 11, have been fulfilled, including the resignation of the TV director and publication of alleged election irregularities. But according to BTA, the students drew up a new list of demands Friday. They have demanded that a date be set for a public trial of Zhivkov, 78, who is in detention. He has been charged with misappropriation of state property, inciting ethnic hostility and grave abuse of power. They also demand the removal of parliamentary deputies associated with the former Communist regime's decisions, such as setting up harsh prison camps and agreeing to take part in the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Operations Halted at Rocky Flats
DOC.TEXT: Security lapses _ including a metal detector that had been adjusted by workers tired of their steel-toe boots setting it off _ prompted a suspension of all nuclear operations at the Rocky Flats plant, officials say. Plutonium operations at the government plant were halted in November while safety and management improvements were made. The new ban applies to other Rocky Flats nuclear operations, virtually all of which are classified. The suspension went into effect Thursday night following an annual inspection by members of the Department of Energy's Albuquerque, N.M., operations office, said Rocky Flats DOE manager Robert M. Nelson. Nelson ordered the suspension to allow for correction of the shortcomings. The duration of the shutdown was not immediately known. The plant, run by EG&G Inc. for the department, is the nation's only maker of plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. Nelson said investigators discovered that security there could be breached, and investigators were sent in during the past few weeks to try to smuggle out items in their clothing such as plutonium and other sensitive materials. Nelson said the only line of defense that failed was a metal detector such as that used at airports, and there were other lines of defense that caught it. Security was lax because workers were wearing steel-toe shoes required by federal regulations that kept setting off the metal detectors, Nelson said. He said workers became frustrated at having to remove their shoes to pass through. He said said workers are now wearing fiberglass-toe shoes. ``Plutonium processing operations are shut down right now, so this was a good time to do it,'' he said. ``Maybe we overreacted when we shut down the plant. They only made it through one line of defense. But to me, that's enough to stop everything.'' Nelson said other violations were found, but none were ``showstoppers.'' They included such things as improper access to classified documents and improper handling of chemicals, he said. He would not elaborate. Energy Secretary James Watkins ordered the halt to plutonium operations late last year to let EG&G address safety and environmental concerns.

DOC.HEAD: Unity Talks Enter Final Stage; Economic Pinch Prompts Protests
DOC.TEXT: Experts from both East and West Germany have held their first full talks on the final stage of creating a single nation, and some sticking points emerged. Also Friday, East Germany was hit by factory workers' warning strikes and farmers' threats to dump their milk because the shift from communism to capitalism is hurting them. Guenther Krause, East Germany's top negotiator and the Parliament state secretary, said Friday the two sides agreed on a timetable of meetings that will result in a final unity treaty by the end of August. Krause also said the exact date of all-German elections _ expected in December _ would be decided by the end of this month. The two nations are negotiating a treaty that will reconcile the differing laws of the countries and build a political framework for a united Germany. One point of disagreement is the new nation's capital. Krause said the treaty should mandate that Berlin is the capital of a united Germany. But West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble told reporters the decision on the capital should be made by a newly elected Parliament of both nations. Bonn is now the West German capital and East Berlin is the East German capital. The political treaty would have to be ratified by both Parliaments. East Germany would then hold elections in October to create five state governments, to match the West German state government system. Under one proposal, common German elections would be held in December and the two countries would formally merge a day later. The political treaty would be the companion piece of the economic pact that went into effect on Sunday and formally combined the economies of the two German states. The economic merger triggered soaring prices in East Germany, where lawmakers on Friday passed a law to break up state grocery chains that suddenly had become unregulated monopolies. Lawmaker Gerhard Schultz said the new rule should help stop the ``exorbitant prices and price dictating.'' The law allows local governments to sell the stores of the huge grocery chains HO and Konsum in their towns to private buyers. Under the former Communist system, all prices in state stores were set by the government. On Friday 120,000 factory workers were striking for job protection and higher wages to compensate for rising prices, and farmers buffeted by Western competition threatened to spill unsold milk in the streets. Farmers in southern Leipzig said Friday they would dump 2,640 gallons of milk on the streets Monday to protest the loss of business, the East German news agency ADN said. East German workers have been staging daily ``warning strikes'' to demand higher wages and protection against widespread joblessness expected as East German enterprises confront Western competition. The East German affiliate of the powerful West German metalworkers union, IG Metall, called more strikes Friday at factories in East Berlin, Frankfurt an der Oder, Cottbus, Potsdam, Hennigsdorf and Eberswalde. More than 120,000 workers took part in one-hour rallies, said Detlef Kuchenbecker, spokesman for the West German union. The strikes were held to coincide with negotiations between the metal union and 151 Berlin-area factories represented by a newly formed East German employers association. IG Metall is seeking labor contracts similar to those it has in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Encampment Vanishes; Public Returns to Park Outside City Hall
DOC.TEXT: Some of the homeless had lived under the trees across from City Hall for more than two years. But within hours, the transients' occupation of Civic Center Plaza seemed like it had never taken place. Office workers ate lunch under the olive trees in the one-block park and children played tag on the grass; mothers wheeled their babies on the paths and old men sat on benches, reading newspapers and chatting. Police rousted some 100 transients from their illegal camp before dawn Friday, the deadline set by Mayor Art Agnos. Five people were arrested for refusing to leave, and another half dozen arrests took place later in the day. The liberal mayor, who had been under pressure to restore the showpiece park to public use, was enforcing a city ordinance banning camping in public places. After city workers had moved the transients' tents, sleeping bags and assorted possessions to homeless shelters, and hauled away trash, the plaza had an uncharacteristically pristine appearance by midday. Dozens of people who previously steered clear of the park reclaimed the lawns and benches. ``I just sat on the bench ... enjoying the sunshine,'' City Hall employee Tony Pacheco said. ``Normally I wouldn't do that. It looked like a campground until today.'' ``There was a whole bunch of people before, and we were afraid,'' said Karen Valdez, 9, who played with her sister and two brothers. ``We didn't come a lot to the park because there were drunk people around here.'' Police said they planned round-the-clock patrols of the park, which was virtually deserted Friday night, to discourage the homeless from returning. One homeless men who had camped at the park for months pledged to return, even if it meant being arrested. ``I'll just lay here and let them take me, because I'm right. I'm talking about the United States. I've got rights,'' said Kenny Martin, 40. Martin said he had nowhere else to go. He characterized the city's shelters, including two that opened this week, as ``warehousing'' and claimed they had no vacancies. But Larry Bush, an assistant to the mayor, said ``no one has been turned away.'' On Thursday night, the two new shelters, with a total of 140 beds, had about 20 vacancies, he said. Scores of homeless people have lived in the plaza for several years, and their numbers swelled to more than 300 after the Oct. 17 earthquake, which destroyed or made uninhabitable many residential hotels. Police officers used a ``low-key, friendly approach'' in telling the campers to leave, said Police Chief Frank Jordan. ``We're going to take it a day at a time, but long term we think it is a step in the right direction,'' he said. Five homeless people went to court Friday, asking a judge to stop the arrests. They claimed the ordinance violates the rights of the homeless and that the arrests are cruel and unusual punishment because the homeless have nowhere else to go. Superior Court Judge John Dearman refused to block the arrests but set a July 23 hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Car Wrecks, Homicides Leading Injury Killers of Kids
DOC.TEXT: Auto crashes, homicides, suicides and swimming accidents account for three-quarters of the deaths of more than 22,000 young people in this country each year, the national Centers for Disease Control says. Nearly 13 percent of the 22,411 fatal injuries to children in 1986 were homicides, second only to motor vehicle accidents, the agency said Friday. It said 1986 is the latest year for which complete statistics are available. Auto accidents accounted for 10,535 deaths in people under 20 in 1986, and between 15 percent and 30 percent of those deaths were associated with alcohol, researchers said. The agency said 2,877 people under age 20 died from homicide in 1986, and 660 of them, or 23 percent, were under 5. Suicide was the third leading cause of childhood fatal injuries, accounting for 2,151 deaths in 1986. Males accounted for 80 percent, and the suicide rate was roughly twice as high for whites as for blacks. Drowning, the fourth leading cause of childhood fatal injuries, killed 2,062 youths; it was the most common fatal injury among kids under 5 and among young men 15-19. Death rates for children from causes other than injuries dropped by 56 percent between 1968 and 1986. Deaths from injuries fell 22 percent in the same period, the agency said. In 1986, a total of 71,383 people under 20 died in this country. Dr. Juan Rodriguez, a CDC injury research specialist, said that if the deaths of infants are not included, injuries account for 64 percent of deaths in the under-20 age group. Most homicides, he said, ``were among the older adolescents, the 15-to-19-year-olds. But a lot were the young children; that is quite worrisome.'' Sixty-eight percent of the young homicides occurred among males, and rates for black children were about five times higher than for white children. A companion CDC report noted that fire officials in Arizona's Maricopa County recorded 243 calls for drownings and near drownings involving kids under 5 in 1988-89. About half of those incidents probably could have been prevented with pool fences and adequate gates and latches, the CDC said. Arizona, the agency said, has a high risk of child drownings because of the large number of swimming pools there. Maricopa County alone, which includes the Phoenix area, has an estimated 125,000 public and private pools. Another type of injury, fire and burns, killed 1,619 young people in the U.S. in 1986; 53 percent of those deaths occurred among kids under 5, and 73 percent occurred among kids under 10. For many deadly childhood injuries, preventive measures exist or are being developed, the agency said. Among the measures cited are car air bags, pedestrian barriers and enclosing swimming pools with fences.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Blasts Whaling Commission for Refusing to Lift Whaling Ban
DOC.TEXT: Angry about an International Whaling Commission decision to continue a ban on commercial whaling, Japan is threatening to quit the 37-nation regulatory body. Japan blasted the commission Friday for overwhelmingly rejecting a proposal a day earlier to lift the ban on certain types of commercial whaling. It said the commission caved in to pressure from environmental groups. Japan says the minke whale, the smallest commercially viable whale, is no longer in danger of extinction. Supported by Norway and Iceland, it called for exempting the minke whale from the ban. But the commission, by more than a two-thirds majority, upheld a 1986 moratorium on all commercial whale hunting. ``A group of nations voted as a like-minded bloc and (for their advice) relied on a minority of scientists that are mostly affiliated with anti-whaling organizations,'' said Alan Macnow, spokesman for the Japanese delegation. ``The Japanese are going to give it another year at least to see if the group will accept'' its proposals for limited commercial whaling of the minke whale, Macnow warned. ``If not, the delegation will recommend to their government that they form another (whaling) organization,'' he said. Macnow said the Japanese held talks with delegates from Norway and Iceland to determine the character of a possible new body. Gudmunder Eiriksson, the leader of Iceland's delegation, also accused the commission of allowing politics to pervade in its decisions. The ban on whaling will continue for one more year, until the commission's next meeting, which is scheduled to be held in Iceland. Compliance with the ban is voluntary among members of the commission, which has no enforcement powers. The International Whaling Commission was set up in 1946 by international treaty. The organization, which includes all the world's major whaling nations, works to save whales from extinction. The whaling mortatorium was instituted in 1986, after nearly all the major whale species had been hunted to near-extinction. The commission voted Friday to begin surveying the world's dolphin and porpoise populations. Those fishes have increasingly become the prey of whale fishermen deprived of their customary catch by the four-year ban. In the early 1960s, when Japanese whaling was at its peak, whales provided about 23 percent of all meat consumed in the country. Since then, declining whale supplies have turned it into a delicacy.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Threatens Alaskan Village
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of firefighters today spent another night defending the village of Tok from a 50,000-acre wildfire at its edge. Statewide, more than 180 fires have blackened an estimated 400 square miles. Fire was burning Friday night to within a half-mile of Tok, a community of about 900 people along the Alaska Highway, 260 miles northeast of Anchorage. But most residents planned to leave a shelter and sleep in their own homes overnight. Firefighters had widened the firebreaks protecting the village, and the winds pushing the flames through the spruce forests and tundra had dropped. ``Mother Nature dealt us a good hand. It's overcast and the temperatures are cooler, so we didn't get active burning, really,'' said Rob McWhorter, a Bureau of Land Management spokesman. On Thursday, the fire burned to within a quarter mile of the village because of gusty winds. Despite the apparent stall in the fire, McWhorter said it was too soon to declare the danger over. ``Today's weather is supposed to be the same kind of high temperature, relative low humidity, and possible gusting winds that was the situation when the fire blew up Thursday,'' he said. ``We're not out of the woods yet.'' Traffic was a stop-and-go affair for a second day on the Alaska Highway, a primary route for travelers heading north to Fairbanks or south to Anchorage. Authorities closed the highway nine miles outside of town for about a half-hour in early afternoon because of fire and heavy smoke. Traffic then was restricted to one way only. Cars had to be led through the haze by a pilot car. At least 396 square miles were burned across a wide mid-section of the nation's largest state, but equipment, crews and attention have been focused on the Tok fire, the only one posing a significant threat to people and property. Statewide, an estimated 1,200 firefighters were deployed as 37 new fires Friday brought to 184 the number burning out of control across Alaska's interior, said Pat Flowers, a fire spokesman. Most of the fires were blamed on near-record heat, low humidity and lightning, which struck an estimated 2,300 times in a one-day period ending Friday night. No injuries or fatalities have been blamed on the fires, which began last weekend.

DOC.HEAD: First Running of Bulls in Pamplona Gores One, Hurts 58
DOC.TEXT: One Spaniard was seriously gored today and 58 others slightly injured in the first running of the bulls at the weeklong San Fermin festival made famous by U.S. author Ernest Hemingway. The six bulls ran the half-mile stretch from the pens to the bull ring in a very long eight minutes. During the run two bulls left the pack, stopped in the cobblestoned streets and threatened dozens of youths testing their bravery by running before them. The bulls finally headed into the city bull ring. Navarre Hospital said a 24-year-old Spaniard who fell before a bull suffered a deep gore wound to the neck and was in very serious condition. Another Spaniard suffered a broken nose in a fall and 57 other runners received on-site treatment for bruises and scrapes. The festival attracts an estimated 200,000 tourists from around the world to this northern city, doubling its normal population. The bull runs take place every morning and are followed up each afternoon with professional bullfights. The bull running, part of the non-stop drinking and dancing festival in honor of San Fermin, the city's patron saint began Friday and is to continue through July 14. Except during war years, the festival has been held continously since 1591. Since that date bulls have gored to death 52 people, 13 of them since 1924, when Hemingway first visited Pamplona. The writer's 1926 novel, ``The Sun Also Rises,'' described in detail the rowdy, round-the-clock festival that awakens with the morning run of the bulls.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I don't think we're dealing in terms of victory and defeat. ... We're dealing in terms of how do we stabilize and guarantee the peace and security of Europe.'' _ President Bush, discussing the NATO summit in London that changed the defense strategy of the alliance.

``What the award meant to me was that just because you are a dissenter, it doesn't mean you are not loyal.'' _ Princeton graduate Sally Frank on an award by the Alumni Council for her 11-year court battle to open the university's men-only eating clubs open to women.

``When I heard it, I knew what had happened. ... I hollered to my people, `Y'all run, run as fast as you can!' I looked back twice and then I just kept running because I knew if it went again, we'd probably get blown up.'' _ Employee Kathryn Cox, on the explosion that killed 17 workers at an Arco Chemical Co. plant near Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Expatriates Demand More Attention from U.S. Government
DOC.TEXT: Americans living abroad say the U.S. government isn't doing enough to help them solve problems involving taxes, voting, education and citizenship. The U.S. expatriates concluded their first world conference Friday by urging the government not to ignore them just because they don't live in the United States. John F. Crawford, the meeting's co-chairman, said the two-day gathering could eventually lead to an expatriates' ``bill of rights.'' He argued that creating better conditions for the estimated 3 million U.S. citizens abroad could help American competitiveness in world markets. The 200 expatriates, who came from as far away as Brazil and Nigeria for the Paris gathering, said the United States lags behind other nations in helping its citizens overseas. For example, the United States is the only industrial nation that taxes citizen overseas on income earned abroad. It allows expatriates no representation in Congress _ unlike France, for one, whose overseas citizens have six Senate representatives. Overseas Americans can have problems ensuring citizenship for their children. And their schools _ unlike those for Japanese, Germans and French living abroad _ receive no government help. The expatriates are also denied Medicare and Medicaid, even though they make Social Security payments. The group said its goals included congressional representation, a congressional task force to deal with their problems and a high-level panel made up of representatives of various government agencies to handle expatriate concerns. Other ideas discussed at the conference included teacher exchange programs, bringing inner-city American children to foreign American schools to widen their horizons, and getting more overseas Americans to participate in U.S. elections. Rep. Mervyn M. Dymally, R-Calif., said he already was taking steps to set up a congressional task force. Dymally, who was one of 10 members of Congress at the Paris meeting, presided over hearings last November on overseas Americans. He said more hearings were planned this fall. Ben Blaz, who represents the Pacific territory of Guam in Congress, said overseas Americans would have to work to win the attention of Washington or their needs would continue to be ignored. ``The burden is on you to change that attitude,'' he said. The meeting was sponsored by the Association of Americans Resident Overseas, the European Council of American Chambers of Commerce, American Citizens Abroad, Democrats Abroad, Federation of American Women's Clubs Overseas, and Republicans Abroad. Crawford said the mainly Europe-based groups that organized the meeting would try to bring together other Americans-abroad groups in the Middle East, Latin American and Asia. The coalition will try to convene a second conference in Washington in the spring of 1991, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cause Undetermined in Plant Blast That Killed 17
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 7th graf pvs, `It looks ...' with areas to be examined in investigation.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTX1
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators were sent to examine the wreckage of a chemical plant today to find the cause of a thunderous explosion that killed 17 workers and sent dozens of employees scrambling for safety. Two tanks that collected waste water and flammable hydrocarbons exploded at the Arco Chemical Co. plant about 15 miles east of Houston late Thursday. The blast could be heard 20 miles away. ``When I heard it, I knew what had happened,'' said employee Kathryn Cox. ``I hollered to my people, `Y'all run, run as fast as you can!' I looked back twice and then I just kept running because I knew if it went again, we'd probably get blown up.'' The explosion leveled an area the size of a city block. Five people, including two people living near the complex, suffered minor injuries. Investigators with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration were to inspect the charred, twisted metal today in hopes of finding the cause. The roof of a three-story, 900,000-gallon tank blew off and landed 100 yards away in a parking lot. The rest of the tower was scattered over a block-wide area. Several smaller explosions followed. A smaller, connecting tank was blackened. ``It looks like a tornado or fire went through that area,'' said Assistant U.S. Labor Secretary Gerard F. Scannell, who is leading an investigation of the accident. OSHA investigators are looking into a number of aspects at Arco, including the maintenance record and complaints from family members that some employees were having to work long hours, Scannell said. Plant manager Earl McCaleb said the tanks were in operation, but he added that it was believed that ``some kind of work'' was being done on a compressor, which compresses gases before they enter the tanks. Seventeen bodies were pulled from the debris. One victim, an employee of a waste hauling company, was found in the cab of his truck, officials said. Five other victims were Arco Chemical employees, and 11 were employed by a contractor, Austin Industrial Inc. of Houston. More than 50 people were working in the plant at the time, officials said. The plant has more than 350 employees. ``We were running through the mud just as fast as we could get out of there,'' said Tommy McBridge, a plant worker. ``We knew what it was.'' The fire was out by daybreak Friday. Plant firefighters sprayed down the wreckage while other workers searched for bodies amid the twisted pipes and other debris. The plant had one previous safety citation, received in 1988 for a death at an off-site fire training facility, McCaleb said. The plant produces propylene oxide, used to make flexible foam for seat cushions and bedding. The substance also is used for cleaning compounds. In addition, the plant makes styrene monomer, used for insulation, foam drinking cups, packaging materials and auto parts, and methyl tertiary butyl ether, a high-octane blending component used instead of lead in gasoline. Arco Chemical, based outside Philadelphia, has been running the plant since 1980, three years after it went into operation. It was the second major loss of life at a Houston-area petrochemical plant in nine months. On Oct. 23, a Phillips Petroleum Co. plastics plant in Pasadena was hit by series of explosions that killed 23 workers and injured 130. On June 8, two people were injured in an explosion and fire at a chemical packaging plant in Pearland, south of Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Marcos Supporters Celebrate Imelda Acquittal in New York
With PM-Philippines-Aquino, Bjt
LaserPhoto MLA2
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of supporters of former First Lady Imelda Marcos drove around the capital today, held demonstrations and offered masses and prayers to celebrate her acquittal of racketeering charges in New York. About 130 cars and mini-buses filled with Marcos loyalists drove through Manila's major roads flashing ``victory'' signs and shouting ``Marcos still!'' to show their happiness over Monday's verdict clearing Mrs. Marcos. Mrs. Marcos with Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi were cleared of federal racketeering and fraud charges. She had been accused of helping loot the Philippine treasury of $222 million and spending the money to buy art and real estate, much of it in New York. Many of the vehicles carried placards praising the American jury that cleared the 61-year-old Mrs. Marcos. Other placards were saying the acquittal showed that Mrs. Marcos was innocent. The caravan momentarily stopped by a hospital and the seaside cultural center where Mrs. Marcos built several exhibition and convention halls during the 20-year rule of the her late husband ousted President Ferdinand Marcos. Marcos and his family fled the Philippines in February 1986 after a civilian-backed military rebellion toppled his government and installed Mrs. Corazon Aquino to the presidency. The former Philippine strongman died in exile in Hawaii last September before the racketeering charges in which his wife was acquitted went on trial. Mrs. Marcos, however, also faces court proceedings in Switzerland in which the Philippine government seeks to recover hundreds of millions of dollars the Marcoses allegedly robbed from the treasury. Later today, the motorcade broke into two groups and held separate rallies. About 3,000 loyalists attended a rally and mass at the seaside Luneta Park near the U.S. Embassy. Some 500 others demonstrated infront of the central post office building, a few miles away. ``We have reason to rejoice,'' said Rally de Guzman, a leader of one of several loyalist groups at the Luneta. ``The verdict favored the First Lady because she was innocent. The charges were filed by her political enemies and you know how dirty politics can be.'' De Guzman said they were still awaiting word from Mrs. Marcos on whether her lawyers in Manila would file a new petition before the Supreme Court asking the tribunal to allow her to return following her acquittal. The high court had earlier agreed to a government ban on the return of Mrs. Aquino, saying she remains a threat to national security. ``Mrs. Aquino is afraid of Imelda Marcos because she knows that she is not the legitimate president,'' de Guzman added. ``even though Marcos is dead, the loyalist know that the First lady can take over.'' During the rally, copies of a letter allegedly from Mrs. Marcos and her family were distributed. The letter thanked the loyalists for their moral support while the trial was ongoing. ``My acquittal is God's answer to all our prayers,'' the letter said. ``Even as we thank the lord for my vindication, let us join together in fervent prayers that this be the beginning of genuine reconciliation....'' A mass was held at the rally and officials said many more masses would be held later today in several churches in Manila.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier to Face Court-Martial From Death During Panama Invasion
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year soldier has been ordered court-martialed on charges of murdering a Panamanian during the U.S. invasion. In ordering the trial, Fort Bragg commander Lt. Gen. Gary Luck on Friday reduced the charge against Master Sgt. Roberto Enrique Bryan from premeditated murder to unpremeditated murder. Bryan, 42, is charged in the Dec. 23 shooting of an unidentified Panamanian. The Army Times, an independent publication, reported that Bryan is accused of shooting a prisoner taken after a firefight near an electrical generating station. Fort Bragg spokesman Maj. Doug Foster refused to comment on the incident. If convicted, Bryan could receive life in prison and dishonorable discharge. No date was set for the court martial. ``Our argument will be that the killing was a lawful but unfortunate killing,'' said Bryan's lawyer, Mark Waple. At least three other U.S. soldiers have been prosecuted for their actions during the invasion that drove Gen. Manuel Noriega from power. Two soldiers were charged with the unpremeditated murder of a civilian during a firefight investigators said was staged to cover up a soldier's loss of his military handgun. One soldier was convicted and one acquitted. Another soldier pleaded guilty to obstruction, conspiray and other charges in the slaying.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Bill Requiring Label for Record Lyrics
With PM-Louisiana Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana Senate has passed a bill that would require the music industry to put warning labels on recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, drugs, child abuse and satanic worship. The measure passed 28-9 Friday. It goes back to the House for approval of amendments. ``We pass bills all the time to have clean air, clean water,'' said Sen. Oswald Decuir. ``Why can't we do something to clean up the environment for children?'' The measure originally made retailers responsible for labeling records, tapes and compact discs. But it was amended to put the onus on the recording industry. A manufacturer could be fined up to $3,000 for each item sold to a minor without the label. A retailer who fails to heed the label and sells such a recording to a minor could get up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine. Opponents questioned the measure's constitutionality and warned that the local economy could lose millions of dollars. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has said it will no longer consider New Orleans as a site for the Grammy Hall of Fame if the bill becomes law. The National Association of Record Merchandisers has threatened to cancel a 1992 convention in New Orleans. In May, the record industry unveiled a voluntary labeling system that it hoped would halt campaigns in some states for mandatory labeling. It became effective this month. Jay Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, said at the time that 16 of the 21 state legislatures considering such bills had backed down since the industry announced its plans. Earlier this week, Capitol Records promised to provide legal help to store operators threatened with arrest for selling its recordings that bear labels warning consumers of sexually explicit lyrics. Last month, two members of the rap group 2 Live Crew were arrested in Florida for performing songs from their sexually explicit ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' album at an adults-only show. A federal judge has declared the album obscene in South Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyer Says Jogger Might Not Have Been Raped
DOC.TEXT: A defense lawyer suggested that the jogger who was beaten nearly to death in Central Park might not have been raped. The question came up during cross-examination Friday of Dr. Robert Kurtz, the surgeon who supervised the the woman's treatment at Metropolitan Hospital. Under questioning by Robert Burns, a lawyer for one of three teen-agers charged with rape and attempted murder in the 1989 attack, Kurtz testified that there was no evidence of injury in the woman's genital or rectal area. He added that lack of such evidence is not unusual in rape cases. The defense attorney did not ask Kurtz directly whether he was certain the jogger had been raped. Outside the courtroom he said, ``What we are really saying is that the examination of the genital area did not show any injury.'' Burns went on to say that if the jogger ``was fighting vigorously, as a woman who is resisting would,'' there should have been some evidence of injury. But Kurtz said, ``You don't fight with your genitals. You fight with your arms and legs and fists.'' The jogger, a 29-year-old investment banker, was jumped by a gang of youths in the park and apparently left for dead. She recovered and is back at work. On trial are Yusef Salaam, 16, Antron McCray, 15, and Raymond Santana, 16.

DOC.HEAD: `Dartman' Hits 52nd Victim; Bullets Could Be Next, Psychologist Says
DOC.TEXT: Dartman, the mystery figure who gets his kicks blowing darts at the backs and buttocks of well-dressed women, could turn more violent if he remains on the loose, a psychologist says. ``Next stage would be bullets instead of darts,'' Harvey Schlossberg, former head of the Police Department's psychological services unit, was quoted as saying in today's Daily News. ``He has got to increase the amount of pain and reaction by the victim to give himself pleasure.'' On Friday, hours after Police Commissioner Lee Brown appealed for help from the public, the attacker hit his 52nd victim since June 26. All the attacks have taken place in daylight in midtown Manhattan, the most crowded part of town. Dubbed Dartman by the city's tabloids, the attacker has repeatedly blown two-inch homemade darts at his victims. Not all of the darts have met their mark, some becoming entangled in clothing, and no one has been seriously hurt. Judith Blitman, a psychiatrist and professor of clinical psychology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, suspects the attacker will curtail his activities as police close in. ``He feels attacked himself,'' she told the Daily News. ``He'll be quite scared by all the publicity.'' In Friday's attack, a passerby saw an attack on a woman in a blue business suit. Police said the passerby warned the woman, who pulled the homemade dart out of her clothing and kept walking. The witness called a police hotline and reported the attack. He said the man who appeared to have fired the dart fled. Earlier, Brown asked people who work in midtown to call police if they spotted a man resembling the one in a police sketch. ``There's enough to worry about walking through the city without this,'' said Liz Echauss, 22, who was dressed in a smart blue linen suit for a job interview.

DOC.HEAD: Social Worker Gets Probation for Child Abuse Conviction
DOC.TEXT: A social worker who allowed a foster child to return to his parents' home, where he was killed for soiling his pants, plans to appeal after being placed on three years' probation, her lawyer says. Margaret Barber, 62, who could have been sentenced to up to five years in prison, was the first employee of the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services ever criminally convicted over the handling of a case. Ms. Barber, the main foster-care worker for 2-year-old Bradley McGee of Lakeland, was found guilty of negligence June 15 in recommending to a judge that the foster child be returned to his parents, while not providing the court with a psychological report describing the parents as explosive and infantile. Bradley died two months later of head injuries after repeatedly being shoved head first into a toilet for soiling his pants, authorities said. Thomas Coe, 23, and Sheryl Coe, 21, each were charged with first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in the child's death. Mrs. Coe pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and is serving 30 years in prison while her husband faces trial next week in Fort Myers. ``I believe I did everything with the best of intentions and there were no malicious acts,'' Ms. Barber said before sentencing Friday. But Circuit Judge J. Tim Strickland said negligence, not evil intent, was the issue. Ms. Barber's lawyer, John Liguori, said he planned to appeal the conviction on grounds that crucial evidence was disallowed and that the jury didn't take its job seriously, even reportedly throwing a party during deliberations. ``To some extent Margaret Barber was the scapegoat for whatever failings were in the system,'' Liguori said. ``I will carry on,'' Ms. Barber told about 100 fellow HRS workers who cheered her as she left court. So far, her colleagues have raised more than $1,000 for her appeal. Public outrage over Bradley's death led legislators to change the law to make child safety a top priority instead of family reunification. Three other HRS workers were cleared of misdemeanor charges in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershock Shakes Northern Iran; Weaker Quake in South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs of background at bottom on post-quake rebuilding.
DOC.TEXT: A powerful aftershock jolted quake-shattered northwestern Iran overnight, panicking residents, setting off landslides and injuring two people, official media reported today. The official Islamic Republic News Agency also reported a tremor near the southern Iranian city of Yazd this morning, but it was considerably less powerful than the aftershock in the north. IRNA and Tehran Radio, monitored in Nicosia, said the aftershock struck the city of Rudbar in Gilan province, at 11:05 p.m. Friday (3:35 a.m. EDT today). Tehran University's Geophysics Center said it registered 5.9 on the Richter scale. More than 400 aftershocks have hit Gilan since the devastating June 21 earthquake, which killed about 40,000 people, injured 60,000 and left about half a million people homeless. The initial quake was measured at between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale. The aftershock Friday was felt in Tehran, but caused no casualties or damage in the Iranian capital, IRNA said. The quake near Yazd, 370 miles from Tehran, measured 4.9 on the Richter scale, the center said. The agency and the radio initially reported Rudbar had been hit by a new earthquake, but in later dispatches IRNA called it an aftershock. IRNA said two people in Rudbar were taken to hospitals for treatment. The earthquake-flattened city has only makeshift relief clinics, however. The news agency said the aftershock triggered landslides in the mountainous region that blocked two main roads, but it said crews immediately moved in and worked until the roads were cleared. Gilan and Zanjan, another agricultural province to its south, bore the brunt of the June 21 quake. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake measuring 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage and one registering 6 can cause severe damage. Iranian Interior Minister Abdollah Nouri said this week that it would be overwhelmingly difficult to rebuild the earthquake-stricken region. The interior minister said Iran needed to repair roads, water systems and electrical service, as well as replace buildings. The cost just to repair residences and the water and electrical systems will be $1 billion, he said. He said 90,000 residences had been damaged in the quake. Most of them were made of mud brick or kiln-dried brick with little reinforcement in the walls. He said Iran had two months to build shelter before the rainy season begins in September.

DOC.HEAD: Army Gets New Powers, Slaps Indefinite Curfew in Capital
DOC.TEXT: The governor of the troubled northern state of Kashmir ordered an indefinite curfew in the capital effective today and gave the army full control of the battle against Moslem separatists. Soldiers in camouflage uniforms manned checkpoints and patrolled in machine-gun mounted jeeps, strictly enforcing the curfew, said residents who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Hindu-dominated government announced a Special Powers Ordinance giving the army command of countering the Moslem insurgency, newspapers reported. In the past, the army was subordinate to the police and paramilitary forces. Residents said they feared the move could be the start of a fresh crackdown and more violence in the state, which borders Moslem Pakistan. Jammu-Kashmir Gov. Girish Saxena signed the order Friday, permitting army troops to conduct searches and destroy militant hideouts and ordering an indefinite curfew in Srinagar, the newspapers said. On Thursday Saxena empowered security forces to fire at any suspected insurgent and search and destroy any building. Srinagar has been the focal point of the Moslem movement for secession of the Kashmir valley from Hindu-majority India. At least 668 people have been killed in the picturesque Himalayan valley since Jan. 20, when the government first ordered a crackdown on Moslem insurgents. However, the insurrection has shown no signs of abating. Jammu-Kashmir state is the only one of India's 25 states which has a Moslem majority. A separatist movement has been simmering in the Kashmir valley since 1947, after its Hindu ruler opted for union with India when the subcontinent was divided into Hindu-majority India and Islamic Pakistan. The insurgency flared this year after Moslem insurgents dropped their demand for union with Pakistan and began agitating for independence and the status of an neutral nation. The government responded by dismissing the state government and bringing the province under the federally-appointed governor. On Friday, Interior Minister Mufti Mohammed Sayeed said the state would be brought under direct federal rule from July 19, when six months of governor's rule expires. The decision is a technicality, since Gov. Saxena will remain the federal government's representative in the state. But it indicates that the government has no immediate plans to hold elections to the state assembly. Under state law, governor's rule cannot be extended beyond six months, but federal or president's rule can remain in force for up to three years.

DOC.HEAD: Dry in Northeast; Storms over Northern Plains, Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Dry, mild weather prevailed over much of the nation today, and thunderstorms rumbled across the northern Plains and the Great Lakes. Much of the South and West were expected to have dry weather, and a band of scattered storms were likely between the Great Lakes and the mid-Atlantic coast. In the Southwest, showers and thunderstorms were expected to taper off. On Friday, temperatures remained unseasonably warm over portions of the Southeast. Rain and showers were scattered over the western Mid-Atlantic states, parts of the Appalachias and the Plains. Rain also fell in the Rockies, across Washington state and the desert Southwest. The nation's high Friday was 111 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: South Korea Said Rethinking Rebuff of North Korea Border Opening
DOC.TEXT: South Korea may join North Korea in opening a strip of border for the first time in four decades, an influential newspaper said today. North Korea said Friday it would open a portion of its frontier at the truce village of Panmunjom on Aug. 15 in order to promote Korean unity, and called on South Korea to do the same. South Korea initially dismissed the move as propaganda. But the Dong-A Ilbo newspaper, quoting an unidentified government official, said today that Seoul was reconsidering. Also today, Kim Dae-jung, South Korea's best-known opposition politician, expressed support for the North Korean move and asked the Seoul government to broaden contact with North Korea at all levels. Kim, addressing a rally, also urged the Seoul government to accept a North Korean proposal to share a single seat in the United Nations with rotating representation. In another development today, South Korean officials said North Korea agreed to reopen talks aimed at setting up a joint meeting of lawmakers from the capitalist South and the Communist north. The talks, suspended since January, were to resume July 19. Longtime observers expressed hopes that this week's developments could lead to an easing of tensions between the Koreas. The peninsula has been divided since 1945. North-South negotiators agreed in principle this week to meet July 26 to sign accords for a historic first meeting of prime ministers of the two nations. The talks are expected to be held in Seoul in August. North Korea said Friday it would open an 800-yard stretch of border at Panmunjom, a truce village inside the 2.5-mile-wide demilitarized zone, on Aug. 15. Korea was liberated from Japan on that date in 1945. Panmunjom is an oval-shaped enclave straddling a western portion of the 155-mile border between the two Koreas. It is where military officials of both sides meet to discuss alleged armistice violations. The area is off-limits to civilians. North Korea said it would not allow outsiders to travel into the north beyond the perimeter of Panmunjom. The initial South Korean response was negative, but Dong-A said some within the government were rethinking their stance. ``Although the North Korean move is believed to be propaganda, we would not reject it totally. We would rather use it to help ease tension and bring them to openness,'' the paper quoted the unidentified official as saying. The paper said the South Korean government may reciprocate by opening its own sector of Panmunjom, and suggest that the border village be made a meeting place for 10 million separated family members in the two Koreas. South Korea also may propose building a ``peace city'' jointly with North Korea inside the demilitarized zone, it said. North Korea has rejected similar proposals in the past. Seoul officials said they suspect that the North Korean move is aimed at encouraging South Korean dissidents to hold a unification rally at Panmunjom on Aug. 15. A major South Korean dissident group, Chonminyon, welcomed the North Korean announcement and said it will send 300 delegates to meet with North Koreans that day. The Seoul government bans unauthorized contact with North Korea by its citizens. It contends dialogue with the North Koreans must be conducted through official channels.

DOC.HEAD: Text Of IRNA Dispatch On Hostages
With PM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Following is the text of a report in English from Beirut, Lebanon, carried by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency. It anticipates the release of a Western hostage: A Western hostage held in Lebanon will probably be released soon, informed sources said Saturday. The sources declined to disclose name of the hostage, but hinted that he is most probably a European national. It is not known when and where the hostage will be released.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO RESTORE BYLINE
IRNA Says Western Hostage Likely To Be Freed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs, RECASTING lead to bring wording into line with IRNA dispatch and UPDATE with Syrian source saying Keenan likely to be freed, other details. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Iranian President...' TRIMS.
DOC.TEXT: Iran's official news agency reported today that one of the 16 Western hostages held in Lebanon _ most likely a European _ will probably be freed soon. Most Western hostages in Lebanon are believed held by factions of Hezbollah, or Party of God, a fundamentalist Shiite Moslem group that gets considerable financial support from Iran. ``A Western hostage held in Lebanon will probably be released soon,'' said the Islamic Republic News Agency's five-sentence dispatch from Beirut, Lebanon, citing ``informed sources.'' It said the sources refused to disclose the identity of the hostage to be released, but ``hinted that he is most probably a European national.'' The English-language IRNA report, monitored in Nicosia, said ``it is not known when and where the hostage will be released.'' The hostages include six Americans and 10 Europeans _ four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. In Beirut, a source close to the Syrian army command said if a hostage were to be released, it would ``probably'' be Brian Keenan, the Irishman who also holds a British passport. The source spoke on condition of anonymity and refused to provide any other information. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon. It has 40,000 troops in northern and eastern provinces as well as the Moslem sector of the capital. Keenan, 39, was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut April 11, 1986, as he walked from his home to the American University of Beirut, where he taught English. No group has claimed the abduction of Keenan, of Belfast. But American educator Frank Reed said after his release in April that he had seen Keenan. Two underground factions in Lebanon, the Organization of Islamic Dawn and the Arab Revolutionary Cells-Omar Mukhtar Brigade, had claimed to hold Reed. Iran played a key role in mediating the release of Reed and another American hostage in Lebanon, Robert Polhill. The first word of a possible release of hostages in April had come from IRNA in short, similarly worded dispatches. Within days, Polhill was freed and Reed's release followed. Iran said then it would work for the release of other hostages if the United States and Western governments make a ``gesture of goodwill.'' Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani and other Iranian officials suggested that Western governments pressure Israel to release about 300 inmates, most of them Lebanese Shiites, held at a detention camp in south Lebanon. The inmates are suspected guerrillas involved in an underground warfare against Israeli troops and allied militiamen of the South Lebanon Army who control a border strip in south Lebanon. Israel has said it would not agree to any such deal unless it also involved freeing three Israeli servicemen believed held by Shiite groups after disappearing in south Lebanon. An outpouring of Western assistance to Iran after the devastating June 21 earthquake had raised hopes in some quarters that Iran might use its influence with the pro-Iranian groups believed holding the hostages. Rafsanjani has said Iran should be grateful for the foreign quake aid. However, in comments earlier this month, he made no link between such aid and the release of any Western hostages. Rafsanjani, seeking closer ties with the West, has been in conflict with hard-line Moslem fundamentalists in the government who oppose his efforts. Iran also has demanded that the Western governments help shed light on the fate of four Iranians who were kidnapped in 1982 by a right-wing Lebanese Christian militia in north Lebanon. Christian leader Samir Geagea has said that when he seized command of the Lebanese Forces militia in 1985, he found no trace of the Iranians, and blamed their murder on his rival predecessor Elie Hobeika. But Iranian officials have in recent weeks insisted that they have word that the missing Iranians are still alive. Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East bureau chief for The Associated Press, is the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. He was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Christian Science Trial, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0445,0447
DOC.HEAD: Christian Science Couple Must Take Their Children to a Doctor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf to CORRECT former town to Boston sted Hyde Park, which is a neighborhood, add couple's ages. Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: A Christian Science couple convicted of manslaughter for relying on prayer to heal their dying son said they would abide by a judge's order to take their other children to a doctor for regular check-ups. The requirement was part of the 10 years' probation handed out Friday to David and Ginger Twitchell. ``We always tried to obey the law, both in '86 and now, and we'll try to obey the judge's instructions,'' Twitchell said. The couple were convicted Wednesday of recklessly and wantonly causing the death in 1986 of their 2{-year-old son, Robyn, by not seeking medical care for the boy, who had a bowel obstruction. They could have received 20 years in prison. Superior Court Judge Sandra Hamlin imposed probation under maximum supervision and ordered the couple to take their three remaining children for checkups under guidelines set by the American Medical Association. Hamlin also said that at ``any signs of serious illness'' in the children _ who range in age from 9 months to 8 years _ a doctor must be called in. In a statement, Twitchell said that while he would obey the order, he would ``always pray first'' for his children's health. ``We have never ruled out medical care. We just feel prayer, God's power, is a lot better,'' said Twitchell. The former Boston residents, both 34, now live in Brentwood, N.Y. The Christian Science Church teaches that sickness can be healed by spiritual means alone. Church officials have said the case is an attack on their religion and expressed confidence the verdict will be overturned on appeal. The trial has garnered wide attention, in part because it was held in Boston, where the Christian Science Church has its headquarters. Since 1980, there have been seven prosecutions of Christian Science parents on such charges as murder, manslaughter and neglect. Five have been convicted, one acquitted, and one case was thrown out, child rights activist Rita Swan. No one was jailed in those cases. Prosecutor John Kiernan had asked for a long period of probation for the Twitchells, periodic checkups of their children and a requirement for community service. Defense attorney Steve Lyons had asked that the Twitchells receive four years' probation with no conditions. He said required checkups would place a ``medical policeman'' in the Twitchell home when ``there are no guarantees with medicine.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO FIX CODING
Mixed Reviews From Two Germanys For NATO Summit
With PM-Summit-NATO, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West Germany welcomed results of the NATO alliance meeting, especially a decision that the size of a united German military should be negotiated at ongoing arms talks in Vienna. But East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and his foreign minister criticized the alliance for not renouncing the first use of nuclear weapons in Europe, where the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact alliance is unraveling. De Maiziere, in an interview Friday night with West Germany's ZDF television network, said the results of the London summit, which ended Friday, ``in many points remained behind our expectations.'' He said the process of German unification would be considerably easier if NATO would abandon its policy of ``flexible response'' and renounce the first use of nuclear weapons. Flexible response leaves open the possibility that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization could counter a conventional attack with nuclear weapons. The strategy was developed as a deterrent against the Warsaw Pact's superior numbers of troops and tanks, but the Soviet-led alliance is losing strength and relevance after last year's democratic upheaval in Eastern Europe. The NATO leaders, in concluding their two-day summit, said the alliance would from now on regard its own nuclear arms as weapons of ``last resort.'' But at the insistence of Britain, they said ``there are no circumstances in which nuclear retaliation in response to military action might be discounted.'' The leaders also proposed the elimination of nuclear artillery shells from Europe. But NATO will still have 700 short-range Lance missiles in Europe. East Germany's foreign minister, Markus Meckel, said the danger of a nuclear war in Europe remained as long as NATO has an arms mix of conventional and atomic weapons, according to the East German news agency ADN. ``We believe that Europe doesn't need atomic weapons for its security. This is why we reject for Germany the stationing ... ownership and transport of such mass means of destruction,'' ADN quoted Meckel as saying.
