Meckel's West German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, was considerably more upbeat, calling the London gathering ``a historic summit for Europe.'' ``The German delegation was very satisfied with the outcome of the summit,'' a government source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Another source said ``it was our very clear intention'' to have the size of a united Germany military negotiated at the conventional arms talks in Vienna. The Soviet Union had wanted the question of German troop levels, one of the contentious points in discussions over approaching German unification, negotiated in the ``two-plus-four'' talks among the four World War II victors and the Germanys. West Germany rejected that idea, not wanting its forces to be singled out among Europe. Negotiating the size of Germany's military in the ``two-plus-four'' talks would have amounted to the victorious World War II allies setting German troop limits. But negotiating it in the context of the conventional armed forces in Europe talks puts the question in the broader context of European security. Genscher, in an interview from London with West Germany's RIAS radio, said the summit had sent a ``clear and significant political signal'' to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe that there would be cooperation on disarmament. And he said Germany could lead the way in that cooperation by giving the Soviets assurances on what would be the future strength of a united German military. West Germany's full-time military troop level is 465,000, with 30,000 active-duty reservists who can be called into action immediately. East Germany's military strength, debilitated by defections following the collapse of the Communist government, is 97,000, East Germany's defense ministry said this week. Defense ministry sources in Bonn said this week the government was willing to consider limiting post-unification troop strengths to about 400,000. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said at the last round of ``two-plus-four'' talks in Berlin the Soviets would like to see a united German army of between 200,000 and 250,000 troops.
Checked state department and Anita Stockman is press ofificer there and today's duty press officer. WX-naylor

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Terrorist Reportedly To Speak On Group's Activities
DOC.TEXT: A terrorist suspected of belonging to the Red Army who gave herself up to West German police has agreed to speak out on the group's structure and recent attacks, according to news reports today. But the woman, Susanne Albrecht, has refused to detail alleged ties between terrorists and East Germany's ousted Communist leadership, Der Spiegel magazine reported. Albrecht, 39, was arrested in East Germany but voluntarily surrendered to West German police last week. She was one of eight alleged Red Army members who lived in East Germany under false identities supposedly supplied by the now-disbanded East German secret police. West Germany had a warrant out for her arrest for her alleged role in the July 30, 1977, shooting death of West German banker Juergen Ponto. Der Spiegel's article is to appear in its Monday issue, but an advance text was provided by the magazine today. Der Spiegel did not say how it had obtained information on her testimony to police. The magazine quoted West Germany's chief prosecutor, Alexander von Stahl, as saying he did not expect the seven other Red Army suspects held in East Germany to be extradited. Instead, von Stahl said the seven would probably stand trial under West German law after the two Germanys formally unite. ``There's hardly time to begin criminal (extradition) proceedings before unification,'' von Stahl said. A formal merger of the two German states is expected in December. However, Von Stahl did call on the seven suspects still in East German custody to surrender to West German authorities. No group in East Germany has taken responsibility for hiding the Red Army suspects, although West German media have accused ousted Communist Party chief Erich Honecker and the head of the Stasi, Erich Mielke, of doing so. The hard-line Communist leadership was ousted last year.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Attack Monrovia's Port Near President's Mansion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD U.S. denial that Marines supplied Doe with water, sub 8th graf pvs, `The United...' with 3 grafs. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `In Abidjan...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based on a pool report filed by reporters in Monrovia and reports from Ivory Coast and Washington. Associated Press correspondent Michelle Faul was among the Liberia pool reporters.

Rebels have tightened their noose on the capital, attacking the port near the fortified mansion of besieged President Samuel K. Doe. ``Don't die for Doe,'' rebels only two miles from the executive beachfront enclave urged demoralized government troops on Friday. Many soldiers were abandoning their posts. Meanwhile, renewed talks to end the 6-month-old civil war in this West African nation stalled Friday because a rebel delegation had not reached the negotiating site in neighboring Freetown, Sierra Leone. Doe, who seized power in a bloody coup in 1980, was holed up in his mansion with troops of his minority Krahn tribe who have remained loyal. His top commanders and advisers fled last week. The rebels led by Charles Taylor, a former Doe aide, accuse the government of corruption and human rights abuses. Automatic rifle fire and artillery blasts echoed across the capital from dawn until noon Friday, and plumes of smoke from explosions rose from the city outskirts. A rebel fishing trawler fired at a coast guard cutter about five miles offshore, and a cannon from Doe's Israeli-built mansion fired two shells into the ocean to deter rebel boats. Witnesses said the rebels withdrew from the port later in the day. The United States supplied water to the president's mansion under heavy guard by U.S. Marines, a witness said. Four American vehicles escorted a water tanker to the mansion early Friday morning, the witness said. In Washington today, State Department press officer Anita Stockman denied that the United States had escorted tankers or delivered water to Doe. ``The situation remains the same in Monrovia. We're certainly not providing water to Doe,'' she said. In Abidjan, Ivory Coast, diplomatic sources said Doe had asked the United States to ferry him and 100 troops to his home region of Grand Gedeh County. The United States refused the request, which would have enabled Doe to continue the war, the sources said. A senior U.S. government source in Washington said Doe had mentioned a desire to visit his home region, but did not ask for assistance to get there. The United States has offered to help Doe leave Liberia, a condition set by rebels before they will accept a cease-fire. Doe reportedly has offered to resign on condition his safety and that of his Krahn tribe is guaranteed. A senior rebel official, based in the United States, rejected a reported plan for the six West African nations that were leading the negotiations to send a peacekeeping force to Liberia to oversee new elections. But the rebel official, Tom Woewiyu, said he would go to Freetown for the talks. Soldiers continued to loot in Monrovia under cover of a dusk-to-dawn curfew, but residents said the looting was less widespread than during the previous night. Many of the city's 500,000 residents searched for food and carried buckets of water from rapidly depleting wells. Monrovia has been without water for nine days and without electricity for one week. Most shops and markets have been closed all week, and some people have been begging for food or collecting leaves to eat. The rebels began attacking the capital on Monday, but their progress has been slow. Rebel sources in Ivory Coast said 4,500 more troops joined the original assault contingent of 800 men Wednesday night, but the insurgents failed to live up to their claim that they could take Monrovia in 12 hours. The rebels invaded Dec. 24 from the Ivory Coast. Doe's forces then killed hundreds of civilian members of the Gio and Mano tribes, seen as the main support base for the rebels. The rebels sought revenge by killing members of Doe's Krahn tribe and the Mandingo people who have supported him. Rebel leader Taylor has gained much support throughout the country, but the United States and other governments have questioned his commitment to democracy and free elections. Reports of summary executions of suspected Doe supporters, as well as the reported execution of one of the founding members of Taylor's movement, also have damaged his credibility.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Forces Congress To Reconsider Vote on Each Politburo Member
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today forced the Communist Party congress to drop a plan to evaluate each member of the party's ruling Politburo, warning the move would ``bury the party.'' Despite rampant criticism of his policies by the largely hard-line congress, meeting for its sixth day, the Soviet leader showed his mastery of the delegates by pushing through the reversal. ``If you want to bury the party, to split the party, then continue on this way,'' he told delegates. ``But think hard.'' Before its afternoon break, the congress voted 2,557-1,393 for an individual thumbs-up or thumbs-down vote on each Politburo member. Delegates later reversed themselves 2,495-1,515 after hearing Gorbachev's opinion. Gorbachev cited a note from the delegation from northern Arkhangelsk that said: ``There is no need to evaluate each Politburo member. The Politburo, according to the rules, is an organ of the leadership, and the leadership is collective.'' Instead, the congress agreed to evaluate as a whole the work of the policy-making Central Committee, and within it the 12-member Politburo. Evaluating each Politburo member separately would have broken a tradition of regarding the body as a collective entity. The idea brought criticism in the corridors of the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses from reformist delegates. ``Our Russian thirst for blood is showing,'' said Inna Dementyeva, a Moscow delegate. ``It's stupid and ugly and inhuman.'' But other party members said they backed the decision because it would let future leaders know that they couldn't hide behind ``collective responsibility.'' ``Collective responsibility is no responsibility,'' said a Byelorussian delegate who identified himself only as Alexander. ``And there should be a full renewal of the leadership.'' Delegates and reporters standing outside the Palace of Congresses said Gorbachev looked angry when he left following the initial vote. On previous days he stopped to talk with bystanders, but today he went straight to his car. Congress members had said they expected at least half the Politburo members would get the thumbs down. Names singled out as most likely to receive negative votes were ideology chief Vadim A. Medvedev _ criticized by many as ineffective _ and Alexander Yakovlev, considered the most radical member of the Politburo. Yakovlev has been unapologetic for his reformist views before the largely conservative congress. The evaluations would have had no practical effect, because the congress chooses a new Central Committee, which would have selected a new Politburo anyway. But they clearly would have left a mark on each man's career. The name-by-name voting also likely would have hurt Gorbachev's position by discrediting some of his allies and helping his rival, Yegor K. Ligachev, who enjoys wide popularity at the congress, delegates said. ``Now there could even be the variant that Ligachev will come to power,'' Anatoly Tubyshkin, a Moscow delegate had said. ``It's very worrying.'' The congress had been expected to begin nominating candidates for its top post today, but by mid-afternoon it appeared nominations would not come by the end of the day. Delegates said there did not appear to be any serious challenge to Gorbachev as party leader. ``At present, we do not have outstanding leaders except Mikhail Gorbachev in the party,'' said Leningrad party chief Boris Gidaspov. In a draft of party rules also expected to come to the floor today, the party's head would still be called general secretary. Both he and a deputy would be elected by the full congress of about 4,700 delegates. With Gorbachev the presumed winner for the post he has held since March 1985, talk in the corridors revolved around who would be his deputy and run the party's day-to-day affairs. Delegates mentioned Ligachev, Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin and Pravda editor Ivan Frolov as contenders. Gorbachev advisor Georgy Shakhnazarov said he thought the deputy might turn out to be a near-unknown, ``someone completely new.'' Delegates said they expected a massive overhaul of the party leadership. Moscow party secretary Yuri Prokofiev said today as much as 80 percent of the leadership might be changed. Yakovlev and other members have already said they plan to retire from the Politburo, and Medvedev indicated today he, too, would be happy to retire and let ``younger, more energetic, more strong-willed people'' take over. The 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party, which opened last Monday, appeared likely to adjourn sometime late next week.

DOC.HEAD: Television Shows Internationally Sought Terrorist with Hungarian Agents
DOC.TEXT: State television today showed what it said was footage of a 1980 meeting in which Communist intelligence agents tried to persuade the international terrorist Carlos to leave Hungary. The footage appeared to back up allegations made three weeks ago that Hungary's former Communist leaders had allowed Carlos, also known as the jackal, to use the country as a base for his terrorist attacks. The report did not indicate how long Carlos allegedly stayed in Hungary. A former Communist official interviewed on the program claimed that the Communists had tried to oust Carlos as soon as they discovered he was operating in the country. The nation's Communist Party disbanded in October. Carlos, a Moscow University graduate, began his life as a terrorist in 1973 and topped Interpol's most wanted list by 1975. In December of that year, he allegedly organized an attack in Vienna on OPEC oil ministers in which three people were killed. Carlos remains at large. State television said the meeting shown in the film took place in 1980 in an office of the Interior Ministry's Department for the Supervision of Foreigners and was filmed without Carlos's knowledge. There was no indication of how the film was obtained. Interior Minister Balazs Horvath said on June 27 that he had instructed the chief prosecutor to investigate former Communist Party officials who allegedly provided shelter and training grounds for Carlos, whose real name is Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, and his terrorist group. The man identified as Carlos in the film spoke fluent but accented English. The two Hungarian agents spoke Hungarian among themselves and English to Carlos. The conversation was poorly recorded and difficult to make out at times, so the film was subtitled. One agent told Carlos that he ``must liquidate your base of operations here, must stop using Hungary from where to direct your group because there is danger. Your operations may be compromised. ``Also, if you were to continue, the interests of the Hungarian People's Republic may be jeopardized if you are associated with us.'' ``You can travel through Hungary or even stay for brief periods,'' the Hungarian official told Carlos, trying to mollify him. Andras Petresevics, one of the agents, said in an interview on the program that the terrorist accused him of being an ``imperialist agent'' and of acting without the knowledge of his superiors to get him to leave. The former Communist chief of counterintelligence, Miklos Redei, also was interviewed in the program. Redei, who also met Carlos, said: ``He gave the impression of being paranoid, afraid, but he was not dumb.'' Horvath said last month that recently discovered documents implicated the late Communist Party leader, Janos Kadar, former Interior Minister Andras Benkei, former President Karoly Nemeth, and Antal Gyenes, former head of the Communist Party's foreign relations department, in the Carlos case. One of the documents produced by Horvath was a letter allegedly written to Kadar by Carlos in 1980, the same year the terrorist apparently left Hunagry. ``From our base in Hungary, we have developed our international ties, getting in contact with the revolutions of every nation without any hindrance on the part of the Hungarian authorities,'' the letter purportedly said. Benkei, Nemeth and Gyenes have denied any role in sheltering terrorists. Redei asserted that a small group of terrorists led by Carlos ``did not come here at the invitation of any Hungarian official. We tried to keep tabs on them after their arrival. At one point we lost them,'' said Redei. ``Carlos was a well-trained agent and could spot a tail easily.'' Redei denied Carlos was provided with any training facilities in Hungary. He said fear of the terrorist kept Hungarian authorities from acting against him. ``We ... knew that if we do anything to him, his group would take revenge.''

DOC.HEAD: Ten More Die In Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Two days of heavy rain in eastern China's Jiangxi province flooded 400 homes and caused a mudslide, killing 10 people, an official report said. So far this summer, at least 400 have died in flooding. Of the 10, four people drowned and one was crushed by a building that collapsed, China News Service reported Friday, in a dispatch seen in Beijing on Saturday. More than 4 inches of rain fell on 14 prefectures. Flooding in southwest China's Yunnan province last month killed at least 108 people, while in the southern province of Hunan at least 254 died. Typhoon Ofelia late last month killed at least 33 in coastal China.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed After Quake in West Java
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sutarjo has one name.
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake jolted West Java, destroying or damaging more than 150 homes and buildings and killing one villager, officials said Saturday. Eleven people were injured. The quake Friday measured 5.2 on the Richter scale of ground motion and was centered in a mountainous area of Majalengka about 185 miles southeast of the capital, said Sutarjo, a government meterology official in Jakarta. The death and injuries all occurred in the Anggarwati area near the epicenter, said Majalengka district administrator Djufri Pringadi. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 5.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 4.5.

DOC.HEAD: Rogue Bell Ringers Peal Trouble
DOC.TEXT: A band of rogue bell ringers has been pealing under false pretenses in Lincolnshire, and vicars throughout England will be on the alert Sunday for rats in their belfries. Six to eight bogus ringers have recently rung unsafe bells at four churches in the diocese of Lincoln, endangering themselves, others and the bells, according to Church of England officials. The rogues struck at St. Clement's in Worlaby and St. Andrew's in Bonby, on the south bank of the Humber, and at two other churches that have not been identified. Similar incidents were reported in Cambridgeshire earlier this year, and a bell tower in a village church was damaged. Robin Heppenstall, secretary of the Lincoln diocese Guild of Church Bellringers, said the pealers duped vicars and church wardens into allowing them into the towers, where they rang bells long silent because of their dangerous condition. ``It is conceivable that the clapper inside the bell could be worn and faulty and if it flies out it could go anywhere,'' Heppenstall said. ``If that went out through a window it could conceivably injure someone seriously,'' he warned. ``It could be churches were thinking of spending a few hundred pounds to make the bell tower safe and the bells operational and then suddenly they are faced with a bigger bill,'' he said. The bells, anchored on frames and weighing about 1,000 pounds, revolve 360 degrees. ``If the frame is badly worn or eaten by woodworm and you start ringing there is considerable force. The whole frame could collapse under the energy of the bell,'' he said. Bell ringers require months of training, Heppenstall said. ``I've seen people lifted several feet into the air _ because they've lost control of the bell,'' he said. ``These tower grabbers are competent people, they appear to have some knowledge of bell ringing.'' Each of the 5,425 belfries in England provides a unique experience for ringers. The size, the weight, the casting and the way the bell is hung contribute to a distinctive toll and feel. ``They sound differently and you can go on a little outing and ring in different places. But they have taken it to an extreme and are ringing where bells are not safe and obviously we are concerned,'' Heppenstall said. Anne Carpenter, assistant editor of Ringing World, a 4,500-circulation weekly newspaper, said there is a proper way to go about testing bells. ``There are those who behave in a decent way and arrange proper outings to ring bells and have lunch. That is a a perfectly civilized way of going about it,'' Ms. Carpenter said. She said this was the first organized band of rogue bell ringers she has heard of since the distinctive English style of change-ringing developed in the 17th century. Such knavery has sent ominous tintinnabulations echoing through the ringing fraternity. ``If a vicar has been conned he won't be keen on bell ringers on the whole, so if anyone asks, `Can I have a ring on your bells?' he will say, `no,''' Ms. Carpenter said. ``I like to visit fresh churches with my learners,'' Heppenstall said. ``It would do them good to ring on bells that are a different weight and I like to take them on an outing. But if I ring up a vicar he might say we don't have visitors here because of the rogue bell ringers, so legitimate requests are refused.''

DOC.HEAD: Black Governor Gets Close Scrutiny in First Six Months
DOC.TEXT: After just six months as Virginia's governor, L. Douglas Wilder is being hailed as a new national leader and hot Democratic presidential prospect. But at home, the nation's first black elected governor is coming under criticism for his travels, unpaid bills and social life. Since becoming governor in January, Wilder has visited 11 states, including the early presidential sweepstakes states of New Hampshire and Iowa, carrying his message of fiscal conservatism and social activism. He criticizes the failures of the Bush administration and tells audiences the same ``new mainstream'' that elected him governor should put a Democrat in the White House. He describes the qualities of the ideal nominee and says ``I'd like to think I'm one of those persons.'' But Wilder insists he has no plans to run for president. The governor maintains that his travels and the attention he gets are helping Virginia, which has not been nationally prominent since Colonial times. ``It's been a long time since Virginia's ever been considered at the national level,'' he said. ``It's to Virginia's credit that the governor has been asked (to travel).'' ``I give Virginia about 18 hours a day, and that's seven days a week,'' Wilder told reporters last month. But the governor has come under criticism for his busy travel schedule and, most recently, for his use of a state helicopter to take personal trips with Patricia Kluge, estranged wife of America's richest man, John W. Kluge. The Kluges, who gave Wilder his biggest campaign contribution of $200,000, separated two months ago. The governor last winter appointed Mrs. Kluge, a former nude model and high school dropout, to the board of visitors of the University of Virginia. ``We're friends,'' Wilder told reporters last month and refused to elaborate. A spokeswoman for Mrs. Kluge gave a similar response. Friends and critics of the divorced governor agree his friendship with Mrs. Kluge is a private matter. ``But when the relationship somehow involves his use of state aircraft, then to that extent it is a public matter,'' the Roanoke Times & World-News said in an editorial. Some blacks say Wilder has been targeted for criticism because of his race. Even whites admit he is being watched closely because of his unique place in American politics. ``By the mere fact of who he is, he's going to get some scrutiny. That's acceptable,'' Jack Gravely, state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said last week. But he added, ``Many black folk that I've spoken to over the holiday have said, `They've got Barry, now they're going after Doug,''' referring to the ongoing trial of Washington's black mayor, Marion Barry, on drug and perjury charges. ``An awful lot of white people are watching Doug Wilder closely. And X percentage of them are hoping he will trip up,'' said a white, longtime observer of Virginia politics who asked not to be identified. Wilder's historic Jan. 13 swearing-in ceremony still is making news with disclosures that his inaugural committee has yet to pay a $148,500 bill for printing the invitations. The governor also has been criticized for refusing to reveal how he will use any profits from his inaugural ball. Lobbyists and corporations contributed an estimated $1 million to pay for the celebration. Meanwhile, Virginia has been having financial troubles of its own. Wilder has said he will announce spending cuts next month to cope with a projected $300 million budget shortfall over the next two years. ``He's worked to cut back state services, all the while establishing himself as the most extravagant governor in Virginia's history,'' said Joe Elton, executive director of the state Republican Party. The governor also has drawn fire for ordering state agencies and institutions to sell stocks in companies doing substantial business in South Africa. Teachers have worried about how the divestment would affect the state's $11 billion employee pension fund. The various criticisms are ``having some impact on his image in-state,'' said Larry Sabato, a University of Virginia political analyst. ``Eventually, it will be part of the national evaluation of Doug Wilder the candidate for vice president or president.'' While disavowing national ambitions, Wilder has shown no reluctance to address national and foreign policy issues. He has asked President Bush to appoint an independent commission to investigate the savings and loan bailout, has expressed support for Israel and has promised to visit the Jewish state as well as Saudi Arabia next year. At the same time, he has shied away from some state issues, such as whether tax-supported Virginia Military Institute should be opened to women. When the governor repeated last month that he has no opinion on VMI's admissions policy, he was met with groans and hoots from an audience of teen-age girls attending a conference on state government. His support among other constituents, particularly blacks, remains strong. ``The overwhelmingly majority of the people in the community that I serve feel that the governor is doing a good job,'' said the Rev. Darrel Rollins, pastor of the 31st Street Baptist Church in Richmond.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Angola Blame Each Other For Famine
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Angola blame each other for a breakdown in efforts to mount a relief operation for hundreds of thousands of Angolans who may face starvation. A representative of the Angolan government said he was worried that the Bush administration could use relief deliveries as a cover for sending weapons to anti-communist rebels in Angola. U.S. officials call that allegation nonsense and say the administration informed the Angolan government some time ago that the U.S. was willing to permit delivery of food shipments by the International Committee of the Red Cross or another neutral relief organization. The affected area is in southern Angola and encompasses territory under the control of both sides in Angola's 15-year old civil war. The government has received substantial aid from the Soviet Union over the years while the United States has been providing covert aid to the UNITA rebels since 1986. The Red Cross estimates that some 250,000 Angolans are in immediate danger of starvation because of recent droughts and the internal conflict. The lives of hundreds of thousands of others could be at risk in the coming weeks. The administration favors an overland food delivery operation through a third country, partly because airlifts are so costly. The countries adjacent to the affected area are Namibia and Botswana. Robert B. Washington, a Washington lawyer whose firm represents the government of Angola, said in a letter this past week to congressmen that authorities in Luanda strongly support food deliveries to Angolans of all persuasions. However, he said the Angolan government has concerns about food deliveries by aircraft or by truck from Namibia or Botswana. ``We hope you can understand the reluctance of the (Angolan) government to allow officials of the administration, who have continued to support additional funding of lethal military aid to the UNITA rebels, to oversee the movement of supplies over unknown boundaries into UNITA-controlled territory,'' Washington told the congressmen in his letter. A State Department official, who spoke only on condition that he not be identified, said the United States has never proposed sending the food into Angola unilaterally. ``We don't know where they got that idea,'' the official said. Washington sent his letter to the members of Congress after UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi wrote to President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev asking them to consider a joint food airlift for Angola. Savimbi also proposed that ``corridors of peace'' be created in Angola, through which international relief convoys could pass with guarantees of safe passage from rebel and government forces. The Bush administration supports that approach. Soviet and American officials have held discussions about a cooperative relief effort but no agreement has been reached. The two countries agreed recently on a joint food airlift for Ethiopia, with U.S. food to be flown on Soviet planes.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Says Asylum Seekers Can Leave Country Without Reprisal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Hungarian official saying Albanians in all embassies will be allowed to leave under supervision for foreign diplomats. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `The rush...'
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of freedom-hungry Albanians crowding about a dozen embassies will be allowed to leave their hard-line Communist nation under foreign supervision, a Hungarian diplomat said today. The diplomat, who spoke from the Albanian capital, Tirana, on condition of anonymity, said the logistics of the departure had not been worked out. But he said ambassadors of embassies harboring up to 5,000 Albanians had been told by Foreign Ministry officials their personnel could supervise the issuing of travel documents and accompany the emigres to their new homelands. Only people who have been accepted by another country will be allowed to leave, the diplomat said in a telephone interview. The reported breakthrough came just hours after Albanian legislators guaranteed that the asylum-seekers could leave the hard-line Communist nation without fear of punishment. The rush on the embassies continued overnight, and there reportedly were up to 5,000 people in more than a dozen missions today. About 10,000 pro-democracy demonstrators gathered in a square near the embassies Friday in the largest demonstration of its kind in 45 years of Communist rule, Austria's APA news agency reported. The silent rally dispersed after a brief clash between police and some demonstrators. The Albanian Foreign Ministry on Thursday promised to grant passports to those who have sought refuge in foreign embassies in a desperate attempt to flee their homeland, which borders Greece and Yugoslavia. But today's parliamentary decree, published by the state news agency ATA, was the first pledge with the force of law that all Albanians in the foreign missions could come out and receive passports without fear or prosecution. A special Central Committee meeting to deal with the recent disorder continued into its third day today. Communist leader Ramiz Alia on Friday criticized the thousands of asylum seekers and told the Central Committee that the party would not give up power as Communists had done elsewhere in Eastern Europe. ``The aims and actions of these destructive, anti-democratic and anti-Albanian forces go too far,'' Alia said in remarks carried by Albania's ATA news agency. ``We may be poor, undoubtedly we have difficulties and shortages, but the foreigner has never solved our troubles.'' The APA report on the demonstration was sketchy, but no injuries were reported. The news agency has one of the few correspondents in Albania. Meanwhile, the embassies offering shelter to asylum seekers said sanitary conditions were nearly intolerable. The number of refugees in the West Germany Embassy doubled to 2,000 overnight, and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher was consulting with his French and Italian counterparts on a resolution to the crisis, the Foreign Ministry in Bonn said today. ADN said there were 1,500 Albanians in the Italian Embassy and 500 in the French mission. Some embassies lacked sufficient food and water, and Albanian authorities were not allowing foreign governments to send supplies, Western officials said. The sometimes-violent rush to the embassies in Tirana, the Albanian capital, this week follows last year's exodus of East Germans to embassies in other East European countries shortly before the fall of their hard-line government. Under 45 years of hard-line Communist rule, travel for average Albanians has been virtually impossible. But under Alia, who took over after Enver Hoxha's death in 1985, the country pf 3.2 million people has increasingly sought ties abroad and has slowly begun to implement reforms. A package of new regulations that took effect Tuesday entitled all Albanians over age 16 to own a passport for foreign travel. The passport regulations did not check the flow of asylum-seekers. Most of the Albanians who fled to foreign embassies before Thursday entered in a rush during rioting that began Monday under fire from Albanian security forces. Diplomats said at least three people were wounded. In recent months, Alia has begun to modify Albania's Stalinist economic and political systems. He promised on Friday to continue reforms but insisted that only the Communist Party could ``realize the genuine democracy, the human rights, the country's progress and the defense of its freedom and independence.'' Alia promised a new election law, but strongly implied it would not affect the Communist Party's monopoly on power.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Damages Atomic Research Center; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A fire at an atomic energy research center early Saturday caused extensive damage but no injuries, officials said. The fire broke out in the biology laboratory of the Democritus Hellenic Atomic Energy Committee in the northern Athens suburb of Holargos, they said. The first two floors of the three-story building were gutted. Another building in the palm-groved compound houses a small nuclear reactor used for experiments, but it was about 500 yards from the fire. ``There has been no leakage of any kind, neither chemical nor nuclear,'' said Ion Siotis, director of the state-run institute. He said there was no danger to the environment and called the research reactor ``inherently safe.'' Frightened residents telephoned police when they saw the fire at the institute, but there was no evacuation, police said. The cause of the fire was under investigation. Since mid-May, Athens has been rocked by weekly terrorist attacks. Seven recent blasts have caused damage but no serious injuries. But there was no immediate indication that the fire was linked to terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Fires Force Evacuation of 2,000 Vacationers
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters on Saturday battled two major forest fires that forced the evacuation of 2,000 vacationers from campgrounds and cottages in southern France. More than 1,000 firefighters battled the blazes through the night and declared them under control after they had burned about 2,220 acres of forest and brush. The cause of the fires was not known. Seventeen people, including 15 firefighters, suffered light burns or smoke inhalation, officials said. The fires destroyed one villa and about 20 camping caravans. The fires, which broke out Friday in the Var region near Toulon, were the biggest in France so far this summer. Much of southern France has been plagued by drought for several years, and summertime forest fires have become an annual occurrence. The evacuated vacationers spent the night at community halls, gymnasiums or in the homes of local residents.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Declare Students' Military Training a Success
DOC.TEXT: ``One, two,'' the drill master barked Saturday. ``One, two,'' the women of Beijing University's freshmen class barked back. Then, arms swinging and faces stolid, they goose-stepped in unison across the parade ground of the Shijiazhuang Military Academy. This is how the first class to enter Beijing University after last year's democracy movement spent the school year _ learning to be good foot soldiers of the Communist revolution. Their training reflects the Chinese leadership's analysis of the root cause of the massive 1989 student-led protests _ weak ideological education. Its prescription for preventing further unrest is to intensify political training and discipline. While older Beijing University students passed the school year in glum cynicism after the violent quashing of the movement they helped lead, the 728 freshmen spent 10 months training at Shijiazhuang. At the army school 170 miles south of Beijing, they learned to march, salute, shoot, throw grenades and roll their bedding with military precision. They also read the works of Marx, Lenin and Chinese revolutionary leader Mao Tse-tung, and were lectured on the error of the 1989 protests, which ended in an army attack that left at least 300 people dead. Officials on Saturday showed the freshmen off to foreign journalists allowed for the first time to visit them, 10 days before the program ends. The class now faces four years of regular coursework in Beijing. ``This experiment has been successful so far,'' said Beijing University President Wu Shuqing. He said the next freshman class, which will number 1,600, will undergo the same program. This year's class was reduced drastically from the average 2,000 so the academy could accommodate it. ``It has toughened their confidence in socialism and invigorated their determination to build a strong China,'' said the academy's political commissar, Maj. Gen. Xiang Xu. A video prepared by the academy described the year's training as a powerful formative and bonding experience, much like that undergone by army recruits anywhere who have their egos broken down to be rebuilt in a military image. ``We were critical, stubborn and sometimes naughty,'' said an unidentified woman student who narrated the video. ``But gradually ... we were acclimatized and became part of the academy. ``We have never learned so much in one year,'' she said. ``What we have gained will comfort us for the rest of our life.'' Most Chinese high school and college students receive brief military training, usually a few weeks of marching drills on campus and a compulsory course in military history. That is as close as most intellectuals get to soldiers, whom they tend to look down on because most are poorly educated peasants. Political study also is mandatory at all levels of school, but in recent years many college students skipped political classes or paid little attention. At Shijiazhuang, the freshmen knew their lessons. ``Military training was a great good fortune,'' said 20-year-old Han Tao, unit leader in his 12-bunk dormitory room, explaining why he didn't mind spending five years at college instead of four. His roommate, Jiang Qinjun, said he might make friends with an upperclassman who took part in the 1989 protests, but ``we can't support their participation in the marches. If someone has an incorrect understanding, we should educate them.'' The key question is how long the academy's influence will last once the freshmen are exposed to Beijing University's far less-disciplined atmosphere. Some upperclassmen have said privately they plan to re-educate the freshmen _ in politics and a more-relaxed lifestyle. At the military academy, the freshmen have followed a strict regimen _ up at 6 a.m. and in bed at 10 p.m. after a day of exercise and study. No drinking and no romantic relationships are allowed. The students wear standard army uniforms, and the women's hair is clipped to chin length or shorter. Many jumped to attention when approached by journalists. Xiang said the students could be relied on to ``rise in defense of the state and the people'' if China faced foreign aggression. Wouldn't it be ironic, journalists asked, if some of the freshmen put their new military skills to use during a future round of student protests? ``I am confident my students will not do that,'' Xiang said. Of course, he said, there are always ``a few individual scum _ exceptional cases.''

DOC.HEAD: State Says Malathion Spraying To Resume In L.A.; Study Raises New Questions
DOC.TEXT: The state plans to resume aerial spraying of the pesticide malathion to eradicate Mediterranean fruit flies this week despite a study that says the material contains toxic heavy metals. State officials say their tests show there's no threat to public health. Helicopters will spray a 14-square-mile area of Los Angeles on Thursday, state officials said Friday. The spraying was scheduled for last week but was delayed after city attorneys presented the findings of their analysis. The Mediterranean fruit fly, also called the Medfly, can destroy hundreds of varieties of fruits and vegetables and is considered a serious threat to the state's multibillion-dollar agriculture economy. A study released by City Councilman Joel Wachs found that samples of malathion contained excessive levels of lead, nickel and chromium. Wachs said the presence of the metals violated strict state limits on toxic substances and said he would seek a temporary restraining order against the spraying Monday. Truesdail Laboratories in Tustin, Calif., conducted the independent analysis of malathion for the city of Los Angeles. But state tests of the same samples found no dangerous levels of heavy metals, state officials countered. ``The numbers our lab got are very low, in fact lower than that in plain old soil,'' said James W. Stratton, who headed the state Department of Health Services' review of the pesticide. ``The Department of Health Services has completed its latest test and like all previous tests has determined that our malathion spraying program poses no public health risk,'' said Henry J. Voss, state agriculture director. The downtown spraying was ordered after a single female Medfly was found near Dodger Stadium. Malathion was last sprayed in southern California on June 26 in Riverside and San Bernardino counties. The state also plans to release millions of sterilized male Medflies in an effort to interfere with reproduction.

DOC.HEAD: Furor over Verdict in Mother's Slaying Continues Unabated
DOC.TEXT: It's usually the pretrial publicity that lawyers worry about, but little could rival the circuslike aftermath of trial that cleared a 19-year-old woman of being an accomplice to her mother's murder. The Hartford prosecutor's office has been besieged by angry phone calls after the June 28 verdict, mostly from people who want to see Karin Aparo behind bars along with her former lover, her alleged accomplice. ``I've never, ever, ever seen anything like it,'' said an employee in the office of Hartford State's Attorney John M. Bailey who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We've never had people call this office and be so outraged.'' Ms. Aparo's aunt _ her dead mother's sister _ has launched a publicity campaign to counter what she calls the lust for blood among those who believe Ms. Aparo was responsible for the 1987 death of her 47-year-old mother, Joyce Aparo. Though cleared of being an accomplice to murder, Ms. Aparo could still face a retrial on a less serious charge of conspiracy, in which the jury could not reach a verdict. Dennis Coleman, the former boyfriend, added to the trial's bizarre conclusion when he gave a jailhouse interview to more than a dozen reporters last week to denounce the verdict. He charged jurors were taken in by Ms. Aparo's tears. Ms. Aparo, who shared a condominium with her mother in the well-to-do Hartford suburb of Glastonbury, was accused of hatching a plan when she was 15 to do away with her overbearing mother. Prosecutors charged she recruited her love-struck boyfriend to ``do the deed,'' as Coleman, now 22, referred to the alleged plot. Coleman, who confessed and is serving a 34-year sentence, testified that his passion for Ms. Aparo went ``beyond obsession.'' The defense successfully portrayed Ms. Aparo as an abused child who fantasized about her mother's death but didn't enlist Coleman to act on her fantasies. Instead, the defense said, Coleman broke in while Karin was away and strangled Mrs. Aparo as she slept, because he believed she was encouraging her daughter to sleep with another man, the 24-year-old son of Karin's violin teacher. The four-week trial fixated Connecticut residents with details about what Coleman described as the teen-age couple's ``active and liberal'' sex life, including bondage with handcuffs and pantyhose. There was also bizarre testimony that Mrs. Aparo psychologically abused her daughter, even insinuating her real father was Hartford's Roman Catholic archbishop, a family friend. Michael Aparo and Joyce Aparo were divorced when Karin was 5. The jury found Ms. Aparo innocent of being an accessory to her mother's 1987 murder, but deadlocked 7-5 in favor of acquittal on the conspiracy charge. By Thursday, the prosecutor's office had logged more than 150 calls, all but a handful from people who want to see Ms. Aparo retried on the second charge. The Journal Inquirer, a newspaper that has covered the trial closely, added its voice to the chorus urging a second trial, suggesting that everyone who believed Ms. Aparo was innocent might fit into one room. ``Lucky for Karin, it was the jury room in Hartford Superior Court,'' an editorial said. A number of callers were upset by the behavior of jury foreman Richard Meister, who winked at Ms. Aparo before the verdict was announced and was later shown on television hugging her outside the courthouse and stroking her hair. Meister said he justed wanted to spare Ms. Aparo a few seconds of agony before the verdict was announced, but some people interpreted the wink as inappropriate intimacy. One irate Aparo-watcher called Bailey's office and charged the jury, made up of four women and eight men, found Aparo ``innocent by reason of an advanced case of the hots.'' Ina Camblor, Ms. Aparo's aunt, calls the public response ``lunacy'' and complains that those who are unhappy with the verdict ``don't want justice, they want blood.'' She's asking those who share her feelings to write Bailey and Gov. William A. O'Neill to urge that the state drop the remaining charge against her niece. So far, about 30 people have done so, she said. Ms. Aparo's defense attorney, Hubert Santos, filed motions Tuesday to dismiss the remaining charge, arguing that a ``lynch-mob atmosphere'' in Connecticut makes a fair second trial impossible. Bailey says he won't decide whether to retry Ms. Aparo for a few weeks, to give himself time to step back from the emotions of the case.

DOC.HEAD: Incident Between Norwegian Fisherman, Soviet Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Norway issued a sharp protest to the Soviet Union after five Soviet soldiers and a Norwegian fisherman were involved in a border incident, the national news agency NTB reported Saturday. Norway said the Soviet soldiers entered 110 yards into Norwegian territory and chased fisherman Werner Pedersen, 45. Norwegian border official Edward Larsen said the Soviets fired at Pedersen but he was not wounded. According to the Soviets, Pedersen was fishing on the Soviet side and was chased back into Norway. The incident occurred Thursday. Norway and the Soviet Union share a border within the Arctic Circle, near the Soviet port of Murmansk. Sergei Komissarov, deputy chief of the Soviet embassy in Oslo, was called to the foreign ministry Friday to give an explanation of the incident and to hear Norway's protest.

DOC.HEAD: Bargainers Slog Away While Colleagues Make Political Hay
DOC.TEXT: The rhetoric swirled through the marble corridors of the Capitol. Republicans and Democrats alike hauled out their most colorful, cataclysmic language and vowed a battle royal should anyone dare to raise taxes. All the while, in a room across the hall from the Senate chamber, the men who actually might decide if taxes would be raised hunkered down and got to work. ``It was kind of like being in the eye of a storm,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., one of those in the quiet bargaining room. The issue that day last month was taxes after President Bush abandoned his staunch anti-tax stance. But the scene is the same every day that negotiators for the White House and Congress try to shrink the federal deficit while their colleagues play the issues for all their political worth. The negotiators' ability to seek compromise while the rest of the Capitol rings with partisan clamor reflects two overriding factors: their perspective about the task they've been assigned and the personalities of the people involved. The bargainers must look at the federal budget from exactly the opposite perspective that most members of Congress usually have. The negotiators are looking for $50 billion in new taxes and spending cuts for next year and about $500 billion over the next five years, a search that entails nothing but thorny choices. They know that if they fail, the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law will automatically cut tens of billions of dollars from most programs this fall. Most lawmakers, on the other hand, see their jobs as a constant battle to bring federal dollars back home and to protect their districts from pain. ``These people sitting around the table are staring the deficit problem in the face,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the House Budget Committee who is not one of the negotiators. ``Members of Congress are staring their constituents in the face.'' Participants in the talks are aware of this dichotomy, and say that reacting to it is a crucial part of their job. ``If we don't keep our lines of communication open to those members and make sure they have input, we may come down from the mountaintop with an agreement that nobody is prepared to vote for,'' said one of the bargainers, House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. The talks have been moving slowly for two months. But participants say the negotiating has gotten more serious since Bush's reversal on his tax position. Bargainers would like to complete a deal on a package before the beginning of the August congressional recess. Negotiations resume Tuesday. Another reason for the negotiators' single-mindedness is the personality and political instincts of many of the people in the bargaining room _ and their bosses. By historical accident, many of the key figures are moderate, consensus-building politicians who believe that compromise is what effective governing is all about. Bush, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, all fit that mold. President Ronald Reagan and former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, did not. ``There's no Jim Wright in there,'' said Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., one of the House's most conservative members. ``There isn't even a Tip O'Neill,'' the Massachusetts Democrat who as speaker was a persistent liberal champion during the Reagan years. Ideologues are few among the negotiators, with the best examples being the staunchly anti-tax Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, No. 2 House Republican Newt Gingrich of Georgia and the White House chief of staff, John Sununu. Sasser, a former chairman of his state's Democratic Party, and No. 3 House Democratic leader William H. Gray of Pennsylvania are perhaps the most partisan of the Democratic bargainers. The bargaining teams are loaded with lawmakers who have been through the budget wars before and who seem inclined to compromise to deal with the deficit. These include Panetta; Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M.; Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn.; and the White House Budget Director, Richard Darman. ``You're dealing with people,'' said Rep. Tim Penny, D-Minn., ``who really are willing to give a little bit of their own agenda to achieve the goal of deficit reduction.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp
From Fajitas to Peking Duck, First Family Has Houston Roots
DOC.TEXT: When George and Barbara Bush called Houston home, they often stopped by a no-frills Tex-Mex restaurant on the poor side of town and dined on beef fajitas and spicy green sauce. They also frequented Patterson Hardware, like other weekend home warriors, picking up tools to fix their two-story pink brick house and to putter in the garden. The Bushes visit Houston only infrequently now, and the nation's first couple calls a Houstonian hotel suite their home away from home. But local folks still have fond memories of them. ``They're beautiful people. They've always been very down-to-earth,'' says Ninfa Laurenzo, owner of the chain of Ninfa's restaurants, which specialize in Tex-Mex fare. ``I think he's going to be very busy,'' Laurenzo says when asked if he thinks the president might visit his old haunt. ``He has a pretty full agenda. But there's always a chance he'll stop by.'' In fact, the tight summit schedule doesn't include any stop at Bush's old favorites. But the president is known for his spontaneity. One time, his motorcade paid a surprise visit to Molina's, another Tex-Mex restaurant, where Bush is fond of the Tejas enchiladas. A few miles from the Houstonian is Hunan, an elegant Chinese restaurant and another Bush favorite. On New Year's the first couple even ordered some takeout from the restaurant that was delivered to their suite at the Houstonian. Manager Gigi Huang, whose father owns Hunan, said she hasn't been informed of any presidential visit. Like Mrs. Laurenzo, she says any visit will be last minute. ``George and Barbara Bush have been dining with us for about the past 12 years,'' she said. ``When they lived in Houston, we would see them about once a week or every other week.'' ``He really enjoys the people and Mrs. Bush is very friendly, and down-to-earth,'' she said. ``She's very real. We always enjoy seeing them.'' When they had some household chores to do, they went to Patterson Hardware, where owner Bill Collins remembers them as ``just plain customers like everybody else. They owned a home and they did their own upkeep. They weren't afraid to get their hands dirty.'' Despite the dilapidated surroundings, the festive Ninfa's with its colorful decor attracts an affluent but casual crowd hungry for the traditional south-of-the border fare. The area is strikingly different from the manicured lawns and sprawling brick homes of Tanglewood, an expensive neighborhood in west Houston where the Bushes lived after the he moved his oil company to the city. Then-oilman Bush moved his family from Midland, Texas to Houston some 31 years ago. He became Harris County Chairman Republican chairman in 1962, ran unsuccessfully for the U.S. Senate in 1964, won a seat in Congress in 1966. He sold his 6 percent stake in Zapata Petroleum at the time for $1.1 million. The Bushes also remain members of St. Martin's Episcopal Church, a brown brick church in Tanglewood. The Rev. Edward Stein said Bush has been to services at St. Martin's about three times since being elected president in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
Global Warming, Rain Forests To Dominate Summit Environmental Agenda
DOC.TEXT: World leaders will focus on global warming and the destruction of rain forests at the economic summit, but they are unlikely to do enough to satisfy environmentalists. President Bush and his six summit partners are expected to sign a communique outlining how they will cooperate on international environmental issues. Several environmental groups, who will be on hand with an ``environmental scorecard'' to grade the summit, are skeptical about what the leaders of the industrial nations will accomplish. ``The people of the world want more than just communiques that sound environmental; they want policies that are environmentally sound,'' said Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund. Global warming _ the so-called greenhouse effect _ has emerged as a thorny international environmental issue. Scientists say gaseous emissions trap solar heat causing a gradual warming of the earth. While several European nations already have plans to reduce or stabilize carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2000 of 2005, Bush contends more research is needed on global warming before such dramatic steps need be taken. In advance of the summit, U.S. officials said participants are expected to agree on the outlines of an international convention, to be held by 1992, to discuss global warming. But the officials, speaking on condition they remain anonymous, said they appear to have avoided what could have been a bruising battle at the summit with European nations over the reduction of gaseous emissions. The officials said the Europeans seem to be willing to back away from their previous insistence that specific reduction goals be set at the summit. Led by Germany, some countries had sought a commitment to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions or reduce them by up to 25 percent by the end of the decade. There is still wrangling, however, over when the nations should begin work on agreements to formally spell out how they will fight global warming, administration officials said. Two other contentious areas involve curtailing the destruction of tropical forests and setting up an international ``green fund'' to help developing countries protect their environments. The United States is not anxious to sign any agreements curbing the destruction of tropical forests, but one official said: ``I'm not going to throw down my body in front of a train'' if others nations devise a plan. The summiteers are expected to agree on strengthening the Tropical Forestry Action Plan that was conceived in the mid-1980s by the World Bank and other international organizations. The plan channels international investment into tropical countries to help them develop land use policies that will help save forests. The plan's critics say so far the projects selected to receive money ignore forestry protection goals. There is a general feeling among the summit partners that a tougher plan is needed, one U.S. official said. Meantime, the World Bank is viewed as the most likely vehicle to administer a ``green fund'' to provide money for developing nations' environmental projects. But the Bush administration will oppose a separately financed ``green fund,'' at the World Bank, which lends money to poor countries for various projects. One administration official said the United States would probably go along with a ``green fund'' if it were paid for out of existing resources _ a position some Europeans would oppose. Bush, in an attempt to blunt any criticism of the United States as reticent on global warming or other issues, intends to tell his summit partners at Tuesday's environmental session about recent U.S. environmental accomplishments. Officials say he will recite a series of steps that when combined, according to administration projections, would stabilize or even reduce carbon dioxide emissions by the end of the decade. They include: the Clean Air Act still pending in Congress, Bush's plan to plant 1 billion trees a year and purchase wilderness areas, and the U.S. commitment to the elimination of ozone-depleting chemicals by the year 2000. The economic summit communique is likely to include endorsement of the recent 93-nation agreement in London to wipe out chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals that deplete the earth's protective ozone layer, by the end of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: China to Summiteers: Don't Interfere in Our Affairs
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party chief says the leaders of the seven industrialized powers should avoid meddling in China's internal affairs at their annual economic summit in Houston this week. Jiang Zemin said the Group of Seven should ``confine themselves to discussion of economic and other issues among themselves,'' the official Xinhua News Agency said in a report Saturday that paraphrased his remarks. Jiang was interviewed Friday by Noboru Watanabe, president of the Japanese Mainichi Newspaper Group. During the two-hour interview, Jiang also disclosed that the party has been unable to resolve the case of former party chief Zhao Ziyang. Zhao was stripped of all his posts in June 1989 for supporting a student-led, pro-democracy movement, but he has not been brought to trial. During their three-day summit, the leaders of the seven industrialized nations are expected to discuss lifting economic sanctions they imposed on China after its brutal suppression of last year's pro-democracy movement. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan will push for ending the economic sanctions imposed on China, but his bid to unfreeze $5.2 billion worth of development loans is opposed by other summit countries. Besides Japan, the summit participants include the United States, Canada, Britain, West Germany, Italy and France. ``Some Western countries are very unwise to have imposed economic sanctions on China, as this will bring about no positive result but will, instead, arouse the Chinese people's resentment,'' Jiang said. Many Chinese citizens initially welcomed the sanctions, saying the government should be punished in some way for killing hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people to crush the democracy movement. However, there have been more appeals recently for lifting of the sanctions, which some say are beginning to hurt the Chinese people. Japan, the only Asian member of the Group of Seven, already has eased its ban on loans to China, granting two loans last week for $16 million to be used to improve drinking water. Japan acted after China lifted martial law in Beijing, released nearly 900 people arrested for joining the democracy movement, and allowed dissident Fang Lizhi to leave the U.S. Embassy and go into exile in England. ``If (the Western nations) interfere in the affairs of other countries, (I am) afraid that would not be proper,'' Jiang said. His remarks contrasted with a Foreign Ministry statement last week urging the Group of Seven to ``take timely, positive steps by seizing the opportunity to improve relations with China.'' Jiang was also asked about Zhao, who has not been seen in public for more than 13 months. ``He is still a party member and no change has been made in his treatment in terms of material well-being,'' Jiang said. Chinese leaders had previously said Zhao was living in his home and continuing to draw his regular salary. In the weeks after Zhao's purge, party leaders hinted strongly that he would face criminal charges for supporting the democracy movement, which China considers a counterrevolutionary rebellion. But Jiang's disclosure that the case was still under investigation suggests that a strong reform element still exists within the party.

DOC.HEAD: No Picnic Bringing Up Quints, Six Other Kids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: L'Esperance is pronounced Less-per-ANCE.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PON1
DOC.TEXT: Welcome to the L'Esperance home, where kids will be kids will be kids will be kids will be kids. And that's just the quintuplets, the nation's first test-tube set. Besides the 2{-year-old quints, Michele and Raymond L'Esperance have three sons from previous marriages and now are caring for three nieces at their home about 30 miles north of Detroit. That's 11 kids, if you're counting. It hasn't been easy. Food costs $350 weekly, the telephone was briefly cut off last month for non-payment, the couple worried their electricity was next and handed their limousine, the only vehicle that could carry all the kids, back to the finance company. Raymond, 29, is a Macomb County Jail guard, bringing in $26,000 yearly; his wife, 36, works at a shelter for battered women. Recent publicity over the couple's tight finances upset the family, Mrs. L'Esperance said. She says they can care for their children, but needed a foster-home license _ and the increased state aid it would bring _ to care for her sister's brood. ``Why take them from family?'' she said in a terse interview outside the family's two-story colonial home, as she held one of the two horses they keep on their 10-acre spread. Oakland County Probate Judge Barry Grant was angered at a hearing last week on the license requested five weeks ago. He ordered the state Department of Social Services to explain why it hasn't acted on the couple's request to waive rules that normally exclude a family with eight or more children from being a foster home. ``This is government bureaucracy at its worst,'' Grant said. Chuck Peller, a spokesman for the department, said the foster-home license decision was delayed because the family only recently filled out the needed paperwork. As foster parents, the L'Esperances would receive about $1,000 monthly for their nieces rather than $295 in welfare they now get. The L'Esperances told Grant that private donations will let them keep their nieces regardless of the government's decision. Outside court, they won't talk about money. ``I'd rather let sleeping dogs lie,'' Mrs. L'Esperance said. The couple apparently once expected that commercial endorsements would offset the sudden costs of Erica, Veronica, Danielle, Alexandria and Raymond Jr., born 10 weeks premature in January 1988. ``No endorsements occurred. Multiple births had become a lot more common,'' said attorney Thomas Plunkett, who was hired to negotiate contracts. Even being the country's first quints conceived through in-vitro fertilization didn't land offers, he said. There were donations _ limousine rides from the hospital, cribs, clothing and toys. And Gerber Products Co. still pays for any food, clothes or other company items the family uses. It will do the same for any quints, company spokesman James Lovejoy said. Because of its offer for multiple births, Gerber keeps records. They show U.S. multiple births _ which often result from the use of fertility drugs _ have increased 128 percent since 1983. Last year, the company had four sets of quints, 37 sets of quadruplets and 402 sets of triplets in its free product program, Lovejoy said. ``Two-and-a-half? It gets worse. This is the easy time. It gets tough,'' said Peggy Jo Kienast of Far Hills, N.J., whose 20-year-old quints are now in college. ``Of course, we had all sorts of people giving them clothes,'' she said in a telephone interview last week. ``I wish I could offer words of encouragement. You do what you can.'' The Kienast quints, the nation's second surviving set, have been featured in commercials ranging from cough drops to sneakers and on national talk shows. Amy, Abby, Sara, Ted and Gordon as children were signed with the William Morris Agency, a talent agency. But there were financial problems. An anonymous donor provided $115,000 to pay off mortgages and prevent the family's eviction in 1983, but William Kienast killed himself the next year, after a business venture failed. The L'Esperances married in 1986, using $4,000 for in-vitro fertilization rather than holding a fancy wedding. In that procedure, a woman receives fertility drugs to stimulate ovum production. The eggs are surgically removed, mixed with sperm and reimplanted. Last year, Mrs. L'Esperance's nieces, ages 6, 10 and 13, moved in. Their parents, who are unemployed, told the court last week that they would receive alcoholism treatment, said Grant's clerk, John Chamberlain.

DOC.HEAD: Youngster Trapped In Camp Cooler Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old boy has died after being found inside a camp cooler fitted with a latch that locked automatically when the lid dropped. Jacob Green was found unconscious late Friday inside the old metal cooler stored underneath a work bench in the family garage, police said. The boy was declared dead on arrival at Valley Memorial Hospital. Jacob's mother, Kary Green, had called police during the afternoon to report the boy missing. About 150 people assisted by police dogs and a helicopter searched the surrounding area.

DOC.HEAD: Organizations Reach Out to Flood Victims _ Gradually
DOC.TEXT: Some victims of last month's deadly flash flooding in villages off the west bank of the Ohio River are struggling to cope with the bureaucracy and confusion of relief organizations. Most of the attention has been focused on the Wegee and Pipe Creek communities south of this Belmont County village. On the night of June 14, at least 26 people died when flash floods rampaged down Wegee and Pipe creeks. But residents of several smaller villages _ Dillonvale, Adena, Newtown, Rayland, Mount Pleasant and Connorville _ just to the north in Jefferson County, suffered as well when Short Creek and its tributaries went out of control the same night. Dillonvale Mayor Leon Bailey said his valley suffered far more damage than Wegee and Pipe Creek, although with no deaths, and fears rural Jefferson County is being shortchanged because of the attention given Shadyside. The American Red Cross said it has issued $180,600 in vouchers to Belmont County residents and $207,400 in vouchers in Jefferson County. Red Cross spokesman Doug Skroback said Jefferson County reported almost twice as many houses damaged as did Belmont County. The Federal Emergency Management Agency, the Small Business Administration and the Ohio Emergency Management Agency are making grants and loans as specific problems and costs are identified and applications approved. FEMA reports 3,059 registrations for help from the Ohio counties that were declared a federal disaster area as a result of recent severe weather. It has disbursed $1.1 million in disaster housing aid statewide and paid $600,000 in individual and family grants. Marion S. Szypkowski, 76, and his wife, Nancy, were evacuated from their Dillonvale home by rowboat with little more than their nightclothes. Water from Short Creek caved in the front wall of their basement, making their home unsafe. They moved in with a friend, but so far no one else has offered any help. ``I filled out an application for FEMA a week ago,'' said Mrs. Szypkowski. ``I turned it in at the church like they said. And I've called that 800 number several times that they gave me, but they haven't got it yet.'' ``I can't afford a loan,'' Szypkowski said, adding that his only income is from Social Security. He has estimates of $800 to $1,100 labor costs to rebuild his basement wall, plus the cost of materials. FEMA officials held a town meeting last week to explain to Dillonvale residents how the agency makes cash grants for relocation or immediate repairs to dwellings. Rob Svoboda walked out of the meeting after heatedly asking why some people are charged 8 percent for loans and others get grants or lower interest loans. ``I applied to FEMA and I made out well, but those on fixed income are getting stuck,'' said Svoboda, 26, an electronics technician at a steel mill. Village leaders in Shadyside, Dillonvale and Adena have organized to accept and distribute money and materials donated to help flood victims. The Rev. David Baker, president of the Shadyside Fellowship of Churches, says more than $300,000 has been donated to the Shadyside Relief Fund Inc. Baker hopes fund managers can start distributing the money by mid-July. He expects the fund will aid about 115 households hardest hit by the flood. ``Getting the organization set up and running properly is taking longer than expected,'' said Baker, pastor of United Methodist Church. Attorneys, accountants and other specialists are donating their expertise to be certain the distribution is properly handled. Adena, a dozen miles up Short Creek, has a little more than $5,000 in its local relief fund, but Chet Masloski, whose wife is coordinating the fund, said the town has 153 damaged houses. ``Any of those we can help won't get much,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New President's Honeymoon Ends in Strikes, Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, ``The shock ...' to delete extraneous words.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: On inauguration day, President Fernando Collor de Mello promised a better life in 100 days, but recession looms, strikes abound and grumbling has begun about his anti-inflation shock therapy. Their flamboyant new president stunned the 150 million Brazilians in March by freezing bank accounts as part of his drastic program of bringing down annual inflation of nearly 5,000 percent. He was immensely popular at first, but that is changing. ``The shock was cruel, monstrous and unnecessary,'' Paul Singer, an economics professor and planning secretary for the city of Sao Paulo, said in an interview. Collor, 40, is Brazil's first freely elected president since 1961. He took office March 15, promising a ``new Brazil'' and reform of the bloated, corrupt bureaucracy. He said the first task was to reduce inflation drastically and eliminate a $31 billion budget deficit. On March 16, he announced an 18-month freeze on 80 percent of the money in savings accounts and financial markets; price controls; a new currency, and an end to numbered bank accounts. Police made showcase arrests of bank and supermarket managers accused of not complying with the plan. Cheering crowds gathered as the executives were taken away. They were released later. To set an example of austerity, Collor abolished half the 24 government ministries and ordered the sale of 42 government-owned mansions and 10,177 apartments formerly used by top officials rent-free. Thousands of official cars were auctioned in lots with signs proclaiming, ``The End of Perks.'' Dozens of the 188 state-owned companies were put up for sale. Import taxes and trade barriers for thousands of imports were lowered or dropped. Automatic cost-of-living pay raises were eliminated. Collor said 360,000 of the government's 1.4 million employees would be fired by June 18. Official inflation fell from 84 percent a month in March to 3.3 percent in April, and the government said it soon would be zero. Brazilians were elated. ``The Collor government can be accused of almost anything in these first 100 days except indolence, sluggishness or monotony,'' the newspaper O Estado de Sao Paulo said in an editorial called ``A Hundred Days that Shook the Country.'' Collor's style appealed to the poor majority of Brazilians, who provided his main election support. He personally checked prices at a supermarket and opened a $100 bank account to encourage saving. He tested an army tank, flew an F-5E jet fighter, toured a remote Amazon Indian reservation in combat fatigues, spent weekends riding jet-skis and motorcycles, jogging, bicycling and kayaking. A poll in May gave him a 74 percent approval rating. His economic plan soon ran into trouble, however. The freeze on accounts slowed the economy to a crawl. Sales plummeted, companies began laying off workers and the country slid toward recession. In Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city and its financial center, 47,447 workers were fired in May alone, the highest one-month total since 1981. Unemployment in Sao Paulo rose to a record 12 percent. ``It was a case of killing the cow to get rid of a tick,'' said Leonel Brizola, a former governor of Rio de Janeiro state, who ran against Collor for president. Unions said inflation was much higher than the government admitted. Their figures ranged up to 44 percent a month. Collor's announced plans for layoffs led to strikes at government companies that run the docks, railroads and oil industry. Inflation refused to go away. Prices rose 8 percent in May and nearly 10 percent in June, according to official figures. ``It was an error for the government to talk about zero inflation,'' said Sen. Roberto Campos, a former planning minister. ``Inflation of 7 or 8 a month is great progress, but the goal became too ambitious.'' Opponents were nettled by Collor's habit of enacting key reforms by decree, then sending them to the congress for approval. Many likened that to the decree-laws of the military governmnts of 1964-1985. When legislators prepared to vote on the economic plan, Collor told them not to ``meddle'' with it. ``He tries to act like a prince of the Brazilian aristocracy,'' Brizola said. ``It's been 100 days of impositions.'' The target of 360,000 layoffs by June 18 was not reached. Some critics even questioned the government's claim that 90,000 were fired, retired or sent home with pay. One estimate put the figure at 41,000. ``There's more smoke than fire,'' David Fleischer, a professor of political science at the University of Brasilia, said in an interview. ``The popularity of the plan is sustained by imagery and the use of television. When the government gets in trouble, Collor goes on TV. He's very skillful.'' A Supreme Court ruling that some reforms were unconstitutional did not help the government's credibility. New bank deposits by small savers declined and businessmen found ways to ``unblock'' their frozen assets. Fleischer said: ``The plan destroyed the faith of people in the savings account system, which took 15 or 20 years to build up. The government was naive.'' A poll taken in June said only 36 percent of those rated Collor's performance good or excellent job, 43 percent said average and 19 percent classed it as bad or terrible. His press spokesman, Claudio Humberto Rosa e Silva, said the president was misunderstood. ``Everything that was promised is being done,'' he said in an interview. The layoffs of govenment employees were not intended to be finished by June 18, he said, but will reach or exceed 360,000 by 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl a Major Force for Change in New European Order
DOC.TEXT: When Helmut Kohl received an honorary doctorate at Harvard University a month ago, the West German chancellor was lauded as a ``German Hercules'' for his role at the head of one of the world's richest nations. The comparison may be apt. Kohl is a strong position to become the first chancellor of a united Germany. And as military might recedes as a measure of world power, Germany is certain to expand its international influence as an economic giant. Kohl has not been shy about wielding his influence. He has bluntly called the 1990s ``the decade of the Europeans.'' He has become a champion of economic aid for the Soviet Union, a message he will take to the economic summit in Houston after raising the issue at the just-ended NATO meeting in London. In Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia, the chancellor notes approvingly, there is already talk of applying for membership in the European Community following the collapse of communism.
