For Kohl, the greater the steps toward full European integration, the greater the chances for stability that will extend the continent's longest period without war in centuries. The conservative Christian Democrat, 60, has been in office nearly eight years. Still, he retains many of the folksy touches that appeal to the solid conservative majority at home, and a similar bloc of voters in East Germany. During the NATO summit, Kohl sat and regaled reporters for more than an hour late one night, mixing a keen sense of history, humor and frequent stinging barbs at the politicians he has known over the years. Diplomatically, Kohl strictly banned any repeat of those comments, but his closing news conference on Friday brought out several quips. Asked the reason for his close ties with U.S. President George Bush, the chancellor said: ``Well, right off, I could say it's because we are such good politicians. That's the first answer that comes to mind. ``Of course, that's not the answer I'll give, but I naturally like it when people say and write that,'' the chancellor added with a smile. Instead, Kohl said of his relationship with Bush, ``the chemistry is right, as you say in the United States.'' When asked about an apparent rift in East Berlin over NATO membership for a united Germany, Kohl said such the dispute was ``a specialty of the East German government.'' He quickly added that occasional disagreements are hallmarks of democratically elected governments. A man of huge dimensions _ 6-feet-3-inches tall and 235 pounds _ Kohl towers over most of his European counterparts. Two of those leaders, 64-year-old British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand often bicker predictably at European summits. That has left Kohl in charge of much of the EC's direction, guiding the community's integration on a parallel track with German unification. The twofold strategy is important for a country still acutely aware of international wariness of a powerful Germany after the catastrophic experiences of two World Wars. ``We have learned the lessons of history,'' Kohl told the Bush and the 14 other NATO leaders, echoing a statement he has made time and again. Kohl once infuriated Jews by referring to the ``mercy of those born later,'' which Jewish leaders interpreted as an attempt on the part of younger Germans to wash their hands of the Holocaust. Despite that and other occasional gaffes, the chancellor has held on to power during some of the most tumultuous years in his country's nearly 41-year history. They include the massive resistance to the installation of medium-range nuclear missiles in West Germany in 1983 and the East German unrest that broke down the Berlin Wall last November. Earlier this year, there were predictions that Kohl could get hit by an anti-unification backlash among West Germans tired of seeing their country awash in handout-seeking East Germans. However, two recent public opinion polls indicate that Kohl has regained the momentum in his bid to become the first chancellor of a united Germany after joint elections expected in December. A poll conducted by the respected INFAS institute and released Friday said Kohl enjoys a 56 percent approval rating, compared with 37 percent for his Social Democratic challenger Oskar Lafontaine. The SPD and others have criticized Kohl, saying he has been pushing forward with unification too quickly at the risk of creating instability in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhotos NY44,NAR3
DOC.TEXT: Move over Princess Di, meet Princess Kiko. The 23-year-old Kiko, who eight days ago was a graduate student living in an apartment with her middle-class family, is now a national celebrity after her marriage to Prince Akishino and is greeted by large, adoring crowds. Even her choice of hats is subject to the close scrutiny of television's gossipy morning variety shows. But as she and Prince Akishino, 24, Emperor Akihito's youngest son, concluded their three-day ``honeymoon'' with a visit to an imperial tomb in this western Japan city Saturday, the newest addition to Japan's royal family couldn't have looked more composed. Walking slowly a few steps behind her new husband, Princess Kiko nodded to a crowd of several hundred guests at the tomb of the legendary Emperor Jimmu, a semigod who according to myth was Japan's first monarch. ``She's so much more beautiful in person,'' gushed one middle-aged woman in the crowd. ``I like the way she smiles.'' ``Kiko-sama,'' as she is respectfully known, is only the second commoner to marry into Japan's imperial family. Akishino's mother, Empress Michiko, was the first when she wed then crown-prince Akihito in 1959. The empress, however, was raised in a decidedly upper-class home, while her new daughter-in-law is the daughter of a college professor of far more humble means.

A federal judge has awarded $3,000 to a filmmaker who sued talk show host Geraldo Rivera for broadcasting part of his documentary on mass murderer Charles Manson without permission. Robert Hendrickson claimed victory even though U.S. District Judge Ronald S.W. Lew awarded him far less than the $310,000 he was seeking from Rivera. ``It's all exclusive film. That's what the court has ruled,'' said Hendrickson, 45. ``I won the copyright issue against the best copyright lawyers in Beverly Hills. I think that's something.'' Hendrickson, who acted as his own attorney in the case, filed his suit in May 1989, a month after Rivera aired excerpts from the 1972 documentary ``Manson'' in a televised special called ``Murder _ Live From Death Row.'' Rivera's attorneys argued that Rivera's production company, Investigative News Group of New York, had paid a video distributor $3,000 to use the excerpts. Hendrickson said the deal was made without his permission. Tribune Entertainment and KTLA-TV, which aired the Rivera special, also were named in the suit. Lew ruled Thursday that Investigative News Group did infringe on a copyright on the documentary. But he dismissed most of Hendrickson's damages claim, including $42,000 the filmmaker said Rivera should have paid him to use the footage. The judge ordered Investigative News Group, Tribune Entertainment and KTLA-TV to jointly pay the award. Actress Sharon Tate and four others were murdered at her Benedict Canyon home on Aug. 9, 1969. Wealthy market owner Leno LaBianca and his wife, Rosemary, were killed at their Los Feliz home the next night. Convicted with Manson were Susan Atkins, Patricia Krenwrinkle, Leslie Van Houten and Charles ``Tex'' Watson. All are serving life sentences.

Actor Gene Hackman was in good condition Saturday, recovering from an operation doctors hope will help the screen toughguy avert a heart attack. Hackman, 60, was getting diet and exercise instruction at St. Vincent Hospital & Medical Center, said Mary Jane Bonesteele, a nursing supervisor. ``We don't know anything about the time for his release,'' she said. ``He is finishing up with what we need to teach him as as a patient.'' Hackman checked into St. Vincent on Tuesday after experiencing chest pain while vacationing on the Oregon coast. His cardiologist, Dr. Herbert Semler, said Thursday that doctors who examined Hackman detected a narrowing of an artery leading to his heart. A balloon catheter was used to dilate the blood vessel. Semler said that without the procedure, the artery would have closed, possibly bringing on a heart attack. Hackman's most acclaimed role came in 1971's ``The French Connection,'' in which he played a rough-and-tumble narcotics cop. His other screen credits include ``Bonnie and Clyde,'' ``Mississippi Burning,'' ``Hawaii,'' and ``Hoosiers.''

Wright-Patterson Air Force Base is naming its new hotel for military personnel in honor of Bob Hope, who traveled the world to entertain U.S. troops. The new 266-room hotel for military personnel and the accompanying meeting center cost $14 million and will be known as the Hope Hotel and Conference Center, said base officials. The comedian will attend a grand opening in November. Proceeds from the event will be donated to the Bob Hope House for troubled boys in Cincinnati, said William Boden, president of Valley Group Inc. of Franklin, the developer and operator.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Firms Stand Against Academic Tracking, Says Minorities Suffer
With AM-Teachers
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest teachers' union issued a report Saturday calling for a gradual end to the controversial practice of grouping students according to past performance. Robert Chase, vice president of the National Education Association, said it would be ``foolhardy and unrealistic to expect that tracking can be eliminated overnight,'' but said the union will offer strategies to better arrange class groupings. Academic tracking has become a hot educational issue as U.S. students continue to test poorly in basic subjects. Opponents complain that minorities are too often placed into low ability and special education classes. Proponents argue tracking is needed so high achievers can move rapidly. ``We must give students an education that will open up their options for the future, not close them,'' said Chase at a news conference at the annual convention of the union representing 2 million educators. Chase pointed to a Carnegie study issued two years ago that found 63 percent of all U.S. teachers considered tracking useful. The report, based on a commissioned Johns Hopkins University study, said students can benefit from tracking, but only under very specific conditions. Sue Hovey of Moscow, Idaho, who worked on the NEA report, said students should be grouped only for specific skills, like reading, rather than by general ability. Also, group assignments should be frequently reassessed. The report said most schools track students by segregating them all or most of the day according to general achievement or behavior, rather than by abilities in specific subjects. The study found that groupings in elementary and secondary schools are hard to break out of and are likely to create racially identifiable classes. Leon Horne, an NEA executive committee member who chaired the task force handling the report, said the study also found that minorities are significantly underrepresented in classes that are prerequisites to higher level courses. Without these courses, Horne said, many students are prevented from pursuing careers in advanced fields like science and engineering. Two years ago, the union proposed and debated a resolution calling for an end to academic tracking ``based on socioeconomic status, race, or sex.'' Saturday's report came from a task force appointed then to study the issue further.

DOC.HEAD: Little New in First Week of Party Congress
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: This one was supposed to be different. According to traditionalists and reformers alike, the 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party would be a bitter struggle for the future of the party. But halfway through their agenda, the nearly 4,700 delegates meeting in the Kremlin have been able to do little more than erect a facade of unity on a foundation of words rather than action. The most powerful assembly of the most powerful organization in Soviet society appears dispirited and near ideological bankruptcy. In the words of Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev: ``The party of the revolutionary idea has turned into the party of power.'' Soviet society, taking advantage of the changes under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, will pursue reforms no matter what course the party chooses, Yakovlev said. But the new ideas, however modest, are being rejected by the congress. Rank-and-file delegates are confused. New faces are certain to appear in the party leadership, but it is far from certain that personnel changes will be enough to bolster the party's sagging authority. The congress sharpened the rhetoric Soviets first heard at a party conference two years ago and at the governmental Congress of People's Deputies last year. Then, it was breath of freedom to watch the verbal duels between reformer Boris N. Yeltsin and more traditional Yegor K. Ligachev. Live broadcasts were curtailed because people were watching instead of working. In March, looking ahead to the congress, Ligachev said it would mean ``the fixing of boundaries, and the cleansing from the party of all those who are destroying it, who are engaging in a factional, opposition struggle and who are participating in anti-socialist movements.'' On Friday, Yeltsin warned that the party could not simply discard those Ligachev considered troublemakers. He said they would demand their share of the party's property, or that the property be nationalized. Just has he has for years, Gorbachev continued to steer a middle course, successfully avoiding the open split that had been promised by radical delegates. ``Consolidation'' was one of the congress buzzwords, but it seemed to apply to preserving the party rather than forging new policies. Delegates seemed subdued rather than energized by months of buildup. The lack of anything new drove some party members to despair. On the opening day of the congress, Rafael Belyalov, a composer and party official in the city of Kazan, announced he was quitting the party. ``I did not wait until the end of the 28th congress, since I was sure that nothing is changing,'' the Postfactum news service quoted him as saying. Delegate Yuri Boldyrev from Leningrad urged nationalization of the party's property on the first day of the congress and said 57 percent of the active party constituents in his district agreed with him. But he said 40 percent of the district party members did not bother to take part in elections to the congress, apparently out of apathy. ``For me, nothing has been explained, nothing is happening, just as we predicted,'' said Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, a leader of the Democratic Platform reform group. Group members decided to quit the party and ask for a share of its assets after the congress. The modest new ideas presented at the congress have been shot down. Gorbachev lost a bid to rename the party leader's post chairman rather than general secretary, and add two deputies. He said it was more likely that the congress would add one deputy. He also wanted to expand the Politburo in a move that would tend to diffuse power, but he said it was likely the body would remain as it is. Several Politburo members said they would step down, and party leaders said 80 percent to 90 percent of the members of the policy-making Central Committee might be changed. It was unclear whether that would make much of a difference. Gorbachev already has replaced most of the Politburo and retired many old members of the Central Committee with little effect. Gorbachev's position as party leader was secure. Despite a barrage of criticism, neither traditionalists nor reformers could find another acceptable candidate. When delegates showed a burst of independence, unthinkable in previous congresses, by declaring that they would give each Politburo member a separate evaluation, Gorbachev quickly cowed them with a warning they would split the party. For those watching from the outside, it hardly mattered. ``I don't think there's any point to struggle with the Soviet Communist Party,'' said reform-minded historian Yuri Afanasiev, who quit the party two months before the congress. ``It is leaving the stage, it is simply falling apart.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Mark J. Porubcansky has reported from Moscow for The Associated Press since February 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands March to Show Concern Over Natal Violence
LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of African National Congress supporters marched in cities across the country Saturday to protest black factional fighting in Natal Province that has claimed thousands of lives. Official permission was granted for about 20 peace marches planned by the ANC, and its allies, the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the United Democratic Front, to mark the end of a week of national protest against the violence. Petitions protesting the violence were presented to authorities at various police stations throughout the country. About 80,000 protesters staged a peaceful march through the streets in the Eastern Cape province city of Port Elizabeth. The high turnout was attributed to the region being a traditional ANC stronghold. There were no incidents despite a heavy police and army presence and the sealing off of some roads with barbed wire. The march was led by recently returned ANC exile Thobile Mhlahlo and former police lieutenant Gregory Rockman, who last year exposed incidents of police brutality. A memorandum delivered to police read: ``This is not black-on-black violence, it's also neither faction fighting, but apartheid war.'' President F.W. de Klerk was urged to stop the violence. About 12,000 people marched through the Natal capital, Durban. Protesters carried huge cloth banners that read ``Stop the apartheid war, defend Natal.'' They presented a memo to the local police commander, Col. Kobus Le Roux. The Johannesburg march was led by ANC internal leader Walter Sisulu, who was released in October after 25 years in jail. He led about 2,000 protesters to police headquarters, John Voster Square. Sisulu and three senior activists presented a nine-page memo to police protesting the ``terrible carnage taking place in Natal.'' ``The government has to do something positive to bring peace in that region,'' Sisulu said after delivering the petition. About 500 protesters marched through Pretoria to deliver their petition to police. Authorities refused applications for marches in five towns which have been the scenes of racial conflict and white right-wing activity in recent months. About 800 security force members were deployed in Vereeniging, one of the five towns, to ensure a planned march did not go ahead. The independent South African Press Association said police stopped 5,000 black youths from marching. They then gathered at the town's black township, Sebokeng, where several blacks were killed by police during a protest March 26. Sebokeng's police commander, Col. Paddy Mazibuko, said that since the march was thwarted, the crowd had gathered in the township to attend the funeral of two local activists. March organizers confirmed this. The weeklong protest was aimed at drawing attention to four years of conflict in Natal between supporters of the ANC and Inkatha, a conservative Zulu party. More than 4,000 people have died in the violence, which the ANC claims is caused by Inkatha. De Klerk lifted most of the country's state of emergency last month but kept it in Natal because of the violence in the region. The ANC claims the government has not taken firm steps to stop the fighting. It has demanded that the government end the state of emergency in Natal and disband the police force of the Kwazulu homeland. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi heads the homeland. Organizers of the protest said there could be no political settlement in South Africa until the Natal violence ended. They said the Natal crisis was an obstacle to a negotiated settlement to end white-minority rule. The ANC and the government have begun a process of talks which they hope will lead to a peaceful end to apartheid. Both sides have identified various obstacles which they want removed before negotiations can begin.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Saturday's Communist Party Congress Session
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Highlights of Saturday's session of the 28th Communist Party congress, its sixth day:
GORBACHEV WINS: Mikhail S. Gorbachev turned defeat into victory by persuading the Communist congress to drop plans to evaluate each member of the ruling Politburo, warning that such action would ``bury the party.''
GERMANY DISPUTE: Yegor K. Ligachev, the conservative member of the ruling Politburo, took issue with Gorbachev's qualified support of German reunification. Ligachev told the congress it was ``not a unification, but an annexation or rather the swallowing of the German Democratic Republic by the Federal Republic.''
KEY QUOTE: ``If you want to bury the party, to split the party, then continue on this way. But think hard.'' _ Soviet party general secretary and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Bush sending cable to Gorbachev, comment on Japanese aid to China, etc.; minor editing thruout; No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush cabled Mikhail S. Gorbachev to reaffirm support for the Soviet leader's economic reforms while flying to the Texas summit he's hosting for his counterparts from major industrialized nations. Chief presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president sent Gorbachev the message from Air Force One, his executive jet, as he was flying to Houston from the London NATO summit Friday night. Fitzwater revealed the communication from Bush to Gorbachev while briefing reporters today on meeting Bush held here with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Bush expressed his support for Gorbachev's program of perestroika, or economic restructuring, the spokesman said. Fitzwater said that Bush gave his personal reflections with ``a little personal emphasis'' on just-concluded NATO meeting, the spokesman said. Bush ``was very pleased with the reaction of the Soviet Union to the summit,'' Fitzwater said, citing the favorable comments issued by Soviet officials. Gorbachev had said Friday he was anxious to accept NATO's offer to address a future meeting of the Western alliance. Bush had told reporters on the flight that he received a recent communique from Gorbachev. While he refused to disclose its contents, there was speculation that it was similar to a recent letter Gorbachev wrote to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher appealing for Western aid. On the question of possible Western aid to the Soviets, Fitzwater said it would undoubtedly be raised at the Houston economic summit and said ``there are a lot of things they can consider short of direct aid.'' Fitzwater also said the United states was ``willing to discuss the matter'' of bilateral aid by other countries to China, which is still under economic sanctions from many countries. Bush started his bilateral session with Kaifu by indicating the United States wouldl acquiesce to Japan's proceeding with its plan to give economic assistance to Beijing. Japan ``is a sovereign nation,'' the president told reporters. ``They can make up their own minds on a lot of questions.'' Bush had been asked whether he would try to dissuade Kaifu from proceeding with the loan package. ``They work very cooperatively with the United States, but sometimes they have interests that predominate,'' Bush added. While the United States still retains sanctions against Bejing, in the wake of last year's bloody crackdown on Chinese pro-democracy demonstrations, the Bush administration has chipped away at those sanctions and said that the United States does not want to isolate such a geopolitically important country. Bush and Kaifu got a jump on the seven-nation economic summit, which officially begins Monday, with their meeting scheduled today. Most of the other participants were due early too, for some Texas-style social preliminaries. The leaders of the world's richest democracies faced a full, likely contentious agenda, ranging from whether to provide the Soviet Union with cash and other direct assistance to how to resolve a family trade fight involving billions of dollars in agricultural subsidies. Other countries participating in the 16th annual economic summit were Britain, West Germany, France, Italy and Canada. This was the first time in seven years that one of these gatherings has been in the United States. And Houston, picked by the president because it is his adopted hometown, was going all out to prove that the city has made a dramatic turnaround since hitting bottom during the oil price bust in the last decade. Before the formal summit talks began, Bush was playing host to the other summit leaders at a combination rodeo, barbecue and performance by the Grand Ole Opry on Sunday. Flags of the summit countries were flying everywhere, and the city gleamed in the wake of an effort by thousands of volunteers to clear it of trash and debris. The actual meetings between the leaders will be held at Rice University, a 4,000-student private university located about five miles from downtown. All of the talks were expected to involve a search for consensus on the differences separating the countries. And some of those threatened to fray, rather than bind, their connections. On Soviet aid, the United States, Britain and Japan found themselves aligned in opposition to a proposal being pushed by West Germany and France to provide a $15 billion assistance package to bail out President Mikhail Gorbachev's floundering economic reforms. Bush on Friday continued to insist that such aid would inappropriate at a time when the Soviet Union is still spending huge sums on its military and also providing $5 billion annually to support Cuba. However, the president seemed to open the door to a possible compromise with Western allies when he suggested that it might be possible for the United States to extend trade credits. Such credits could take the form of loan guarantees provided to the Soviets on their purchases of American farm and industrial products.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Scientology President, Five Colleagues
DOC.TEXT: The president of the French branch of the Church of Scientology and five colleagues have been arrested in a probe of alleged fraud and illegal practice of medicine, court and church officials said Saturday. The president, Daniele Gounord, was arrested Friday in Paris along with the church's treasurer and the head of a church foundation. They were placed under court supervision, but not jailed Three officials of the Scientologists' branch in Lyon were arrested there in the past 10 days _ the local president, treasurer and secretary. They have been charged with complicity in fraud and illegal practice of medicine. All six are to appear in court in Lyon, where an order for Friday's arrests was issued by Judge Georges Fenech. The arrests stem from a police investigation into the suicide of Patrick Vick, a Church of Scientology member in Lyon who jumped out of a 12th floor window in 1988. Investigators found medicine in his house allegedly provided to him by the church in violation of a regulation requiring a doctor's prescription. Vick's widow filed a complaint in court against the Scientologists' branch in Lyon. The church issued a communique denouncing the arrests as ``a serious attack on individual freedom of religion.'' The Church of Scientology was founded in the United States in 1950 by L. Ron Hubbard.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Forces Congress To Drop Personal Evaluations of Leadership
LaserPhotos MOSB1,3
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev turned defeat into victory Saturday by persuading the Communist Party congress to drop plans to evaluate each member of the ruling Politburo, warning that such action would ``bury the party.'' Delegates to the 28th Communist Party congress have criticized many of the 12 Politburo members and wanted to give the thumbs-up or thumbs-down on each of them. The delegates voted 2,557 to 1,393 for such a chance before their afternoon break. But Gorbachev later warned: ``If you want to bury the party, to split the party, then continue on this way. ... Think, think hard, think hard.'' The ire of the 59-year-old Soviet leader, who has skillfully consolidated his position at the congress, prompted the delegates to vote 2,495 to 1,515 to reverse themselves. In his argument, Gorbachev read a note from the northern Russian city of Arkhangelsk that said: ``There is no need to evaluate each Politburo member. The Politburo, according to the rules, is an organ of the leadership, and the leadership is collective.'' Instead, the congress agreed to evaluate the policy-making Central Committee, and within it the Politburo, as a whole. Politburo member Vladimir Ivashko later read a draft of a resolution on the Central Committee that is to be voted on this week. The draft praises the committee for major changes enacted since the last congress in 1986, the move toward democracy and free elections. But it blames the party for failing to carry out party policy, leading to social and economic difficulties. The congress broke a decades-old tradition last week by requiring each Politburo member to account for his work and answer written questions from the nearly 4,700 delegates. Inna Dementyeva, a Moscow delegate, said the vote on personal evaluations would have gone too far. ``Our Russian thirst for blood is showing,'' she said. ``It's stupid and ugly and inhuman.'' Delegates interviewed in the lobby of the Kremlin Palace of Congresses said that allowing the mostly conservative congress to vote on individual leaders also might have embarrassed Gorbachev and his allies and benefited such conservative critics as Yegor K. Ligachev. Some also said they had expected at least half the Politburo to get the thumbs down, particulary ideology chief Vadim A. Medvedev and international policy head Alexander N. Yakovlev. ``Collective responsibility is no responsibility,'' said a Byelorussian delegate who identified himself only as Alexander. ``And there should be a full renewal of the leadership.'' Several Politburo members responded to the written questions they received from delegates, and Medvedev said he had been accused of letting party ideology crumble and discipline among Soviet journalists break down. He responded that the party had shed ``fossilized thinking and dogmatism'' and that journalists should be governed by law and their ``party and civic conscience.'' Yakovlev, one of Gorbachev's closest advisers, said he had been accused of ``connivance to separatism in the Baltic republics'' and the ``loss of Eastern Europe.'' He responded that he had spoken out against separatism and nationalism and that the people of Eastern Europe were the ones who rejected the Communist Party. Ligachev also took the floor and said he opposed reunification of the German states because the West was ``absorbing'' the East. He criticized the concept of private property and plans to convert the Soviet Union to a market-oriented economy, saying proponents of ``free market relations'' should become the first Soviet unemployed. Ligachev also opposed political reforms that would diminish the party's role in society and government. ``I don't see another force other than the party which could bring progress to our country,'' he said. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze defended Soviet policy on German unity, saying Moscow's interests could best be served through international negotiations rather than attempts to block the merger. He received only mild applause, but drew strong support when he reminded the congress that the republic of Georgia, under his leadership, started to fight corruption in the party. Although Gorbachev preserved the facade of collective leadership by defeating individual evaluations of Politburo members, major personnel changes are expected at the congress. Yakovlev, Medvedev and Lev Zaikov have indicated they plan to step down from the Politburo. The congress will choose a new Central Committee, which in turn will select a new Politburo. Delegates said there did not appear to be any serious challenge to Gorbachev as party leader. Nominations for the post were delayed until later this week. In a draft of party rules, the congress will elect a new party leader _ the general secretary _ and create a new post of deputy general secretary, also to be elected by the congress. Among the candidates mentioned for the No. 2. post are Ligachev, Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin and Pravda editor Ivan Frolov. But Gorbachev adviser Georgy Shakhnazarov said he thought the deputy might turn out to be ``someone completely new.''

DOC.HEAD: Officers May Use Stun Guns _ Only After They Get Stunned First
DOC.TEXT: Police here have been authorized to use stun guns as an alternative to nightsticks, but there's a catch _ any officer who wants to use the device has to get zapped first to know what it's like. Forty Pompano Beach officers have signed up for a six-hour course on the use of the electric weapon. The officers are responsible for buying their own stun guns, which cost an average of about $150. Getting zapped is the last part of the course, and on Friday officers of all sizes yelled and crumpled helplessly to the ground when they were touched with the stun gun and the electricity hit their muscles. ``It's really a convincer,'' officer Bill Butler said after he experienced it. ``It's like something really biting into you.'' ``It hurt. A lot,'' said officer Kathy Konieczka. After being zapped, officers said they would not hesitate to use the guns as a last resort in place of physical restraint. ``A nightstick will injure someone,'' Butler said. Officer Ken Holland, who is in charge of the training program, said the stun guns are completely safe. But there are precautions _ an officer must stop the current as soon as the subject falls and they are forbidden to place the device on a person's head, face or groin. Twelve officers carried the guns during a pilot program that began in February. The weapons have been used 12 times with no complaints and no injuries, Holland said. ``All were violent or potentially violent situations,'' he said. ``We had no allegations of abuse or use of excessive force.'' The weapon's shock is supposed to do nothing more than render a person defenseless for a few seconds. ``It has nothing to do with your brain or heart,'' police spokeswoman Sandra King said. ``Your muscles will go limp for a couple of seconds.'' And use of the guns will be strictly monitored. ``Any time the officer takes it out or shows it to someone, they have to fill out a long form explaining why they pulled it out,'' King said.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Soar in East German After Economic Merger
DOC.TEXT: Katrin Matthes got out of bed before dawn Saturday, left her home in southern East Germany and drove three hours to West Berlin to find food she can afford. She was among hundreds of East Germans crowding into a West Berlin store to buy meat, butter and milk that, paradoxically, are suddenly cheaper in the wealthy West than the struggling East. The 17-year-old factory worker from Dresden paid 102 German marks ($60) for groceries she said will feed her and three Dresden families in the next few days. ``It would have cost 300 marks ($180) in East Germany,'' she said. The stunning rise in prices just days after the German states merged their economies has created a scandal in both countries and sent droves of East Germans into Western grocery stores. After the two nations unified their economies on July 1, East German stores began filling their shelves with Western products. But because East German stores face substantially less competition, their prices are not only three or four times higher than before economic unification, but also often higher than the same goods sold in West Germany. German media reported a flood of East Germans heading West on Saturday, the first shopping weekend since the economic merger and the first Saturday of the month, when West German stores by law are allowed to stay open longer. At one store, a pound of salt was selling for 21 cents, while in East Berlin it was selling for 72 cents. Anna Neitman, a 22-year-old student from the southern city of Leipzig, said the East German stores that were once state-owned and sold food at government-set prices are now taking advantage of their captive markets. ``We have to buy what they sell, unless we come here,'' she said as she stood outside a West Berlin supermarket. Andries Kurjo, a West Berlin economist and a leading expert on the East German agricultural economy, said consumers will have to rebel to bring prices down. ``The consumers won't accept these high prices,'' he said. ``They have to pay for bread that is four times higher. They can get the same things in some West German shops much cheaper.'' Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany criticized the price increases last week, and government officials asked consumers to begin reporting instances of price gouging. The East German Parliament on Friday passed a law intended to break up the two large grocery chains that hold a virtual monopoly in the East German food business. The law would allow communities to sell the formerly state-owned stores in their towns. Kurjo, however, said he expected few takers. ``Who has the money to buy them? Who has the knowledge to run such a store?'' he said. The two grocery store chains, HO and Konsum, made deals with eight large West German companies in March to sell Western products, which now dominate the marketplace. Konsum, in a statement on Saturday, denied that it was a monopoly and sharply criticized the law passed Friday by Parliament. The chain's board said the property rights of the company are ``protected and inviolable,'' according to a statement carried by the East German news agency ADN. It said that 1,500 stores were being run by private proprietors and that there were applications to run 600 others. The statement claimed the chain is not a monopoly because it is not owned by its wholesalers. Kurjo, however, said the chains were monopolies because they dominate their markets with little competition, and the products they sell are strictly regulated by their agreements with the West German firms. ``HO and Konsum were glad to get into these agreements, but it has led to this monopoly,'' Kurjo said. ``Now they are under the control of the Western food chains. There is no real competition. The lack of competition is so bad that (East German) producers are not allowed to offer their products in these shops,'' he said. Many stores in smaller towns sell East German agricultural products, but many of those prices also are higher because the government has eliminated the state subsidies of the old Communist regime, he said. Kurjo said consumers can bring prices down only by refusing to buy outrageously priced products buying in West German stores that sell cheaper goods, because they face more competition. He said East German farmers must be willing to find new ways to market, distribute and sell their products if they want to survive. Retailers learned quickly, however, and their grasp of the laws of supply and demand drew some sour comment from German media. ``With bravura the former staunchly socialist Konsum and HO have sprung into the market economy _ as capitalistic as the greediest capitalist,'' East Germany's ADN news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors of Bankrupt Khashoggi Company Receive Payments
DOC.TEXT: Creditors of Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi's bankrupt Utah holding company were sent $10 million in payments the same day he was acquitted on obstruction of justice and fraud charges. The 53-year-old arms merchant was cleared by a New York jury Monday of charges that he helped former Philippines president Ferdinand Marcos and his wife, Imelda, conceal the purchase of four New York City buildings. Coincidentally, that same day, partial payments were mailed to creditors of Triad America. The Salt Lake City-based Triad America, the holding company for Khashoggi's U.S. interests, declared bankruptcy in 1987 after a string of failed real estate ventures. Khashoggi's trial meant nothing to the Triad America case, said estate attorney Danny Kelly. Two years ago, Khashoggi paid the Triad estate $32 million, which forms the bulk of money now being disbursed to creditors. The $10 million constitutes the largest single distribution from the estate, bringing the total amount paid to unsecured creditors to $18 million, said Triad trustee R. Todd Neilson. That amounts to about 43 percent of their total recognied claims, he said. ``I hope we can ultimately distribute another $15 million,'' he said. He plans a fourth distribution this year and a final one sometime in 1991. The estate's largest creditor is Sheraton, which has received about $7 million so far. Last week's payment included $3,147,000 to the hotel company, while the smallest creditor, Mount Olympus Water, received $3.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her summit-hopping colleagues will have no trouble telling the difference between London, site of the NATO summit, and this Texas city, host to the seven-nation economic summit. For one thing, there is the weather. Temperatures were in the 60s on Friday in London as the world leaders ended their NATO session. Here in Houston, it was a scorching 93 degrees with humidity readings above 80 percent. Houston is taking the weather in stride _ and hoping its guests do the same _ emphasizing its world-class air conditioning and a summit slogan of ``Houston's Hot.''

President Bush and his summit partners may spend a fair amount of time haggling over a sticky economic problem that most Americans have never heard about. It's a fight over farm subsidies as part of an effort to reform the global trading system. The talks, known as the Uruguay Round for the Latin American country where they were launched in 1986, have been going on mostly unnoticed for the past four years in Geneva. Hoping to raise the profile of the issue, the staff of U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hill is handing out buttons at the summit sporting the slogan, ``The Uruguay Round is not a dance.''

Rice University, where the VIPs will hold their discussions, has the look of an unfinished house whose owners already are moving in. Furniture is being moved. Light fixtures are being moved. Even trees and bushes are being moved. Classrooms have been turned into meeting rooms. Meeting rooms have been turned into holding rooms. All told, more than 500 chairs, cabinets and desks are being moved in or out. Even Rice University president George Rupp has been moved. Rupp will conduct university business elsewhere while another president, George Bush, works out of his office.

Rice University is hardly a household name, although it likes to call itself the Harvard of the Southwest. Its 4,000 students are among the best and brightest, with SAT scores for last year's freshman class averaging 1,350. The national average is 904. One-third of the freshmen were National Merit Scholars. Bush taught there in 1978. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's grandfather, the start of the roman numerals, was the school's first chairman of the board. The school's namesake, William Marsh Rice, made his fortune in cotton, cattle and lumber in the mid 1800s. He was killed in 1900 by his butler, who plotted to steal his boss's millions.

DOC.HEAD: Paratroopers Young and Old Mark 50th Anniversary of Airborne Military
LaserPhotos WX6,7
DOC.TEXT: Former paratrooper Chuck Beckman watched and remembered Saturday as a group of modern Army Airborne troops marched past him in combat dress, their backs straight, jaws out and berets cocked just so. ``We were tough,'' he said, ``but I don't know if we were that tough.'' Beckman, from Southern Pines, N.C., was one of several thousand former paratroopers who gathered in Washington over the weekend and held a parade Saturday to mark the 50th anniversary of America's Airborne military. Former paratroopers from World War II, like Beckman, as well as those from the Korean and Vietnam wars, and the periods in between and since, also took part. Some marched, and others chose to watch. Alex Madsen, 69, of Solvang, Calif., watched from a park bench with a friend from the old days, H.G. Bennett, 73, of Sun City, Ariz. ``You know, we've spent a lot of money just to come to a bull session,'' Madsen joked. Both were members of the Army's 507th Airborne Regiment, headquarters company, and both parachuted into Normandy on D-Day, 1944. They also parachuted at the Rhine crossing in 1945, and Madsen wore his paratrooper's wings bearing a pair of stars, one for each combat drop. There were veterans from all periods, but the World War II crowd, the original paratroopers, were most in evidence. They marched together with what was left of their old regiments. The brass also was there. Retired Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who was U.S. military commander in Vietnam from 1964 to 1968, received the marching men's salutes at a reviewing stand. Only 13 gray-haired men marched with the original 501st parachute batallion, which was formed in 1940. In other groups, some rode in wheelchairs or walked on crutches, and some wore what they could of their old uniforms. ``It's air conditioned,'' one marching veteran said to the crowd, tugging at the jacket that no longer met in the middle. The all-black 555th Battalion also marched. Charles McCloed, 63, of Philadelphia, became a member of the 555th in 1946, volunteering after a year in Germany with Army intelligence. He served until 1950, and recalled when the order to integrate came in 1948. The battalion was made a part of another unit. ``It was just on paper,'' he said. ``We stayed in the same place, at Fort Bragg. We just changed the patches on our shoulders.'' Paratroopers have always been a close-knit group, in a way that transcended boundaries of race or rank, he said. ``I don't care whether it's a general or a private, today we all just say, `How you doing, trooper,''' McCloed said. There were old Jeeps, trucks, even a restored staff car _ all privately owned. Tony Lambros, a Vietnam veteran from Fallston, Md., drove a Jeep nearly as storied as the old veterans he carried in it. The Jeep landed in the invasion in 1944 and carries documentation of its stops through Belgium and France, where it stayed until it was sold as salvage more than 15 years after the war, he said. The world they fought in has been changing rapidly, these veterans of the war in Europe acknowledged. But there were few regrets or sounds of alarm about the unification of Germany or the easing of East-West tensions. ``I welcome it,'' Madsen said. ``Let's hope that the day will come when it's no longer necessary to have such a vast amount of money tied up in the military.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Louisiana Senate Sustains Abortion Bill Veto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs. SUBS 2nd graf to explain why another vote possible. Minor editing. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana Senate today sustained Gov. Buddy Roemer's veto of the nation's toughest state abortion bill, coming three votes shy of the number needed to override. However, the issue was not dead and a second vote on the issue is likely to be taken Sunday. Under legislative rules, the fact that a simple majority was in favor meant that backers can try for another vote on the issue Sunday. The vote in favor of the override was 23-16. It takes 26 votes in the Senate to override a veto. The House voted to override Friday. The senators debated as chanting abortion foes, and a few pro-choice demonstrators, gathered in the balcony, in the Capitol rotunda and outside. At one point, state troopers carried a screaming woman from the balcony after she interrupted the speech of an abortion opponent. Had the override succeeded, it would have been the first time this century that Louisiana legislators had overruled a governor's veto. Roemer vetoed the measure Friday because it made no exceptions for victims of rape or incest. ``It is not just the people outside this building or in this state watching what we do,'' said override backer Sen. Mike Cross, a co-author of the bill. ``People all over the country, all over the world, are watching us. I hope you will say no, that you will not continue to do away with future generations.'' Sen. Sydney Nelson, who wanted the veto upheld, said that a bill that did not include exceptions for rape and incest is inhumane. ``I'm not for abortion on demand or for gender selection or birth control,'' he said. ``But for me as a man, to say to the women of this state, that we don't care how you get pregnant, you must carry to term, I just can't do that.'' The deadline for action is midnight Monday, when the Legislature is due to adjourn. Late Friday, the state House voted 73-31 to reject Roemer's veto. It was the first time this century that even one chamber of the Legislature had overridden a veto in Louisiana. But the House, unlike the Senate, had passed the bill by more than a two-thirds majority in the first place. As the Senate resumed work this morning, most of the 34-story Capitol building was sealed off to the public in order to better control demonstrators, said Senate President Samuel Nunez. Demonstrators were being allowed in the rotunda area and the upstairs gallery of the Senate. In the rotunda, some 500 opponents chanted ``Override! Override!'' and waved anti-abortion bumper stickers. Scattered among the crowd were small groups of abortion rights demonstrators. One of the few abortion rights demonstrators in the gallery during today's debate interrupted Sen. John Saunders' anti-abortion speech when he told the Senate that none of the hundreds of demonstrators outside the chamber was carrying signs in support of the veto. ``Yes there is! Yes there is!'' the woman screamed. Two state troopers carried her out of the balcony as she yelled ``Let me go!'' A few seconds of stunned silence followed before Saunders said ``Well, there is one.'' The woman, identified as Karen Anklam, 26, of New Orleans, was not arrested. She was ordered out of the Capitol and allowed to listen to the Senate debate on loudspeakers set up outside. Before the Senate quit for the day Friday night, Sen. Allen Bares, a supporter of the bill, acknowledged to his colleagues that abortion foes do not have the necessary two-thirds majority of the Senate. Proponents of an override were already at work, buying full-page ads in New Orleans, Baton Rouge and Lake Charles newspapers featuring a message from Mother Teresa of Calcutta, who sent a telegram to Roemer in favor of the bill. The bill passed two weeks ago would allow abortion only to save the life of the mother. Doctors could get up to 10 years in prison for performing an abortion. The bill was written to challenge the 1973 Supreme Court decision Roe vs. Wade that recognized the right to an abortion. The governor's forces wanted an immediate vote to sustain his veto, but Bares got his colleagues to adjourn. ``This issue is too important to handle this late at night without a hearing,'' Bares said. Robin Rothrock, leader of an abortion rights coalition, had said earlier she was confident the Senate would sustain Roemer's veto. ``In the Senate we believe that we still have the 15'' legislators who voted against the measure when it passed the Senate with 24 votes, she said. In his veto message, Roemer responded to charges he changed his position on abortion since he was a member of Congress, running for governor, in 1987. ``As a member of Congress, I consistently voted to curb abortion on demand and to protect the life of a fetus,'' Roemer wrote. ``I initially voted for the exception to save the life of a mother, but over the years of struggling with this issue I became acutely aware of the need to except those instances where conception occurred because of rape or incest. ``Women cannot and should not be forced to bear the consequences of these traumatic, illegal acts.'' The bill's author, Rep. Woody Jenkins, cited statistics in a House debate that out of more than 15,000 abortions performed in Louisiana in 1987, only one was doe to end a pregnancy that resulted from rape. ``He's for killing 15,000 unborn children a year in Louisiana just to make sure that one child conceived in rape is also killed,'' said Jenkins.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa and Mazowiecki Set Aside Their Differences
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki declared a political truce after a private, five-hour meeting Saturday, pledging to cooperate ``for the good of our country.'' A brief statement issued by the PAP news agency after the meeting indicated that the leaders, at odds over the pace of political and economic changes, decided that their disagreements must not lead to social unrest. Roman Catholic Archbishop Bronislaw Dabrowski was host of the unannounced meeting, which was held at an undisclosed location near Warsaw. It took place as thousands of farmers who feel their business is being hurt by Poland's economic policies demonstrated outside the main government building in the capital, Warsaw. ``Differences in political views that appear in our country, as well as different interests of various social groups, should not destabilize the situation in Poland,'' the leaders' communique said. ``The condition of deep reconstruction in our country is the preservation of social peace and law-abidingness.'' According to the communique, Walesa and Mazowiecki promised ``cooperation for the good of our country and further progress in democratization.'' The statement didn't say what subjects Mazowiecki and Walesa discussed, or whether they made any deals for the other's cooperation. Mazowiecki has recently drawn sharp criticism from farmers and the faction of Solidarity loyal to Walesa. In a bid to deflect the attacks, the prime minister ousted three of the four Communists in his Cabinet on Friday and caved in to Walesa's demands for elections earlier than next year. He also appealed to the public, and especially farmers, for patience and self-restraint. But the moves did not satisfy the farmers demanding guaranteed minimum prices for their produce and threatening a nationwide road blockade on Monday. About 3,000 farmers marched through central Warsaw and then took up a vigil outside the Council of Ministers building for most of the day Saturday. Inside, negotiations between farmers unions and senior government officials lasted into the evening before breaking up with no results. At least one leader of the protesters said they might try to bring down the government. ``It is not our goal but it may be necessary,'' said Bogdan Wlodarczyk, vice-chairman of the farmers' strike committee. ``If I know that in a few weeks I will not have any money to buy something for my child, then nothing will restrain me,'' he said. Walesa for months has been urging Mazowiecki to accelerate political and economic changes, particularly by removing Communists from positions of authority in government and the economy, beginning widescale privatization of state industries, and holding early elections to parliament and the presidency. Walesa himself is considered the most likely candidate for president to remove President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the longtime Communist leader who has held the office for one year. Walesa's criticisms have been accompanied by warnings to the Solidarity-led government he helped install that it was losing touch with the common people who are Solidarity's base. One example is the farmers, who claim they cannot survive under the government's shock economic program. The program has resulted in falling consumer demand, leading to a glut of produce and low prices for farmers. A national farm protest committee said all major highways in Poland will be blocked for one hour on Monday, from noon to 1 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Letter-Writers Pour Out Hearts For Bridgeport
DOC.TEXT: A ``60 Minutes'' show on Bridgeport painted such a bleak picture of the city that hundreds of people wrote to offer the new mayor some free, if not always sound, advice on how to turn things around. Some even sent cash after the piece on Bridgeport aired this spring, including a man who wrote a check for $2.50 in appreciation of a General Electric toaster manufactured in Bridgeport many years ago. ``It's still working fine,'' the man wrote. Two people from California, both impressed with Mayor Mary Moran's portrayal as the anti-politician, sent $100 each. Total donations topped $300. ``We were appalled and heartsick at the monumental task you face,'' one family wrote. CBS depicted Bridgeport, a city of 142,000 about 55 miles northeast of New York City, as a once-major industrial center on the ``verge of economic collapse.'' Viewers were shown shot after shot of blighted housing and abandoned factories in a city described as ``depressed, discouraged and broke.'' The letter-writers ranged from a Wall Street investment firm to inventors with sometimes dubious claims about the moneymaking potential of their products and consultants seeking to be added to the city's payroll. A chain letter that reached City Hall _ and never left _ promised good fortune if the letter was sent on. It warned of disastrous consequences if it was broken. A man from Ohio was not pleased when he saw the mayor cooking breakfast for her husband on ``60 Minutes.'' He told her she could not be both a housewife and mayor of a city with so many problems. ``Let your husband learn how to fix his own breakfast, a simple task millions of males already do for themselves,'' he said, before going on to suggest she should report for work at 5 a.m. Hong Kong millionaires seeking to leave the British crown colony before it comes under Chinese rule would answer to the city's economic difficulties, several writers said. ``If these men were offered a haven in Bridgeport, by buying up some old, rundown sewing or other factories, and turning them into modern enterprises, you couldn't fail!'' a woman writing from New York enthused. In response to the show, a $1,000 prize is being offered to the person who can produce the best videotape showing Bridgeport's good side. The contest, which ends July 30, is called ``6 Minutes: Bridgeport Reels Back.'' The top entries are to be shown next month at a downtown movie house that the owner has dubbed the ``ghost theater'' because of the ``60 Minutes'' claim that Bridgeport has no cinema. The cinema once featured X-rated films but is now a family theater. Frank Borres, director of communications for the Bank Mart and one of the contest organizers, said the ``60 Minutes'' segment on Bridgeport was ``pretty scary because it was real.'' Moran, a Republican who upset two-term incumbent Thomas Bucci last November in her first bid for major public office, said she's grateful for the letters. ``I think it's wonderful that people would sit down and say, `This is what you could do,' whether it was good advice or not,'' she said. Moran says the ``60 Minutes'' piece fell short in not showing the good things Bridgeport has to offer _ ``the reasons why I would want to become mayor.'' She cited the city's zoo, museums, parks, symphony, ballet, P.T. Barnum Museum, and proximity to New York as some of Bridgeport's many attributes. The Legislature imposed state review of Bridgeport's finances in 1988 as a condition for guaranteeing a $35 million loan needed to cover accumulated deficits. With no real growth in the tax base for five years now, the city had to raise taxes 5 percent this year and eliminate about 170 jobs through layoffs and attrition. Homicides, meanwhile, have been occurring at a record-shattering pace. There have already been 38 homicides here this year, compared with 42 for all of last year, a police official said. Moran says the best thing to come out of the controversy is that ``it made Bridgeporters talk positively about their city for the first time in a long time.'' ``People said, `How dare they attack us.' It was like when someone attacks your child,'' Moran said.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Killed During Prison Escape
DOC.TEXT: Israeli army guards on Saturday shot and killed an 18-year-old Palestinian who tried to escape a prison in the occupied West Bank five days before his trial was to begin, the military said. An army official said guards at the Ofer prison near the town of Ramallah noticed the inmate running toward the prison fence shortly after midnight. Following established guidelines, the guards shouted a warning, fired warning shots in the air, then shot at the prisoner's legs, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The prisoner ignored the warnings and climbed over the fence. Outside Ofer, the procedure was repeated and when the inmate refused to stop, the guards opened fire at his body and wounded him, the official said. The military said the prisoner, Tzabari Mansour Abdallah Abed Rabbo, died after arriving at Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital. The case is under investigation by prison commanders and military police, the army said. Abed Rabbo, of El-Jib village near Ramallah, was arrested in January on suspicion of participating in protests and stone-throwings, and his trial was scheduled to start July 12 at the Ramallah military court, the army said. He was the 723rd Palestinian to die of Israeli gunfire in the nearly 31-month-old, anti-Israeli uprising in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. An additional 232 Palestinians have been killed by other Arabs on suspicion of assisting Israeli authorities during the rebellion, and 45 Israelis also have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine: NASA Paid Bonuses to Builders of Troubled Space Telescope
DOC.TEXT: The government overpaid as much as $1 million in bonuses to two Hubble Space Telescope contractors for their cost control efforts on the device, which has been a major headache for NASA, a magazine reported Saturday. Congressional Quarterly reported in its July 7 edition that the overpayments occurred at the same time costs for the expensive telescope were rising dramatically. The original cost estimate for the Hubble was $678 million, but it's final price tag was more than $1.5 billion. The magazine said information about the bonus was contained in a July 1989 audit report by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's office of inspector general. The material was obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. The Hubble was launched April 24 and NASA announced June 27 that its two main mirrors would not focus properly. A manufacturing error was suspected. Congressional Quarterly said the inspector general's report accused NASA management of ``not properly considering all ... cost overruns'' in figuring cost control bonuses paid to Hubble's two principal contractors, Lockheed Corp. and Perkin-Elmer Corp., now Hughes-Danbury Optical Systems Inc., which built the telescope's mirrors. Lockheed received $14.4 million in bonuses and Hughes-Danbury was paid $6 million in bonuses through April 30, 1987, the report said. If NASA had fully considered the cost overruns, the bonuses may have been reduced by as much as $1 million, it said. Attempts Saturday to reach either of the contractors and NASA were unsuccessful. But Congressional Quarterly quoted project managers at Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., as disagreeing with the audit conclusions while promising to implement many of the report's recommendations. A Lockheed official also took issue with the report. ``If this thing followed its normal course they probably didn't pay us enough,'' H. Hollister Cantus, vice president of Lockheed's space group, told the magazine. ``If you're going to do business with NASA, don't expect to make a large profit. NASA is a damned tough taskmaster,'' he added. The magazine said Hughes-Danbury declined to comment. A NASA lawyer told Congressional Quarterly that the agency did ``withhold a significant amount of award fees'' that could have gone to the contractors. Francis P. LaRocca Jr. said NASA declined to give the companies about $6.6 million of an available $27 million.

DOC.HEAD: Doe's Government Announces Cease-Fire, But Fighting Continues
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based on a pool report filed by reporters in Monrovia. Associated Press correspondent Michelle Faul was among them.

President Samuel Doe's shattered government announced a cease-fire on a makeshift radio station but sporadic fighting between soldiers and rebels continued Saturday on the fringe of the besieged capital. A radio broadcast Friday night said a cease-fire had been reached and it appealed to shops to open and government workers to return to their offices. Nearly everything remained closed, however. Monrovians have been beset by looting government troops, rebels bent on tribal reprisals and severe food shortages, and deprived of running water and electricity for more than a week. Many said they wanted to believe the cease-fire announcement but did not. There was no comment from the rebels, but they have said previously that Doe must leave the country before they will accept a truce. Led by former aide Charles Taylor, the rebels invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 to overthrow Doe's government, which they accuse of corruption, tribalism and brutal suppression of opposition. Liberian and diplomatic sources said the cease-fire was announced from a makeshift radio station at Doe's fortified beachside executive mansion. The radio went off the air after the announcement. Few people heard the broadcast because the main state radio station on the eastern outskirts of Monrovia stopped broadcasting Tuesday as rebels advanced on the city. The rebels have been unable to make good on their claim that they could take Monrovia within 12 hours. Meanwhile, Doe has been deserted by most of his Cabinet ministers, the two chief army commanders and dozens of other top officials. Government troops appear demoralized and disorganized, and many have abandoned their posts. Some soldiers fired U.S.-supplied M16 rifles into the air in celebration when they heard the report of the cease-fire. Rebels attacked the city's port on Friday and the capital echoed with the rumble of heavy artillery and the crackle of gunfire. The fighting Saturday was sporadic and occurred on the city's western and eastern outskirts. Relief workers said about 40 people, civilians and soldiers, were treated for injuries at an emergency field hospital set up by the European agency Doctors Without Borders at a Roman Catholic hospital. Hundreds of people, fearing tribal reprisals by soldiers or rebels, have been trying to get into already overcrowded refugee compounds, some of which are protected by Swiss personnel of the International Committee of the Red Cross. Refugees said many people jumped a wall Friday night to join them at the American Community School. Western diplomats said about 17,000 people had gathered for safety at the compound of the U.S. government's ship-tracking transmitter. The transmitter, one of only seven of its kind in the world, fell behind rebel lines on Monday. Managers at the Omega station, just outside Monrovia, have refused rebel demands that they hand over Krahns and Mandingos among the refugees. Doe is of the Krahn tribe and Mandingos are accused of supporting him and growing wealthy during his corrupt 10-year administration. Creeks and wells in the city were crowded with people bathing or collecting water for cooking and drinking. Health officials fear outbreaks of cholera and other water-borne diseases. A supermarket, the first to open this week, let in shoppers two or three at a time after they had lined up for more than an hour. A U.S. Embassy spokesman denied a report Friday that the embassy had supplied water to Doe's Israeli-built mansion. He said a water tanker escorted by Marines had gone Friday to a creek near the mansion to collect water for the embassy compound. The United States has offered to help Doe leave Liberia. He reportedly has offered to resign on condition his safety and that of his minority Krahn tribe is guaranteed. After the rebels invaded, Doe's forces killed hundreds of civilian members of the Gio and Mano tribes, seen as the main support base for the rebels. The rebels then sought revenge by killing members of the Krahn tribe and the Mandingo people, who have supported Doe. Rebel leader Taylor is a strong supporter of capitalism and he has widespread support in Liberia. But the United States and other governments have questioned his commitment to democracy and free elections.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Senate Sustains Veto of Tough Abortion Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; LEADS with 9 grasf of reaction, color; Picks up 4th graf of a0553, Since the...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BT1
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana's Senate voted Saturday against overriding Gov. Buddy Roemer's veto of what would have been the nation's toughest state abortion law. The vote was 23 in favor of the override _ three short of the two-thirds majority needed _ and 16 against. When the bill to make abortion a criminal offense passed the Senate last month, it got 24 votes. The failure of the override attempt was not final, however. Under legislative rules, the bill's backers get a second chance Sunday because a simple majority was on their side. For the override to pass, the Senate must act before the Legislature adjourns at midnight Monday. ``We'll pray that we can change some minds,'' said Rep. Woody Jenkins, author of the measure. The House had approved the override measure late Friday. Terri Bartlett, director of Planned Parenthood of Louisiana, told her jubilant supporters that the battle wasn't over. ``Tomorrow's vote is as critical and as important as the one that happened today,'' she said. After the vote, viewers quietly filed out of the gallery. In the rotunda, pro-choice backers waved purple flowers and ribbons and shouted: ``We won!'' Abortion opponents countered with the chant of ``We will win. We will win.'' If the Senate voted to follow the House's lead and override, it would be the first time this century that a legislature overrode a Louisiana governor's veto. Since the legislative session began in April, Roemer had said he opposed abortion on demand but would veto a measure that made no exceptions for rape or incest. He did just that Friday. Supporters argued that exceptions would allow women to get abortions by falsely claiming to have been raped. The bill provides a maximum 10-year prison term and $100,000 fine for people who perform abortions but no penalty for the woman obtaining the abortion. Sen. Mike Cross, the Senate sponsor of the bill, warned that failing to override the veto would mean legislators would have to put up with continued intense, emotional lobbying going into next year's elections. ``You think it's tough this year?'' said Cross. ``It's not going to wait until next year at this time. It's going to be a long, long, long year if we don't vote to override the governor's veto.'' Supporters of the bill said it would provide the U.S. Supreme Court with a vehicle to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, which made most abortions legal, because by outlawing abortion outright the Louisiana bill forces the issue in the simplest possible terms. Sen. Sydney Nelson argued that no woman should be forced to continue a pregnancy if it results from rape or incest, or if there is evidence the child will have birth defects. He also raised the spectre of women resorting to dangerous back-alley abortions. ``Are we as 39 men to make a decision that so materially affects the ladies of our state?'' asked Nelson. ``I say the governor's veto is reasonable. The governor's veto should be sustained.'' State police limited access to the Capitol to avoid noisy demonstrations that might distract from debate. Demonstrators in and out of the Capitol were for the most part orderly, but at one point during the debate state troopers carried a screaming woman from the balcony of the Senate chamber. She interrupted Sen. John Saunders' anti-abortion speech when he told the Senate that among the hundreds of demonstrators outside the chamber there were no signs supporting the veto. ``Yes there is! Yes there is!'' the woman screamed. Two state troopers carried her out of the balcony as she yelled ``Let me go!'' The woman, identified as Karen Anklam, 26, of New Orleans, was not arrested. She was ordered out of the Capitol and allowed to listen to the Senate debate on loudspeakers. ``They're not going to stop abortion,'' she said later. ``They're just going to make it so that everything's going to go completely haywire.'' State police allowed almost 200 demonstrators _ almost all of them backers of the abortion bill _ to enter the Senate chamber. They allowed 500 others into the rotunda, the wide, high-ceilinged, marble-floored hall that separates the Senate and House chambers. Several hundred more gathered on the steps of the Capitol. Inside and out, the demonstrators sang hymns or broke into chants of ``Override! Override!'' The chants echoing through the rotunda could be heard in the Senate chamber. Some demonstrators knelt in silent prayer for several minutes at a time. Abortion rights advocates but were greatly outnumbered. One group of about 100 chanted ``Sustain the veto!''

DOC.HEAD: Television Station Sues Government for Crash Documents
DOC.TEXT: A television station has filed suit against the federal government, trying to obtain documents about a 1985 plane crash in Canada that killed 248 U.S. soldiers. KDKA filed the suit June 29 against the Justice Department, the FBI, the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology and the National Transportation Safety Board after making unsuccessful requests for documents, said KDKA Managing Editor Jim Esser. The Pittsburgh station had made 70 requests under provisions of the federal Freedom of Information Act, he said. ``We got very little,'' Esser said. ``We got some information, but nothing we considered significant.'' Since January, KDKA has been investigating the December 1985 crash of an Arrow Air charter jet at Gander, Newfoundland, which also killed eight crew members, Esser said. The plane was bringing the soldiers back from a mission in the Middle East. Fourteen of the victims were from western Pennsylvania. Esser would not say specifically what the station hoped to find in the materials it requested in the lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Washington, D.C. ```Documents related to the crash' is all we're prepared to say,'' Esser said. He said KDKA has not received a response to the suit. A South Carolina congressman also has investigated the crash and issued a statement Friday about KDKA's lawsuit. ``Although the official Canadian and United States statement is that ice on the wings caused the crash, there has been substantial evidence to suggest that the plane was downed by an incendiary device,'' Rep. Robin Tallon said. He lauded the television statement for pursuing the inquiry. Tallon became involved in the Gander investigation on behalf of constituents who lost relatives in the crash, said spokeswoman Jean Margaret Smith. Tallon's work has been ``along the same lines'' as KDKA's research, Ms. Smith said. Tallon has sought both congressional hearings on the crash and in an inquiry by the executive branch, Ms. Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Pop Musician Cazuza Dies of AIDS at 32
DOC.TEXT: Cazuza, a top pop singer and composer in Brazil who emerged as a national symbol in the fight against AIDS, died in his sleep Saturday after a four-year struggle with the disease. He was 32. Cazuza, who suffered from respiratory problems his last three days, died in his parents' home in the beachfront neighborhood of Ipanema. ``Fortunately, he died without pain, sleeping,'' his father, Joao Araujo, director of one of the largest record companies in Brazil, said on television. TV film footage showed hundreds of weeping fans crowding into Sao Joao Batista Church in Rio's Botofogo neighborhood where a wake was held. Cazuza began as a singer in small clubs. His career took off in 1984 when he joined the hard-rock band ``Barao Vermelho,'' Portuguese for Red Baron. The band produced three hit records before Cazuza left to record on his own. Mixing Bossa Nova music with 1960s British and American rock, he composed and recorded ``Cazuza,'' his first solo album in 1985, a record known for its biting, sarcastic tone and lyrics. Cazuza's music underwent a transformation after doctors confirmed he had AIDS in 1986. His songs gained a poetic quality, the lyrics focusing on his struggle to live. He produced four more records, including the live album ``Time Doesn't Stop'' and the hit ``Ideology,'' for which he received the Sharp Prize for Best Brazilian Pop-Rock Artist in 1988. His solo records combined have sold 1.1 million copies in Brazil. In April, he returned from Boston where he underwent AIDS treatment, pledging to return to the stage. However, he was bedridden for much of the time until his death. His funeral was held Saturday at the Sao Joao Batista cemetery. He was survived by his parents.

DOC.HEAD: Manned Air Force Drone Crashes, Pilot Survives
DOC.TEXT: A civilian pilot testing an Air Force target drone was forced to eject from the plane before it crashed in the Gulf of Mexico about 12 miles offshore. The crew of a charter fishing boat pulled the pilot from the water Friday and he was in good condition at a base hospital, Air Force officials said. Willard F. Inscoe, 53, of Durham, N.C., is an operations manager for Westar Corp. of Albuquerque, N.M., which is testing the QF-106 drones under contract with the Air Force. The drones, converted F-106 Delta Dart fighters, are based at Tyndall but come under the supervision of the Munitions Systems Division at nearby Eglin Air Force Base. Susan Brown, a spokeswoman for the munitions division, said the cause of the crash was under investigation. The drones, which can fly at twice the speedy of sound, normally are unmanned and flown by remote control, but pilots occasionally test them. The planes are used for target practice and missile development and testing.

DOC.HEAD: Serbia Continues Clampdown in Ethnic Albanian Province
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's republic of Serbia tightened its grip on the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo province Saturday by disbanding the official trade union organization there. The Yugoslav news agency Tanjug said the council of trade unions of Serbia acted because the Kosovo council ``failed to perform its role.'' In Pristina, capital of Kosovo, the Albanian-language daily Rilindija carried a sharp protest of Serbia's ``occupation of Kosovo.'' Ethnic Albanians dominate the province and their leaders issued a declaration of independence last Monday. Serbia responded Thursday by dissolving Kosovo's local governing bodies, replacing the managers and leading journalists of local news organizations and taking Albanian-language radio and television programs off the air. On Friday, Serbian authorities detained several ethnic Albanians and large numbers of uniformed police took up positions throughout Pristina, Kosovo's capital, about 150 miles south of Belgrade. Heightened security also was reported from other towns in the province. Kosovo was calm on Saturday, Tanjug reported. A group of provincial deputies demanded an emergency session of the federal legislature to discuss the situation. Serbian authorities dissolved the local assembly and government after 114 assembly members announced plans to secede from Serbia, the largest of the country's six republics. Both bodies were dominated by ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the province's 1.9 million people. Serbia's moves have virtually abolished the autonomy granted the southern province under the 1974 Yugoslav constitution. At least 60 ethnic Albanians have died in clashes with security forces since Serbia began limiting autonomy in March 1989. Serbians consider Kosovo the cradle of their medieval kingdom. They allege ethnic Albanians, in seeking independence, have pressured Serbians to move out. Ethnic Albanians, who want free elections and a multiparty system, deny Serbia's charges.
