They say Serbia's Communist leader, Slobodan Milosevic, has used such accusations to gain popular support for his drive to control Kosovo. The trouble in Kosovo is one of many besetting Yugoslavia's fragile Communist-run federal governement. The northern republic of Slovenia on Monday adopted a declaration of regional autonomy and said it would take control of Yugoslav military on its soil. Yugoslavia's federal leadership on Friday demanded that the republic rescind its proclamation, but Slovenia's presidency on Saturday refused, the Tanjug news agency reported. The authority of the federal leadership has effectively been crippled since non-Communist, center-right parties won elections this year in Slovenia and Croatia, another liberal republic. It was the first free balloting in Yugoslavia in 50 years. Slovenia and Croatia are demanding a looser national confederation. The current federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces already allows each region to run its own government and Communist party structure. The decentralized system of government was devised by the late national leader Josip Broz Tito. It was intended to prevent one republic from gaining sway over the others, but ethnic and economic differences are again threatening the country's unity.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain In Midwest, Cool In Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Up to 10 inches of rain caused flooding Saturday in southeastern Minnesota, with rain also scattered elsewhere in the eastern half of the nation, and temperatures dipped to record lows in the Northeast. The rain in Minnesota flooded numerous roads and forced evacuation of some low-lying campgrounds. Rainfall amounts ranged from 3 to 7 inches and there were unofficial reports of up to 10 inches in Rice County, the National Weather Service said. The State Patrol closed a highway covered by 2-3 feet of water between Zumbrota and Pine Island, northwest of Rochester. No injuries were reported. Heavy rain also fell in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area and the weather service warned of possible flooding of highway approach ramps and underpasses. Showers and thunderstorms also extended over Wisconsin, western Upper Michigan, northern Illinois, northwestern Minnesota, eastern North Dakota and northeastern Iowa. Scattered showers and thunderstorms spread rain over west-central Florida, west-central Alabama, east-central Mississippi, southeastern North Carolina, northeastern South Carolina, and along the Texas Gulf Coast. Elsewhere, showers and thunderstorms were scattered over northern Maine, Arizona and south-central Utah. Thunderstorms produced about an inch of rain in the Green Valley area of south-central Arizona, south of Tucson, during less than an hour and and a flash flood warning was issued for eastern Pima County. The heat wave that rolled across the nation was definitely over in the Northeast. Binghamton, N.Y., had a record low of 49 and Youngstown, Ohio, had a record of 42. Records were tied at Buffalo, N.Y., at 50 degrees, and Toledo, Ohio, at 47. But the heat lingered in the Southeast, where Augusta, Ga., tied its record of 104. Other Georgia cities also topped 100. The temperature also hit 100 at Jacksonville, Fla., and Montgomery, Ala. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 55 at Rhinelander, Wis., to 103 in Georgia at Augusta, Macon and Warner Robins. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 31 at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Men Who Blew up Heavy Water Plant Relive WW II Exploit
DOC.TEXT: Eight of the saboteurs who blew up a key factory in Nazi Germany's atomic bomb project held their first reunion Saturday, reliving one of World War II's most daring secret exploits. The eight Norwegians, all in their 70s and retired, led several thousand people who walked along a new ``Saboteurs' Trail,'' a five-mile path that follows the route they used to reach the German-operated plant in Telemark County. ``We didn't recognize the importance of what we did until the atomic bomb was dropped on Japan,'' said Joachim Roenneberg, recalling the night of Feb. 28, 1943, when the 10 men blew up the Nazi Heavy Water plant near Rjukan, 125 miles northwest of Oslo. The Allies, fearing Germany would build an atomic bomb before the West, had ordered the plant destroyed at any cost. After an aircraft carrying British commandos crashed in occupied Norway, it was up to the Norwegians. On Saturday, the eight saboteurs attending the ceremony stood at attention for the Norwegian national anthem. One of the 10 has died and another was unable to attend. Women and children handed them flowers and many in the crowd cried. Volunteers in Rjukan, a town of 4,500, built the hiking trail. The 10 Norwegians have been celebrated in books and movies, including the American film production, ``Heroes of Telemark.'' Roenneberg, who led the expedition at 23 years old, said: ``It was not like a military operation. It was more like a group of friends who set out to do something together.'' The mostly British-trained saboteurs parachuted into Norway and, weeks later, approached Rjukan. New York-born Knut Haukelig said they slid down a mountain through wet snow and waited for darkness. One man remained behind as a radio operator. Five stayed near a German barracks, ready to fight if the German soldiers were alerted. Four saboteurs found an unguarded railroad line leading to the plant and crawled through a pipe into its basement. They met only a Norwegian technician, who did not resist. Roenneberg said they set explosives with fuses that gave them 30 seconds to escape. The saboteurs made their way back into the mountains and some skied 250 miles in 14 days to Sweden, before heading back to England.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Turn Up Volume on Anti-Abortion Vote
With AM-Louisiana Abortion, Bjt
LaserPhotoBT4
DOC.TEXT: As state senators quietly debated whether to override Gov. Buddy Roemer's veto of a strict anti-abortion bill Saturday, hundreds of demonstrators shouted their stands as they broiled in the sun outside. The Senate sustained Roemer's veto of what would have been the nation's toughest state abortion law. The vote was 23 in favor of the override _ three short of the two-thirds majority needed _ and 16 against. Before senators cast their ballots, the parking lot at the skyscraper Capitol was jammed with about 1,500 people as temperatures inched into the 90s. State troopers limited access to the building, allowing almost 200 spectators in the Senate chamber, with another 500 in the rotunda separating the House and Senate chambers. Several hundred more gathered on the Capitol steps or under shade trees on the grounds. Most of the crowd was in favor of the strict anti-abortion bill, which would send abortionists to jail for up to 10 years. Anti-abortionists' cries of ``override, override'' pervaded the thick stone walls of the Senate chamber, in which every chair was filled and spectators lined up along the walls. Another anti-abortion rally was held on the Capitol lawn, while about 100 pro-choice demonstrators stood on the steps above them, shouting ``sustain that veto'' and ``church and state _ separate.'' After the Senate voted to sustain, one pro-choice supporter yelled ``all right'' and was told by security officers to be quiet. Then she ran from the chamber, screaming ``I'm out of here.'' As other viewers quietly filed out of the gallery, abortion rights supporters waved purple flowers and ribbons in the rotunda, shouting: ``We won.'' Anti-abortionists countered with ``We will win. We will win.'' The Senate was to vote against Sunday on the override measure.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Intends to Decide Whether Golf Cart Qualifies as Wheelchair
LaserPhoto ERI1 of July 6
DOC.TEXT: A couple with cerebral palsy who use a golf cart to drive city streets are challenging police orders to get them off the road, saying the car provides their only means of transport. John L. Shauberger, 45, of Lake City, was cited May 21 for driving without a license and operating an unregistered vehicle. He faced a magistrate's hearing, which was scheduled for Friday but suspended. If he is convicted and ordered not to drive the cart on public streets, Shauberger said, he and Kathy would be forced to walk with a cane or depend on others for rides. ``That's not independence as far as I'm concerned,'' said Shauberger, who added that he can't afford a car modified for handicapped drivers. Shauberger can walk with the assistance of a cane. His 28-year-old wife is confined to a wheelchair. District Justice Charles Wise suspended completion of the hearing because Shauberger's lawyer could not attend. Wise said he would rule on the traffic citations and decide whether to fine Shauberger $370 after the lawyer presents his case. Wise said he would consider whether the golf cart qualifies as a wheelchair when he rules on the citations. State Trooper Paul McGuire, who testified Friday, said wheelchairs are exempt from being registered, although operators must be licensed to travel on roads. ``I think the essence of this whole case is really ... the definition of a wheelchair,'' Wise said. ``It would seem to me that a golf cart would be safer than a little narrow wheelchair on the highway.'' The magistrate said Shauberger had been cited for driving in a traffic lane of the highway without a drivers license in an unregistered cart. McGuire has stopped Shauberger twice this year. He said he and other troopers previously had warned Shauberger not to drive on the highway.

DOC.HEAD: Poorest Countries Seeking More Aid, Debt Relief At Summits
DOC.TEXT: The world's poorest nations have told the industrial countries meeting at a Houston summit that they must provide more aid and debt relief to avoid a spiral of poverty and social unrest in the Third World. ``It is proved beyond a shadow of a doubt that there is no substitute for a market economy, and this is what we strive to achieve,'' said A.H.G. Mohiuddin, U.N. ambassador of Bangladesh and spokesman for the 42 nations known as the Least Developed Countries. ``But if our efforts are not met by commensurate aid, we will be faced with social unrest which will undo all our good work,'' he said in an interview before this week's Houston summit of the United States and six other leading industrial nations. ``We have tightened our belts beyond our capacity, and if there is a failure in reciprocal commitment (from the industrial world), then it will be suicidal for us,'' he said. Mohiuddin has visited the capitals of the seven nations to ``sensitize'' them to the needs of the impoverished Third World, the poorest of the poor. The poor nations are calling for development assistance in the form of .15 percent of the industrial nations' gross national product by 1995 and .20 percent by the end of the decade. They also seek debt cancellation and reduction and removal of trade barriers to their exports. In general, the Bangladesh envoy said, the response was positive _ but not specific. The poorest nations hope that the final communique from the Houston summit will address some of their problems. Nordic countries and most participants in the Houston summit are approaching or have reached the development assistance sought by the poor nations. However, the United States and Japan, which give extensive aid, have opposed aid targets. The United States gives about .04 percent of its GNP, the total annual value of produced goods and services, to the world's poorest nations. The Houston session could foreshadow what will happen at an international conference on the Least Developed Countries in Paris in September, when a plan of domestic action and foreign help is to be developed. Officials of the poorest nations hope the wealthiest ones will persuade others in the international arena to support their cause. But the wealthiest nations recently have been emphasizing the importance of respecting human rights and instituting democratic political reforms as conditions for foreign aid in Eastern Europe and elsewhere. The poorest nations respond by saying that poverty is the greatest obstacle to human rights everywhere. The poorest nations have expressed concern that aid to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe should not take away from the industrial nations' commitment to help the poorest countries, which have a total of 475 million people. The Least Developed Countries, as defined by the World Bank, are the world's most abjectly poor, with average per capita incomes of less than $500 per year. Their total foreign debt is about $55 billion. Their annual debt service payment alone is nearly $4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Continues to Determine Cause of Fatal Explosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Shearn is cq in 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The ARCO Chemical Co.'s inquiry into the plant explosion that killed 17 people has been stymied by a court order issued Saturday for the wife of a deceased worker. In response to her negligence lawsuit against the company, a judge granted a temporary restraining order preventing Atlantic Richfield Co. and ARCO Chemical from making any changes to the accident scene. Atlantic Richfield, based in Los Angeles, owns 83 percent of ARCO Chemical. ``We can't remove anything until OSHA releases the area to us,'' said Jack Johnson, president of ARCO Chemical Americas. He refused to comment further on the lawsuit, filed Friday by Sandra Lucas Davis. Her husband, Gregory Scott Davis, 27, was one of the names on a partial list of victims released by the company Saturday. State District Judge Shearn Smith issued the temporary restraining order, but it did not prohibit OSHA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, from conducting its investigation. OSHA officials, who were sifting through the damaged area, expect to complete their investigation in about a week, Johnson said. Assistant Secretary of Labor Gerard F. Scannell said Friday his agency was focusing on maintenance reports and complaints that employees had to work especially long hours at the plant. Plant manager Earl McCaleb said workers normally work 12-hour shifts for four days, then are off four days. Harold Sorgenti, president of ARCO Chemical, said the company was concentrating on helping families and employees deal with the deaths, while making sure the plant is stabilized. The explosion at about 11:30 p.m. Thursday ripped through the plant's utility area on the extreme southern end of the complex where employees were doing maintenance work, officials said. What the employees actually were doing ``will be determined by the investigation,'' Sorgenti said. ``Initially, they were beginning to fix a compressor.'' Initial speculation was that the five ARCO workers and 11 Austin Industrial Inc. contract workers killed were cleaning the 900,000-gallon tank that exploded. The other worker killed was the driver of a vacuum truck that was in the area to remove rainwater from a sump, McCaleb said. Sorgenti also said the investigation will focus on why so many people were in the area when normally five people are assigned there. ``I think it's difficult to understand why there was that concentration of employees in that area at that time,'' said Sorgenti, who flew to Houston from Europe where he was on business. McCaleb said it would be several months before the plant begins operating again. The 350 ARCO employees at the plant, about 15 miles east of Houston, are working to restore the plant and will not lose any pay, he said. The ARCO plant annually produces 560 million pounds of propylene oxide, used to make flexible foam for seat cushions and bedding. It also produces 1.3 billion pounds of styrene monomer, used for insulation, foam drinking cups, packaging materials and automotive parts; and 1.7 billion pounds of methyl tertiary butyl ether, a high-octane blending component used as a replacement for lead in gasoline. The explosion was the second major loss of life at a Houston area petrochemical facility in nine months. On Oct. 23, a series of explosions ripped through a Phillips Petroleum Co. plant in Pasadena, claiming 23 lives and injuring 130 people.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Says Asylum Seekers Can Leave Country Without Reprisal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with government shake-up, protest march in Tirana. Pickup pvs 5th graf, `Speaking from...' Edits to trim
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Albanians crowding into foreign embassies in hopes of fleeing their hard-line Communist homeland will be allowed to emigrate under foreign supervision, diplomats said Saturday. Also Saturday, the government announced a shake-up of the ruling Politburo and Central Committee. It replaced several hard-liners, including the police minister. About 5,000 people are sheltered in missions in the Albanian capital of Tirana, Western dipomats said. Many had climbed walls and crashed through embassy gates, some under fire from security forces, to gain entry. Hungarian diplomats said the logistics of the emigration had not been worked out, but ambassadors were told by Albanian Foreign Ministry officials their personnel could supervise the issuing of travel documents and accompany emigres out of the country. ``A solution has been found,'' Hungarian Ambassador Mihaly Kornidesz told state radio in Budapest. ``Passports will be issued, and embassy personnel will be allowed to oversee ... safe passage out of the country.'' Austria's APA news agency said thousands of protesters gathered near embassy row Saturday to show their opposition to the hard-line Communist regime. No violence was reported. Friday, 10,000 pro-democracy demonstrators marched in silence near embassy row, APA reported. The silent rally dispersed after a brief clash between police and some demonstrators. Reacting to the unrest, the policy-setting Central Committee of the Communist Party dismissed a Politburo member, retired three other politicians and relieved Police Minister Simon Stefani of his position, the state news agency ATA reported. Hekuran Isaj, who is regarded as a moderate, was announced as Stefani's replacement, ATA reported. ATA also reported that three new figures were appointed to the Politburo and two new appointments were made to the Central Committee. The changes appeared to reflect the power of Communist leader Ramiz Alia and his efforts to reform Albania's hard-line Communist system. Also Saturday, Alia decreed several measures to reform Albania's command economy, including the introduction of small-scale private enterprise limited to tradesmen and farmers. He did not, however, mention the embassy standoff or promise political reforms. Speaking from Tirana, a Hungarian diplomat said on condition of anonymity that police sealed off the diplomatic quarter Saturday afternoon, apparently to prevent new asylum-seekers from gaining access to the missions. The reported breakthrough came just hours after Albanian legislators guaranteed citizens could leave the embassies without fear of punishment. The Albanian Foreign Ministry on Thursday promised to grant passports to those who have sought refuge in foreign missions. But Saturday's parliamentary decree, published by the Albanian state news agency ATA, was the first pledge with the force of law that Albanians in the foreign missions could receive passports without fear or prosecution. The thousands of Albanians in the foreign embassies were a near-intolerable strain on some missions, which lacked sufficient food and water. Albanian authorities were not allowing foreign governments to send supplies, Western officials said. The Hungarian diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity said that under the deal worked out with authorities, the Albanians were to remain in the embassies until told their passports were ready. ``On the day of their departure, or on the day immediately preceding it, they will be going in groups to the passport office to get documents and can be accompanied by embassy staffers,'' he said. Diplomats will be invited to board the aircraft, trains, buses or boats taking Albanians to their new homelands, the diplomat said. But only those accepted by a foreign country will be allowed to leave, he said. The diplomat said he believed France had already pledged to take in all Albanians packing its embassy. In the 45 years of hard-line Communist rule, travel for average Albanians has been virtually impossible. But under Alia, who took power in 1985, the country of 3.2 million people has increasingly sought ties abroad and has slowly begun to implement reforms. A package of new regulations that took effect Tuesday entitled all Albanians over age 16 to own a passport. The ATA dispatch said the embassy occupations were calculated to create ``a state of tension and opposition to the laws and regulations of the Albanian state.'' ``This is also proved by the fact that some countries want to send here food, tents medicaments, so as to turn the yards of the embassies into refugees' camps. ``Such brutal interference and anti-human acts are unacceptable and punishable,'' ATA said. On Friday, Alia told the Central Committee that the party would not give up power as Communists have done elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The sometimes-violent rush to the embassies in Tirana follows last year's exodus of East Germans to embassies in other East European countries shortly before the fall of their Communist government. Most of the Albanians who fled to foreign embassies before Thursday entered in a rush during rioting that began Monday under fire from Albanian security forces. Diplomats said at least three people were wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Rests Case In Trial Of Four Accused In DEA Agent Death
DOC.TEXT: The defense has rested its case in the trial of four men charged in the torture-slaying of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena. Before Friday's conclusion of the defense case, U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie admitted into evidence Mexican telephone records that raised doubts about testimony given by a key prosecution witness. Hector Cervantes Santos, a former bodyguard for narcotics trafficker Javier Barba Hernandez, testified that drug lords planned the kidnap-murder of Camarena in late 1984 and early 1985 at Barba's Guadalajara home. Cervantes testified that phone calls were made and received at the home while the slaying was being planned. But records from Mexico's national telephone company show there was no telephone service in that area until early 1988. Rafeedie said he expected closing arguments this week after the prosecution calls rebuttal witnesses. On trial in the 1985 torture-slayings of Camarena, his Mexican pilot and two U.S. tourists in Guadalajara are Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, a convicted Honduran drug trafficker; Ruben Zuno Arce, a businessman and brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican policeman; and Javier Vasquez Velasco. The judge refused to admit defense testimony from a government informant. Lawrence Victor Harrison testified at a hearing with the jury absent that Mexican drug kingpin Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo told him he funded the U.S.-backed Contra guerrillas in Nicaragua and felt protected from U.S. prosecution because of it. Felix Gallardo is in a Mexican prison for drug trafficking. But the judge ruled that Harrison's statements were based on secondhand information and did not bear directly on the trial. ``This witness' testimony is based on hearsay, gossip and speculation,'' the judge said after two hours of questioning. ``The court found this witness' testimony incompetent.'' Harrison, 45, was recalled to the witness stand after revelation of a DEA interview in which Harrison claimed the CIA had trained Guatemalan guerrillas at a Veracruz, Mexico, ranch owned by drug trafficker Rafael Caro Quintero, who is serving a prison term in Mexico for Camarena's murder. The defense had hoped to argue that the Guadalajara cocaine cartel operated by Caro and Felix Gallardo had ties to the CIA. The CIA has denied any involvement in drug trafficking.

DOC.HEAD: Transplant Recipient Released From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, was released Saturday from Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh after two days of testing, a hospital spokeswoman said. The 13-year-old girl from White Settlement, Texas, had been readmitted to the hospital Thursday so doctors could monitor her liver function and medication levels. Spokeswoman Lynn McMahon said Stormie had experienced mild rejection and physicians adjusted her medication. Stormie underwent the first heart-liver transplant on Valentine's Day 1984 because of a congenital condition that gave her cholesterol levels 10 times normal. Hepatitis damaged that liver and she received her second liver in February of this year. Doctors discovered last month that Stormie had developed hepatitis. They reduced the amount of anti-rejection medicine she was receiving so her body could combat the infection in her liver.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Bulgarians Rally After Communist President Resigns
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 10,000 people rallied in a downtown square Saturday to celebrate the resignation of Communist President Petar Mladenov. He resigned Friday after admitting he had called for tanks be used to crush an anti-Communist demonstration last year. His departure came less than three weeks after his party of reformed Communists won the country's first free elections in 58 years. Mladenov was instrumental in last year's ousting of Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov. Prodded by popular demonstrations, Mladenov then played a key role in reforming the party, now known as the democratic Socialist Party. Saturday's peaceful rally was organized by students who had been on strike demandiong that Mladenov step down. Most of the student groups involved in the strike announced they would stop Saturday. But about 1,000 students continued a sit-in in front of Parliament to promote other demands, including the setting of a trial date for Zhivkov and removal of former Communist functionaries from Parliament. Zhivkov has been charged with misappropriation of state property, abuse of power, and inciting ethnic hostility. During his rule, ethnic Turks were assimilated into Bulgarian society by force. Blaga Dimitrova, a writer and one of Bulgaria's few dissidents under the old regime, praised the campaign that led to Mladenov's resignation. ``It was a fight not against a person, but against a demoralized system,'' she told cheering participants during Saturday's rally. The event was dubbed the ``Rally of Joy and Victory.'' Mladenov stepped down after weeks of mounting pressure generated by revelations he had suggested that tanks move against an anti-government rally outside Parliament late last year. No tanks were used.

DOC.HEAD: Haitians Stage Protest Near Site of Arrests
DOC.TEXT: About 300 Haitian demonstrators chanted and marched peacefully Saturday outside a shopping center where police had violently broken up a demonstration two days earlier. ``From South Africa to South Florida, apartheid must go!'' protest leaders chanted through megaphones. A Haitian exile leader, the Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, said the demonstration was aimed at opposing violence against blacks and Haitians in stores and by police. ``Today's protest is to stop the trend,'' he said. ``We're saying stop the beating, stop the violence, whether it comes from black or white or Hispanics.'' Authorities issued a permit for up to 100 people to rally for three hours Saturday afternoon on a sidewalk across the street from the shopping center. They were watched by about 130 police officers in riot gear and on horseback. Police had earlier refused a permit allowing protesters near a clothing store. The Rapid Transit Factory Outlet and its Cuban-born owner have been the target of a series of protests following the alleged beating of a Haitian customer June 29 in a dispute over a pair of pants. The store remained open Saturday. Store owner Luis Reyes, 65, claims it was his son who was the victim of the altercation. Tensions between blacks and Hispanics in Miami also are strained by the refusal by Mayor Xavier Suarez and other politicians to welcome anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela last month. The officials said they were opposed to the South African's links to Cuban leader Fidel Castro. On Thursday, police carrying clubs and shields arrested 58 protesters who refused orders to disperse from in front of the store. Seven of those arrested were taken into custody by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and could face deportation. Jean-Juste has called for a boycott against the Rapid Transit store and any other business that treated Haitians poorly. ``Our normal customers are mostly staying away, but Spanish-speaking people have responded to what they feel is an injustice caused by a small segment of the community,'' said Reyes. Reyes promised to remain open as long as customers keep coming. ``This is a fight we are not backing down from,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Billing Chief Arrested For Taking Bribes
DOC.TEXT: An executive whose company processes thousands of claims for the state's troubled high-risk insurance pool was arrested Saturday for allegedly taking bribes to allow auto body shops to inflate bills. William P. Horan, an executive with Computer Science Corp., was arrested on charges of conspiracy to commit racketeering by acts of commercial bribery and theft, said a spokesman for Attorney General Robert Del Tufo. Five alleged co-conspirators _ four body-shop owners or managers and an appraiser _ also were arrested. New Jersey's insurance system is being overhauled. A new law requires the industry to pay $1.4 billion during the next seven years to help eliminate the $3.1 billion debt amassed by a pool for high-risk drivers overseen by the Joint Underwriting Association. The association, whose financing costs every New Jersey motorist $222 per car on their annual policy, is to be eliminated under the law. Computer Science Corp. is the second-largest computer service company working for the underwriting assocation, processing hundreds of thousands claims annually, said Robert T. Winter, director of the Division of Criminal Justice. Horan ``received tens of dollars in bribe money to insure that certain body shops got the claims and that the inflated billings would be approved for payment,'' Winter said. Horan, a group director of field operations for Computer Science's computer division, was arraigned before Superior Court Judge Paul Chaiet and released on $50,000 bail, said Chuck Davis, spokesman for Del Tufo. An 18-month investigation uncovered an ``extensive'' scheme to funnel money to Horan from auto body shops and appraisal companies, Winter said. The body shops and appraisal firms would repair the damaged vehicles and send inflated invoices to the underwriting association, Winter said. Horan was charged with assuring that the inflated claims were approved, with the underwriting association footing the bill, Winter said. Authorities had no evidence to indicate that other Computer Science officials were involved in the scheme, Winter said. A woman answering the telephone at the company's Piscataway office said an official would not be available for comment until Monday. Telephone calls placed to Horan's home on Saturday seeking comment were not answered. Horan was accused of committing the acts between Feb. 3, 1989 and June 29, 1990. Jon Shure, spokesman for Gov. Jim Florio, said the arrests were part of the governor's plan to bring fairness to New Jersey motorists, who pay among the highest premiums in the country. ``When Governor Florio signed the insurance reform law it was more than a commitment to lower rates,'' Shure said. ``It was a pledge to bring back fairness for New Jersey drivers, and that means vigorously pursuing any cases where the people of the state are being ripped off.'' Also accused of conspiracy to commit racketeering through the act of commercial bribery and theft were Nicholas J. Caliendo of Colts Neck, vice president of Rural Body Works, Inc.; Kennedy E. Kowalski of Freehold, owner of Ken's Auto Body; Robert C. Smith of Wall, manager of Bill Murray's Auto Body & Glass, Inc.; Michael J. Bavaro of Colts Neck, president of Bodymotion, Inc.; and John F. Vuono of Neptune, president of Shore Appraisal Service. Caliendo was arraigned before Holmdel Municipal Judge Kenneth Smith and released on $50,000 bail. Bail was set at $50,000 for Bavaro and $30,000 each for Kowalski, Smith and Vunon.

DOC.HEAD: Getty Museum Pulls 6th Century B.C. Greek Statue to Check Authenticity
DOC.TEXT: The J. Paul Getty Museum has removed a prized marble sculpture from public display to determine if it is fake or an authentic 6th century B.C. Greek statue. Doubt about the kouros, a 6-foot-8 carving of a nude male youth, was raised during the examination of another work, a marble torso regarded as a fake or modern copy that was recently acquired by the Getty for study. The kouros was removed from display Friday. ``When I first saw the torso in April this year, I noticed subtle similarities of style and detail between the piece and the museum's kouros,'' said Marion True, curator of antiquities. ``This gave me reason to re-examine our own statue.'' Some experts have doubted the Getty kouros, purchased in 1985 for an undisclosed price from a private collector. Only about a dozen complete kouros figures are known to exist. Two years ago the museum discovered that a marble ``Head of Achilles'' in its collection was a modern copy.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Fire On Supporters Of Multiparty Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to RAISE background on democratic movement, ADD background on Kenya's history; pickup graf 17 pvs `However, the...'
DOC.TEXT: Police fired bullets and tear gas Saturday at thousands of demonstrators who defied a government ban and held a rally demanding a multiparty democracy. The disturbances quickly spread throughout the city and police pursued demonstrators into Nairobi's commercial center. The violence comes after months of agitation for multiparty democracy in Kenya, which has been a one-party state by law since 1982. Riot police moved through the streets Saturday firing into the air and telling crowds to disperse. By nightfall, only small groups of demonstrators remained, clashing sporadically with troops. It was not immediately known if there were any casualties. Witnesses said they saw security forces beat people. The violence broke out after about 500 protesters gathered at a field several blocks from Nairobi's busy commercial center for a rally to demand democracy. Kenneth Matiba and Charles Rubia, leading opponents of the government who were detained last week, had called for the rally. Authorities had denied permission for the rally, and President Daniel arap Moi said force would be used to break it up. ``We want two parties!'' many protesters shouted, waving two fingers in the local multiparty salute. They were joined by thousands of others who had watched the rally from the ground's fringes. The demonstrators, many carrying rocks, then broke into crowds numbering in the hundreds and faced off with security forces who tried to block roads around the field. Trucks bearing dozens of armed soldiers headed toward the field. When protesters stoned a plainclothes police officer and his car and commandeered a bus, security forces charged the crowd, firing bullets and tear gas. Panic-stricken groups ran into downtown Nairobi. Workers poured out of their offices and formed large crowds at bus stops as hundreds tried to flee the city. Most traffic other than buses was quickly gone from the streets. The atmosphere remained tense hours after the clashes. Surrounding streets were littered with rocks, glass and other debris. Thousands of people milled around downtown Nairobi, and special riot police moved through the streets firing into the air and telling crowds to disperse. Sporadic gunfire could be heard downtown throughout the afternoon. A few shops were looted and isolated groups of demonstrators reportedly stoned some cars. Kenya has been at peace since independence from Britain in 1963. It often is cited as an example of stability and prosperity on a continent known more for guerrilla warfare, military juntas and corrupt dictatorship. Since the beginning of the year, however, a loose coalition emboldened by the changes in Eastern Europe has repeatedly accused the ruling Kenya African National Union party of intolerance, corruption and election-rigging. Demands for change began Jan. 1 in an address by the Rev. Timothy Njhoya, long a critic of the government. The Presbyterian pastor urged Africans to reflect on the experience of Eastern Europe and choose multiparty democracy. However, the government has rejected any move toward allowing other parties and calls its opponents subversives. Moi says multiparty politics would create ethnic strife among the East African nation's 40 tribes and lead to tribal warfare. Moi has said he will hunt down political pluralists ``like rats.'' The government has detained at least 11 opponents since Wednesday, according to their families and other sources close to the opposition. Matiba and Rubia, former Cabinet ministers, were seized by plainclothes security agents. Other detainees include Raila Odinga, son of Kenya's first vice president, and Gitobu Imanyara, a lawyer who edits a magazine critical of the government's human rights record. Kenya's last opposition party was banned in 1969. A constitutional amendment in 1982 declared Kenya a one-party state, and last week's detentions appeared to be the harshest crackdown since 1982. Moi has said the existence of about 40 tribes in Kenya would invite tribal-based parties, leading to ethnic divisions and even tribal warfare. On Friday, the U.S. State Department said the detentions ``only serve to tarnish Kenya's image in the international community,'' and it urged the government not to persecute the opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers' Group Votes Down Bid to Stop Pro-Choice Lobbying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to update with delegates' defeat of efforts to stop abortion lobbying, picking up at the 3rd graf previous, ``In a sense.''
DOC.TEXT: Delegates to the National Education Association convention on Saturday easily defeated an attempt to stop the union's policy of lobbying for abortion rights. The union was expected to re-examine its stance in favor of women's right to abortion at least twice more before it concludes business late Sunday. The union in 1985 agreed to support family planning, including ``the right to reproductive freedom.'' Christine Nowak of New York led efforts to eliminate abortion lobbying from the legislative agenda of the nation's largest teachers' union. She and others argued that union dues should not be used for such activity because the NEA's 2 million members have a variety of views on the issue. In a resounding voice vote, the 8,100 delegates to the group's annual convention rejected the legislative amendment. NEA officials said the union has not yet spent money on the issue because it has not come up in Congress. The action came only hours after television producer Norman Lear, a leading advocate of the separation of church and state, urged the NEA delegates to focus more on morals during classroom instructions. ``As educators, you probably have more to do with the character of the next generation than anyone else,'' Lear told the educators. ``In a sense, you are the architects of that generation,'' he said. Lear said teachers cannot successfully instill knowledge in young people's minds unless they also ``feed the heart and soul.'' Neither can schools spark students' interest in the world, social wrongs and personal morality unless they also teach about the core values that bind society together, he said. Educators must ``fling open the doors and find new ways of learning more about each other's values and spiritual traditional and what we all hold in common,'' he said. Today's societal problems are the result of a lack of focus on the ``inner life,'' said Lear, describing that as ``that portion of ourselves that impels us to create art and literature, and study ethics, philosophy and history.'' ``Greed is the order of the day in a society preoccupied at all levels with the pursuit of bottom-lines, a society which celebrates consumption, careerism, and winning, and lives by the creed of `I've-got-mine-Jack,''' he said. To illustrate the destructiveness of this ethic, Lear pointed to ``our alarming environmental woes,'' frequent oil spills at sea, the extinction of 10,000 species per year and teen pregnancies. The Emmy award-winning television producer is best known for prime time sitcoms like ``All in the Family'' and ``The Jeffersons.'' He founded the civil libertarian organization People For the American Way as a response to the growing religious right movement. Although a long-time foe of the religious right, he credited the conservative group with sparking his ideas. Lear cautioned that teaching about religion should not trample on the sensibilities of minority faiths and ``that neither teachers nor students proselytize.''

DOC.HEAD: Injured Protester Dies as Nicaraguan Strike Enters Sixth Day
DOC.TEXT: A worker backing Sandinista labor strikes died Saturday from wounds he suffered during clashes with government supporters. Meanwhile, the government and strike leaders remained at odds in the six-day-old series of walkouts. The slain man was identified as Marvin Alvarado Ponce, an 18-year-old mechanic. Family members said he was shot Friday by two people on a motorcycle when he was taking part in a street demonstration. Police said they were investigating the case. At least four people, not including Alvarado Ponce, were injured Friday when striking workers clashed with pro-government demonstrators. The demonstration was to generate support for the Sandinista-supported strikes in which tens of thousands of workers are calling for more participation in economic policy-making. The walkouts are spearheaded by the Sandinista National Labor Front, a union sympathetic to the leftist Sandinista party. The party lost Feb. 25 elections to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Chamorro's U.S.-backed administration condemned the strike Friday night, calling it ``political, illegal, illicit and non-existent.'' Also Friday night, Finance Minister Emilio Pereira announced a 43 percent salary hike for government workers on lower pay scales. He also promised to give 65,000 of the government's 100,000-member workforce cost-of-living raises based on price increases. But Front leader Lucio Jimenez said the constant devaluation of the national currency will counterbalance the raise. ``We have decided to keep up the strike,'' he said. Labor Minister Francisco Rosales, a member of the government team negotiating with labor leaders, threatened to fire government workers who do not show up for work Monday. He said police will open closed plant gates and army trucks will be used to provide transportation. Jimenez said 90,000 government and private business employees joined the walkouts this week. They are demanding a new minimum wage, job security, protection of peasant land distributed under land reforms of the past Sandinista administration, financing for industrial ventures, and the opening of new construction projects.

DOC.HEAD: Human Relations Panel Sues Pizza Chain For Refusing to Hire Bearded Sikh
DOC.TEXT: The state Human Relations Commission has charged Domino's Pizza Inc. with religious discrimination for refusing to hire a Sikh man, whose religion requires him to wear a beard. The nationwide chain has a policy that all employees must be cleanshaven, but no Maryland health law prohibits food service employees from having beards. The June 28 commission complaint said that Prabhjot S. Kohli, of Catonsville, was refused employment when he applied for a job as manager of a Domino's store in December 1987. Herb James, personnel director of LOOC Inc., the Domino's franchise that interviewed Kohli, said the complaint was ``a slap in the face to us when we are desperately trying to work things out with this individual.'' James, quoted in Saturday's Baltimore Sun, said Kohli knew the dress code and policies when he interviewed for the job and that he also was unwilling to work the weekend and night hours required. He said other company jobs that did not involve contact with the public were available, but Kohli refused to consider them. Kohli, now an engineer with the State Highway Administration, said he applied for the advertised position of senior manager because he had 18 years' experience as a salesman. He said he was not interested in the other jobs. In its complaint, filed with the state administrative hearing examiner, the Human Relations Commission asked that Domino's pay Kohli for two years of lost earnings and that he be hired as a Domino's manager. The examiner's office will hold a public hearing later. A week ago, the commission won a case that ordered the University of Maryland to reinstate and pay back pay to a campus policeman who refused to shave his beard because of a skin condition. That case, decided by a state administrative law judge, involved charges of racial discrimination because the skin condition, pseudofolliculitis bearbae, usually afflicts black men. Men with the ailment suffer scarring and lesions when they shave.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian News Agency Says European Hostage Might be Released
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 10th `Iranian President...' to UPDATE with U.S. reax; pickup graf 11 `In Beirut...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: A European hostage among the 16 Westerners held in Lebanon might be released soon, Iran's official news agency said Saturday. Sources indicated an Irish captive might be freed. Most of the hostages are believed held by factions of Hezbollah, or Party of God, a fundamentalist Shiite Moslem group that receives financial support from Iran. The 47-word report from the Islamic Republic News Agency in Beirut, the Lebanese capital, was attributed to unidentified sources. The headline read: ``A European Hostage May Be Released Soon.'' ``A Western hostage held in Lebanon will probably be released soon,'' said the story, monitored in Nicosia. Sources would not disclose the identity of the hostage to be released, but ``hinted that he is most probably a European national,'' the dispatch said. ``It is not known when and where the hostage will be released.'' The hostages are six Americans and 10 Europeans _ four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. Longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Diplomats in Tehran said in recent interviews that Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has renewed a push to get the 10 European captives in Lebanon freed. Earlier this year Iran helped free two American hostages, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, then asked for a reciprocal gesture from the United States. President Bush has said he will not make deals for captives. But an outpouring of Western assistance to Iran after its devastating June 21 earthquake raised hopes in some quarters that Iran might again use its influence with the pro-Iranian groups believed holding the hostages. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani has said Iran should be grateful for the foreign quake aid. However, in comments earlier this month, he made no link between such aid and the release of any Western hostages. In Washington, State Department spokesman Anita Stockman said Saturday she had no information to confirm the report that another hostage may soon be released. She said the United States provided earthquake aid solely ``as a humanitarian gesture.'' While reiterating U.S. policy demanding the unconditional release of all hostages, she said the hostage issue ``is also a humanitarian issue.'' In Beirut, a source close to the Syrian army command said that if any hostage were released, it probably would be Brian Keenan, an Irishman who also holds a British passport. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war but has little direct hold over the hostage-takers. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, refused to say why he thought Keenan might be freed. A three-man delegation from Ireland's ruling party visited Tehran in mid-June. An Irish Red Cross aid plane was the first to reach Tehran after the quake. Keenan, 39, was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut April 11, 1986, as he walked from his home to the American University of Beirut, where he taught English. No group has claimed to be holding Keenan, of Belfast, but Reed said after his release from captivity in April that he had seen Keenan. ``We are hopeful _ but our hopes have been raised many times before,'' said Michael Gillham, Keenan's brother-in-law, speaking from his home in Dundonald, Northern Ireland. ``It is looking good for somebody at least to be freed and if that happens it will be good news, whoever it is,'' he said. In Moville, Ireland, Prime Minister Charles Haughey said: ``We are following developments very closely. I am always hopeful. We are making a total all-out effort, constantly using every means at our disposal _ our embassy and friends.'' Factions within Hezbollah are believed loyal to both anti-Western and pragmatic camps in the government. The pragmatic camp, led by Rafsanjani, has sought improved ties with the West to help repair Iran's shattered economy. The hard-line camp believes opposition to the West, especially the United States, is a cornerstone of the 1979 Islamic Revolution. But Western diplomats in Tehran interviewed after the earthquake said quake relief could be an important lever for Rafsanjani in his quest to free more hostages. ``The government wants to solve this crisis,'' one European diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``They are trying to find a way out by making a distinction between the European and American hostages.'' He said that focusing on the large amount of earthquake aid sent by European nations to Iran would help silence domestic opposition to making conciliatory gestures toward the West. ``It could be a way of solving the problem internally,'' the diplomat said. When Polhill and Reed were released earlier this year, the first word came from IRNA in a short dispatch worded similarly to Saturday's. At that time, Iran said it would work for the release of other hostages in return for help in gaining freedom for 300 Moslem prisoners, mostly Lebanese Shiites, held at an Israeli detention camp in south Lebanon. The inmates are accused of involvement in underground warfare against Israeli troops and allied militiamen of the South Lebanon Army who control a border strip in south Lebanon. Iran also has demanded that Western governments help shed light on the fate of four Iranians who were kidnapped in 1982 by a right-wing Lebanese Christian militia in north Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Warns of `Bloodbath' in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Saturday that right-wing groups in South Africa are planning a ``bloodbath'' to prevent black majority rule. Mandela was addressing a public rally in Uganda's capital of Kampala on the third day of his visit to this East African nation during an international tour. ``We know that there are many whites who are armed and determined to turn our country into a bloodbath,'' Mandela said. ``But these are hopeless dreams of people who fail to accept that majority rule will come to South Africa,'' said the 71-year-old deputy leader of the African National Congress. He cited allegations that white right-wing groups were responsible for a series of six bombings in South African cities last week. The last attack was Friday when a bomb went off in a crowded black bus terminal, inuring 27 people. White extremists claimed responsibility for five blasts, but there was no claim of responsibility for Friday's bombing. Mandela, who arrived here Thursday accompanied by his wife Winnie, shared the platform with presidents Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Joachim Chissano of Mozambique. Mandela said his organization, the leading group opposing white rule in South Africa, will strive in forthcoming talks with the government to create a constitution ending the apartheid system, the policy of legal racial discrimination. ``We will ensure that every person has the right to vote and serve in all organs of the government,'' he said. Mugabe told the cheering crowd the visit had given the four leaders an opportunity to discuss measures that could hasten the end of apartheid in South Africa. He said they would present the ideas to the annual Organization of African Unity summit starting Monday in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Managers Say Alaska Fire Conditions Worse Than Usual
DOC.TEXT: More than 170 wildfires still raged across Alaska on Saturday, and fire officials expressed concern the blazes could threaten small towns for weeks. Hot, dry weather _ in tandem with thousands of fire-causing lightning strikes _ is making the summer fire season much worse than years past, said Pete Buist, a spokesman for an inter-agency fire information center at Fairbanks. In a more typical summer, tundra and forests would be wetter, humidity higher, and most fires would be monitored but not aggressively fought, he said, ``but under the weather conditions we have now, we start manning fires that we would not ordinarily.'' Unlike other western states, where policies to let fires burn have been criticized, Alaska fire managers typically allow most wildfires to burn because they seldom pose a risk to people or property. No lives or homes have been lost to Alaska fires this year, authorities said. But massive fires across the state are burning nearer to villages than usual. Throughout Alaska some 2,400 firefighters were battling fires consuming more than 280,225 acres in a wide east-west band across the flat tundra and black spruce forests of the sparsely populated interior. The most critical blaze was the 47,000-acre fire near Tok; at its worst on Thursday, it burned to within a quarter-mile of the crossroads village on the Alaska Highway, 260 miles northeast of Anchorage. Firefighters on Saturday took advantage of a second consecutive day of overcast skies, 30 percent humidity and temperatures in the 60s to battle the blaze. Rob McWhorter, a Bureau of Land Management spokesman at Tok, said about 400 firefighters would continue to defend the village of about 1,000 people, even though the fire posed no danger for now. ``The fire is not a direct threat,'' McWhorter said Saturday. ``But the joker in the deck, really, is this cloud cover because we're told that thunderstorms are imbedded in it.'' McWhorter said that could create gusting, erratic winds that could blow the fire near town again. The other serious fires included the 910-acre Pedro Dome fire, 15 miles northeast of Fairbanks; the Cassiar Creek fire about 50 miles north of Fairbanks at 2,500 acres; a 33,000-acre blaze near the village of Beaver, about 100 miles north of Fairbanks; and a 27,000-acre fire touched off by lightning within Denali National Park.

DOC.HEAD: Stars' Salaries Cited in Closure of Harrah's Reno Showroom
DOC.TEXT: Harrah's Headliner Room, one of the last bastions of big-name entertainment in Reno, will become a cabaret-lounge next year, featuring a nightly revue. Ronald S. Jeffrey, senior vice president and general manager of Harrah's Reno, announce the change Friday, saying the planned conversion of the 24-year-old showroom into an ``intimate nightclub'' in December was a response to a changing entertainment scene. The increasing cost of paying for top-name entertainers and the difficulty of finding those who will perform two shows nightly influenced the decision, Jeffrey said. The Headliner Room opened with Eddie Fisher as its top act in 1966 and featured such stars as Sammy Davis Jr., Danny Thomas, Patti Page and Bill Cosby during its heyday. After its conversion, the room will stay roughly the same size, seating 400 to 450 people. The loss of the Headliner Room will leave the Reno area with only three stages designed for top-name acts _ Bally's, the Sparks Nugget and The Flamingo Hilton.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Advocate Had Been Under IRS Scrutiny Prior to His Death
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 8th graf to update with Fennelly leaving hospital
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service had been examining the records of Mitch Snyder for a year prior to his apparent suicide last week, an attorney for the homeless advocate said Saturday. The attorney, Gerald A. Kafka, said the IRS ``stepped in'' about a year ago to audit royalties paid to Snyder from the 1986 television movie, ``Samaritan: The Mitch Snyder Story.'' Snyder was a consultant on the film. ``The IRS was examining civilly Mitch's tax liability for prior years. ... It was the audit of any taxpayer and the IRS wasn't handling it any differently,'' Kafka said in a telephone interview. Ellen Murphy, director of public affairs for the IRS, said Saturday the agency was proibited from commenting. The body of Snyder, 46, was found hanging by an electrical cord Thursday in his bedroom at the Community for Creative Non-Violence, the Washington homeless shelter he ran. Authorities said Snyder apparently had killed himself one or two days earlier. Kafka said he had scheduled a meeting with Snyder for last Tuesday evening to ``wrap up'' the IRS situation, but ``he didn't make the meeting.'' Police found a note near Snyder's body in which he talked about problems with his relationship with Carol Fennelly, his longtime companion and co-worker at the shelter. The two had planned to marry in September. Fennelly was scheduled for admission to Capitol Hill Hospital after she collapsed outside the CCNV shelter during a meeting of the homeless advocacy group on Saturday. Hospital spokeswoman Lisa Poulter said doctors advised Fennelly be admitted for observation but she decided to leave. Police sources last week who described the note did not say if it mntioned any difficulties with the IRS. Snyder had refused, for philosophical reasons, to incorporate his shelter as a tax-exempt group. Kafka would not say whether Snyder had refused to pay taxes. ``It's safe to say Mitch was very consistent in his treatment of taxes,'' Kafka said. ``Mitch did not gain any economic advantage from the movie,'' the attorney said. ``The money went straight to CCNV.'' According to a report in Saturday editions of The New York Times, Snyder told co-workers six weeks ago about the audit. Members of the District of Columbia City Council had criticized Snyder for failing to apply officially for non-profit status. Council members complained that Snyder's group received $360,000 a year in free utilities for which the city could not be reimbursed because of the shelter's refusal to seek official status. Tax-exempt status limits the ability of an organization to engage in political activity. Snyder had been known for his political activism and he had been highly critical of the city's management of its homeless program.

DOC.HEAD: Television Shows Terrorist with Hungarian Agents
DOC.TEXT: State television broadcast footage of a purported 1980 meeting between an international terrorist and agents of the old Communist regime, bolstering claims the ex-rulers let terrorists use Hungary as a base. A former Communist official interviewed on the same program claimed the Communists had tried to oust Carlos as soon as they discovered he was operating in the country. The footage purportedly showed agents of the old regime trying to persuade the international terrorist Carlos to leave Hungary. The nation's Communist Party disbanded in October. However, it appeared to back up allegations made three weeks ago that Hungary's former Communist leaders had allowed Carlos to use the country, at least for a time, as a base for terrorist attacks. The report did not indicate how long Carlos, also known as ``The Jackal,'' allegedly stayed in Hungary. Carlos, a Moscow University graduate, began his life as a terrorist in 1973 and topped Interpol's most-wanted list by 1975. In December of that year, he allegedly organized an attack in Vienna on OPEC oil ministers in which three people were killed. Carlos remains at large. State television said the meeting shown in the film took place in 1980 in an office of the Interior Ministry's Department for the Supervision of Foreigners and was filmed without Carlos's knowledge. There was no indication of how the film was obtained. Interior Minister Balazs Horvath said on June 27 that he had instructed the chief prosecutor to investigate former Communist Party officials who allegedly provided shelter and training grounds for Carlos, whose real name is Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, and his terrorist group. The man identified as Carlos in the film spoke fluent but accented English. The two Hungarian agents spoke Hungarian among themselves and English to Carlos. The conversation was poorly recorded and difficult to make out at times, so the film was subtitled. One agent told Carlos that he ``must liquidate your base of operations here, must stop using Hungary from where to direct your group because there is danger. Your operations may be compromised. ``Also, if you were to continue, the interests of the Hungarian People's Republic may be jeopardized if you are associated with us.'' ``You can travel through Hungary or even stay for brief periods,'' the Hungarian official told Carlos, trying to mollify him. Andras Petresevics, one of the agents, said in an interview on the program that the terrorist accused him of being an ``imperialist agent'' and of acting without the knowledge of his superiors to get him to leave. The former Communist chief of counterintelligence, Miklos Redei, also was interviewed in the program. Redei, who also met Carlos, said: ``He gave the impression of being paranoid, afraid _ but he was not dumb.'' Horvath, speaking about the case last month, said recently discovered documents implicated the late Communist Party leader, Janos Kadar; former Interior Minister Andras Benkei; former President Karoly Nemeth; and Antal Gyenes, former head of the Communist Party's foreign relations department. One of the documents produced by Horvath was a letter allegedly written to Kadar by Carlos in 1980, the same year the terrorist apparently left Hungry. ``From our base in Hungary, we have developed our international ties, getting in contact with the revolutions of every nation without any hindrance on the part of the Hungarian authorities,'' the letter purportedly said. Benkei, Nemeth and Gyenes have denied any role in sheltering terrorists. Redei asserted that a small group of terrorists led by Carlos ``did not come here at the invitation of any Hungarian official. We tried to keep tabs on them after their arrival.'' Redei denied Carlos was provided with any training facilities in Hungary. He said fear of the terrorist kept Hungarian authorities from acting against him. ``We ... knew that if we do anything to him, his group would take revenge.''

DOC.HEAD: Stalin-Era Issues Loom as Obstacles to Gorbachev Aid Package
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: From the sugar fields of Cuba to the shores of the Kurile islands, the ghost of Josef Stalin is haunting Mikhail Gorbachev's effort to win economic aid from the West. With Gorbachev's survival at stake, Western nations are flirting with a $15 billion economic aid package to Moscow _ an issue that is likely to dominate the economic summit of industrialized nations that begins here on Monday. Bush received a recent message from Gorbachev and it was learned Saturday that the Soviet leader made his case for U.S. assistance. It was virtually the same request that Gorbachev conveyed within the last two weeks to leaders of West Germany and France. West Germany, France and Italy are eager to proceed, but Gorbachev may have to reverse decades-old Soviet policy before the United States and Japan will go along. No one is expecting a consensus from this summit. The sticking points for the United States: Soviet assistance to Cuba, and modernization of the Red Army. For Japan: four Kurile islands seized by Stalin after World War II. After ridiculing the notion earlier in the year, President Bush seems to be slowly setting the stage for direct American aid to Moscow. But it isn't going to happen now, he indicated on Friday. ``I have some big problems with that one, and I think the American people do, too,'' President Bush told reporters after the NATO summit in London. He said commercial trade credits might be possible, but that the United States will not provide direct aid so long as the Soviet Union sends $5 billion a year to prop up the Cuban economy. Perhaps more importantly, Bush also urged Gorbachev to scale back the percentage of Soviet spending devoted to the military. Secretary of State James A. Baker III says Moscow has been spending between 18 and 25 percent of its economy ``on military expansion, which in the past has been hostile to the United States.'' Baker also said, ``We really ought to see some progress toward economic reforms'' before sending American taxpayer funds to Moscow. ``We ought to have some faith that the money will be well spent,'' he told CNN. One obstacle dates back past Stalin to the Czarist days. It is a legal restriction on credit to the Soviet Union based on pre-revolutionary debt of several hundred million dollars. On Cuba, Bush is stating an American political reality: The United States isn't going to subsidize Moscow so that Moscow can subsidize Cuba. Soviet economic aid to Cuba is estimated by U.S. officials at more than $4 billion a year, mostly in the form of subsidies for Cuban exports such as sugar. Cuba receives an additional $1.5 billion in military aid, according to U.S. figures. Aid-to-Cuba is already the subject of heated debate in Moscow where some argue that it would be wrong to turn on an ally under threat from the United States. Others say the Kremlin cannot justify a large-scale aid program at a time of economic decline at home. Japan is joining Bush in using the economic aid question as a wedge to reverse long-held Soviet policies. The Japanese are keeping their prodigious wallets zipped pending the outcome of a peace treaty that involves the Kurile chain of islands. In an interview shortly before leaving for Houston, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said it was ``Soviet expansionism at the end of World War II'' that prompted Stalin to seize four of the Kurile islands from Japan. He told The New York Times that economic aid to Gorbachev ``will not be possible'' until the northern territories conflict is resolved. Despite warming relations between Japan and the Soviet Union, a resolution will be none too simple, since the islands _ Etorofu, Kunashira, Shikotan and Habomai _ are not the only or even the most prominent territories seized by Stalin. While Japan is playing hardball on aid to Moscow, Kaifu also is carrying the torch for resumption of Western aid to China. It's possible Japan will lift its sanctions against China even if the other summit nations do not. Bush allowed as much on Saturday, saying, ``Sometimes there are interests that predominate.'' Japan sees China as a huge and natural market and is anxious to proceed with a $5 billion aid package. West Germany's effort to win aid for Moscow also seems to have a self-serving edge. The Communist Party daily Pravda said in a recent commentary that Bonn was trying to ``grease'' the way for Soviet approval of the key tenets of German unification. Despite his best efforts, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl says the issue may not come to a head until the end of the year. ``We are not under time pressure,'' he told reporters in London on Friday. Not under time pressure? Gorbachev said last week that if the Soviet economy isn't awakening within two years, he'll give way. With the ghost of Stalin still complicating international affairs, no one in the West is eager for that to happen.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Jonathan Wolman is Washington bureau chief for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Klan Denounces Summit During Rally in Houston
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS pvs 7th graf to add AP photographer's arrest
DOC.TEXT: About 250 demonstrators Saturday jeered more than 100 Ku Klux Klan members as they marched outside Rice University, where the International Economic Summit will begin Monday. Police made a few arrests but there was no serious trouble at the two-hour protest. Charles Lee, the Texas KKK grand dragon, led Klansmen in chanting, ``No Economic Summit,'' and ``Bush should not negotiate with foreign countries.'' The Klansmen arrived in school buses, carrying banners saying, ``Stop Colored Immigration,'' and began their rally with a prayer by a minister from the Aryan Nation Church. Demonstrators interrupted the Klan's activities with chants. As the rally winded down, one protestor, Travis Morales, who heads the Revolutionary Communist Party, was arrested along with two other anti-Klan demonstrators as they burned an American flag, police said. KTBC-TV cameraman Andrew Sowder of Austin and Associated Press photographer Greg Gibson were arrested for crossing the police line. Police later released the two after ticketing them for the misdemeanor. About 15 Klan supporters calling themselves ``skinheads'' marched in front of angry demonstrators before the Klan arrived. The anti-Klan contingent threw dog food at the skinheads, shouting, ``Dog food for the dogs.'' Members of the AIDS-advocacy group ACT UP, members of Cure AIDS Now, Students And Youth Against Racism and the All Peoples' Congress taunted the Klansmen. Hundreds of police officers wore 50-pound flak jackets and riot helmets in sweltering 90-degree heat while standing between Klansmen and demonstrators. Earlier, on the steps of Houston's city hall, a group calling itself Racial Acceptance, Class Equality, or RACE, sang songs and spoke out against racism to drown the messages of the Klan rally. ``The KKK's rally is irrelevant,'' said Jim Greenwood, a Houston city council member who spoke in support of RACE. ``The KKK has nothing to do with anything real in Houston today.'' About 50 people attended the rally held by RACE, which was founded last year as a voice for white people against racism, but now includes members from various ethnic backgrounds. It was the first public demonstration by the group, RACE president Sue Lloyd said. ``We want to stress to the world that Houston is a diverse, interesting place and while we are not perfect, we are committed to racial harmony,'' she said. Across the street, more than 400 Vietnamese from across the country carried signs and chanted in support for human rights in their native land. Some of the 30 banners painted in the red and yellow of the Vietnamese flag included slogans like ``Freedom For Vietnam,'' and ``Don't Support the Hanoi Regime.'' Hang Nguyen Diep, an organizer of the rally, said the Vietnamese were attempting to gather support from the world leaders attending the summit.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Shift Continents As Summitry Moves to Economic Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Editing to tighten. Note the pvs ld should have been a 3rd Ld.
DOC.TEXT: Western leaders, gathering for back-to-back summits, shifted continents Saturday to take up a series of tough economic issues and mull the encouraging reaction from Moscow to changes in the NATO military alliance. President Bush welcomed his guests in the sweltering heat of his adopted hometown and met over a pre-summit lunch with Toshiki Kaifu, the prime minister of Japan. Their discussions touched on several of the most difficult issues that would arise Monday when the formal summit meetings begin: aid to Moscow, loans to China and trade among the allies themselves. Bush hinted that he wouldn't try to block Kaifu's intention to resume economic aid to China. The prospering allies were trying to map a coordinated strategy to deal with the breakup of the communist bloc. The 16th annual economic summit meeting is the first held in America since a gathering in Williamsburg, Va. in 1983. A decision on sending aid to Moscow was not expected to emerge this week, but the climate was growing more hospitable and Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said of the summit leaders: ``There are a lot of things they can consider short of direct aid.'' Bush told Kaifu, according to Fitzwater, ``that he was very pleased with the reaction of the Soviet Union to the NATO summit. We have read the reports of comments by President Gorbachev as well as Foreign Minister (Eduard) Shevardnadze and we are very pleased that they believe that the NATO summit has been productive and helpful.'' Fitzwater disclosed that Bush sent Mikhail Gorbachev a cable Friday from Air Force One giving Bush's ``personal reflections'' on the NATO summit and describing ``the changing nature of the (military) alliance.'' Previously, Gorbachev wrote Bush to make his case for U.S. economic aid. U.S. sources said the message was much the same as one Gorbachev advanced recently to the leaders of West Germany and France. The Bush-Kaifu meeting also touched on American domestic policies with the Japanese leader praising Bush for new-found willingness to consider tax increases in order to reduce America's budget deficit, a Japanese official said. ``We believe the statement issued by President Bush on June 26 was very courageous,'' Taizo Watanabe, spokesman for the Japanese finance ministry, told reporters. The federal budget deficits have long been a sore point with other summit countries, who contend that excessive American borrowing needs have driven up worldwide interest rates. In addition to the United States and Japan, the other countries at the economic summit are West Germany, Britian, France, Italy and Canada. The world leaders were not spending all of their time discussing serious subjects. Bush was treating the summit leaders to a country-style barbecue, rodeo and performance by the Grand Ole Opry on Sunday. The city of Houston, anxious to show the world that it had rebounded after being flattened by the oil bust of 1982, raised $10 million in donations and turned out an army of volunteers to assist visiting dignitaries and reporters. Last year's economic summit was held in Paris as part of the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution. While Houston boosters conceded that the Houston summit would not top that affair, they did try their best _ providing a Texas-syle welcome for each leader. Kaifu, the first to arrive, was greeted by a group of schoolchildren singing ``Deep in the Heart of Texas'' _ in Japanese. With temperatures in the 90s and oppressive humidity, Kaifu and the other leaders had no trouble knowing they had arrived in Houston. Before the start of his meeting with Kaifu, Bush was asked whether he planned to pressure the Japanese leader to drop his push to resume development loans to China. This assistance was put on hold by agreement of the summit countries last year in Paris in response to the brutal crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in Tiananmen Square. Bush indicated that the summit countries are likely to abandon their united front, providing Japan the opportunity to pursue its own lending policy. Japan, Bush said, ``is a sovereign nation. They can make up their own minds on a lot of questions.'' The go-it-separately approach was also likely to prevail on the contentious question over whether to provide direct economic aid to the Soviet Union. West Germany has already announced it will provide $3.1 billion in loans and economic assistance. West Germany, France and Italy have been pushing the allies to endorse a $15 billion economic aid package to bail out the floundering Soviet economy. But the United States and Britain opposed providing direct economic aid until the Soviets made a bolder move toward a free-market economy and stopped siphoning large amounts of its resources into the military and support for Cuba. Japan has its own special problem with Soviet aid, contending Japanese assistance would be impossible until Moscow has settled a 45-year-old territorial dispute over four islands north of Japan that have been occupied by the Soviet Union since World War II. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Saturday that the summit, scheduled to run from Monday through Wednesday, was likely to conclude without a common position on Soviet aid. Baker for the first time Saturday discussed publicly a new U.S. proposal to establish a multibillion-dollar international aid program for Latin America. While details of the plan are sketchy, it would be modeled after the economic aid package being offered to emerging democracies in Eastern Europe with the assistance coming from the same Group of 24 nations who are providing aid to Eastern Europe. The Latin American aid would be another effort by the Bush administration to reassure new democratic governments in this hemisphere that they will not be overlooked in the rush to help Eastern Europe. The United States received a warning Saturday from an official of the 12-nation European Community that its heavy lobbying on elimination of farm subsidies could be counterproductive. The United States is in a battle with European countries over a U.S. proposal to phase out expensive farm subsidies over the next decade. Europeans contend that the request could cost the jobs of between 2 million and 3 million less-efficient European farmers. Bush has made resolution of the farm dispute a top priority for the Houston summit, believing that agreement in this area is crucial to the successful conclusion of 97-nation effort to overhaul the entire world trading system. Those talks, known as the Uruguay Round, are scheduled to conclude in December.

DOC.HEAD: White House: Bush Won't Stand In Way of Japanese Aid To China
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts 3 grafs on Japan comments after graf 2; editing to conform throughout and update with Bush and Kaifu attending musical
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will not object if Japan resumes aid to China despite continued U.S. economic sanctions in reprisal for Beijing's crushing of the pro-democracy revolt, the White House said Saturday. President Bush was not prepared to enter a multinational aid-to-China agreement but was ``willing to discuss the matter,'' press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. He said Bush wanted to hear Japan's explanation of why it plans a $5.2 billion loan package to its giant neighbor. A Japanese spokesman said Bush did not react negatively when Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu raised that matter during their meeting Saturday. Japan already is doing ``preparatory work'' on the loan it suspended after China's crackdown on the pro-democracy movement last year, Japanese foreign ministry press secretary Taizo Watanabe said Saturday. Contrary to earlier reports, he said ``it is not on our mind'' to push for other summit countries to similarly aid China. Bush, hosting the summit of wealthy industrialized nations beginning here Monday, told reporters that Japan is a ``sovereign nation'' that can make up its own mind ``on a lot of questions.'' He was replying to a reporter's question on whether he would urge Kaifu to refrain from resuming aid to China. ``They work very cooperatively with the United States, but sometimes they have interests that predominate,'' Bush said before going to his meeting and luncheon with Kaifu.
