Most non-communist nations imposed sanctions on Beijing after the brutal crackdown in Tiananmen Square last year against hundreds of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators. However, Bush has backed away from a totally hard line on the China question, sending high level emissaries to begin opening the way to eventual renewed relations, easing some parts of the sanctions, and stating that he does not believe such an important geopolitical giant should be isolated. Later, Fitzwater was asked about whether Bush would try to dissuade Kaifu from going ahead with renewed aid to China. He replied: ``No. We'll listen to their discussion and see what their interests are.'' Asked specifically whether Bush objected to other countries resuming aid to China, he said, ``We're willing to discuss it. That's what this summit is all about.'' As to why Bush wouldn't pressure Japan or other countries to hold firm against China, given the administration's official position that China must show progress on human rights and political freedom, Fitzwater told reporters: ``We do have concerns about multilateral lending in China. On the other hand, various countries have other interests that are outside the multilateral area. We're willing to talk about that. ... We are not looking to change our position, but we're willing to discuss the matter. We are concerned about China and not isolating that country, but I don't anticipate any change.'' Meanwhile, the Chinese Communist Party chief said the leaders of the seven industrialized powers should avoid meddling in China's internal affairs at their annual economic summit. Jiang Zemin said the Group of Seven should ``confine themselves to discussion of economic and other issues among themselves,'' the official Xinhua News Agency said in a report Saturday that it said paraphrased his remarks. Regardless of the reaction of other summit participants, officials have indicated Japan likely would go ahead with its own loan plan to Beijing. At last year's summit in France, the participants agreed on sanctions including a ban on high-level contacts with Chinese officials and a freeze on development loans. Japan has been China's main source of credit and had planned $5.2 billion in a five-year program of loans. Now, Kaifu and other Japanese government officials say, it's time to open the credit window again to avoid isolating China or contributing to economic unrest there. Bush said he had a ``wide array'' of issues to discuss with Kaifu. The included economic and trade issues, and the ongoing Uruguay Round of trade talks, as well as environmental and agricultural issues. The two countries concluded this year an agreement on thorny trade talks designed to correct the massive U.S. trade deficit with Japan. The idea would be to reform institutional economic practices that make it harder for U.S. interests to compete in Japan. Bush and his wife Barbara later took Kaifu to a Houston production of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ``Carousel.'' The musical was added to Bush's summit-week activities after members of the city's host committee insisted that the cultural side of the city be highlighted. The centerpiece social activity before this week's addition of the Carousel show at the Wortham Theater Center had been the Sunday nights rodeo, barbecue and Grand Ole Opry performance. Bush's attendance at the Houston Grand Opera performance of Carousel ``shows that Houston is a city of wide cultural diversity,'' said Peter Roussel, spokesman for the Houston Host Committee. The performance was to have closed last week, but was extended with three performances this weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Former Duvalierist Leader Returns to Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The former head of a dreaded paramilitary force under the deposed Duvalier regime returned to the country from voluntary exile Saturday, a radio report said. The announcement heightened the fears of some presidential candidates that the ex-minister of defense and the interior, Roger Lafontant, intends to disrupt upcoming elections. Lafontant arrived on a regularly scheduled flight from the Dominican Republic, according to Radio Haiti-Inter. He had been living in exile there since 1986. Government prosecutor Bayard Vincent said in an interview with the independent radio station that police were ordered to arrest Lafontant. But airport authorities countermanded the order, said Defense and Interior Minister Joseph Maxi. He said it was unconstitutional to deport a Haitian citizen. ``Lafontant's return is part of a concerted Duvalierist offensive to spoil the electoral process and seize the reins of power,'' said presidential candidate Sylvio Claude, leader of the Haitian Christian Democrat Party. In a telephone interview with independent Radio-Antilles, Lafontant said his re-entry was legal and denied he had returned to interfere with the electoral process. ``There is no place like home,'' he said. Elections are tentatively set for Nov. 4. There has been an upsurge in political violence in this Caribbean country since the Independent Electoral Council was established May 2 to prepare for free elections. The last elections, held on Nov. 29, 1987, failed when army-supported squads shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters. If successful, the new elections would be the first free balloting since Haiti won independence from France in 1804. Lafontant led a dreaded paramilitary group called the Tonton Macoutes. He was considered the power behind ruler Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier before the dictator's ouster in February 1986. On Friday, the Independent Electoral Council denounced the re-emergence in public the day before of ex-Brig. Gen. Williams Regala, who allegedly masterminded the 1987 voter massacre when he was defense and interior minister. The Electoral Council called Regala's return a grave danger to the electoral process. Human-rights groups, popular organizations, labor unions and political parties also expressed worry. Regala was seen on television Friday at the funeral of former Lt. Col. Paul Rosny Casimir, who was shot to death by unknown assailants June 28. Regala was retired from the army in 1988 and had lived in Haiti and the United States since then. Haiti is ruled by a caretaker government led by former judge Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, who shares power with the 19-member Council of State. She took over in March after a popular uprising toppled Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Newspaper Assails N.Y. State Ruling
DOC.TEXT: The official Vatican newspaper Saturday assailed a ``right-to-die'' bill passed by the New York state legislature this month. L'Osservatore Romano, in a front-page editorial, said the Catholic Church ``denounces the alliance that man makes today with death.'' It called such laws ``simple acts of tragic stupidity.'' The newspaper did not specifically mention New York but clearly alluded to the legislation approved earlier this month in Albany. The bill allows the sick to appoint proxies to make health-care decisions for them when they are no longer able to do so. The ruling opens the possibility of a proxy deciding that an incapacitated person should be allowed to die. The legislation was passed after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that a Missouri woman in an irreversible coma could not be disconnected from life-support equipment because it was unclear what her wishes would have been. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, a Roman Catholic, has not yet signed the bill into law but is expected to do so. ``Abortion and euthanasia express the same idea: that human life belongs exclusively to man and that everyone is the exclusive owner of his life,'' the editorial said. The newspaper said only God had the right to terminate life. ``If even the people who are asked to wisely govern the human community have fallen into such blackness as to promulgate such anti-human laws, the culture and mentality of the end of the century have lost their sense of authentic values,'' the editorial said. In a last-minute concession aimed at avoiding the active opposition of New York state's Roman Catholic bishops, legislators said private hospitals could refuse, for moral or religious reasons, to carry out a proxy order to end life support. The hospital would, however, have to inform the patient upon admission that it would not honor a proxy's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Search for Flooding Victims Ends in Shadyside, Ohio, Area
DOC.TEXT: The search for any remaining victims of last month's flooding has ended with the death count at 26, officials said Saturday. ``We got together this morning to discuss the ramifications of suspending the search and whether everything had been done. We decided it was time to end it,'' said Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator. ``I'm satisfied that everything that could have been done was done.'' Funerals for the last two victims, whose bodies were found Thursday, were held Saturday, Vogt said. Seven names remained on the list of those believed missing since the June 14 flood on the outskirts of this eastern Ohio village, but Vogt said officials now believe those people were not in the area at the time. Floodwaters and debris hurtled down Wegee and Pipe creeks the night of the flood, leaving hundreds of people homeless. The cleanup around the creeks will continue, Vogt said. Several miles along both creeks has yet to been cleared of debris.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Found Guilty in Gambling Conspiracy Case
DOC.TEXT: A prominent state legislator has been convicted of conspiracy for inducing a former prison mate to invest in an illegal bingo operation, then fleecing him of half the money. A 12-member jury convicted state Rep. Tommy Burnett on Friday of nine conspiracy counts that carry a possible prison term of 45 years.No sentencing date was set by U.S. District Judge Thomas A. Higgins. Two co-defendants, Columbia businessman E.E. Shutt and Knoxville bingo operator Virginia Hurst, were convicted on charges of conspiracy and operating a gambling enterprise. Burnett faces trial Sept. 11 on a related perjury charge. The convictions were the first to result from a joint federal-state corruption probe that has produced indictments against 43 people, including a former state representative, an election commissioner, a bingo regulator and various bingo operators. The investigation has centered on misuse of profits from bingo, which had been permitted in the state only to benefit charities, and was made illegal altogether in 1989, partly as a result of the investigation. While Burnett was serving 10 months of a federal prison sentence in 1984, the indictment charged, he convinced fellow inmate Joseph Cappello, of Naples, Fla., to invest $48,000 in the operation of a Crossville bingo home. Burnett, Hurst and Shutt created the Columbia Scholarship Fund as a non-profit charter to run the bingo hall in 1985, after Burnett left prison. But the hall operated only briefly, and Burnett made private use of about half of Cappello's investment, according to testimony. Burnett, the once-powerful majority leader in the state House of Representatives, apparently will lose his seat as a result of the conviction. Felons are barred from the office. The 10-term legislator was re-elected in 1984 from the federal prison camp in Alabama, where he was sent for failing to file timely income tax returns. Burnett earned a reputation early in his career as a powerful speaker and champion of sometimes unpopular causes: He once presented an eloquent attack on Tennessee's death penalty. After the tax conviction, which plea bargaining reduced to a misdemeanor, Burnett surrendered the party leadership and became a mediator, helping forge compromise on such issues as education reform. ``All good things must come to an end and perhaps this is the end of it, I don't know,'' Burnett said after the conviction Friday. Burnett said he would not seek re-election but that he hadn't decided whether he would resign. He had previously filed for re-election and has two opponents in the August primary. ``I wish I'd never taken a look at bingo, obviously,'' Burnett said. ``Hindsight is 20-20.''

DOC.HEAD: Insurer Cites Blood Fraud in Refusing to pay AIDS Claim
DOC.TEXT: An insurance company is refusing to pay a $2 million life insurance claim to the survivor of an AIDS victim, saying the victim used someone else's blood to qualify for coverage. Lawyers for Massachusetts General Life Insurance Co. want a federal judge in Fort Lauderdale to throw out the $2 million claim by Anthony C. Fioretti, who died of AIDS on Feb. 28, 1989, in Broward County. Fioretti, 40, tested positive for the HIV virus and was rejected by another insurance company less than a month before virus-free blood was used in his application to Massachusetts General, the lawyers say. ``The person submitting blood for HIV testing on (June 29, 1987) was not in fact Fioretti, but represented himself and his blood sample to be that of Fioretti,'' the suit says. Fioretti also used the name ``Finetti'' on the application to make it more difficult for insurance investigators to discover through national computer records he had previously tested positive for AIDS, the suit says. Despite the proliferation of AIDS cases nationwide, the Massachusetts General lawsuit is one of only a handful of cases filed in federal court involving AIDS victims accused of trying to enrich survivors through fraudulent insurance claims, according to a report in Saturday's Sun-Sentinel of Fort Lauderdale. Fioretti, a former New York City florist, had been paying $30,365 per year in premiums to maintain his $2 million insurance coverage since July 1987. The sole beneficiary was listed as Fioretti's brother, Vincent, of Plantation, who has an unlisted phone number and could not be located for comment. Last month, Fort Lauderdale attorney Steven Fine filed suit on behalf of Vincent Fioretti to force Massachusetts General to pay the $2 million claim. Calls to Fine's office went unanswered Saturday. Mark F. Hughes Jr., an attorney for Massachusetts General in Newark, N.J., said the company _ in accordance with insurance laws _ has offered to refund Fioretti's premium payments, with interest, to his brother. The offer was rejected, he said. Hughes said the insurance company has filed a countersuit in federal court in New York City, where the blood tests were performed, asking the court to dismiss Fioretti's claim. ``How do we know that an imposter submitted the blood?,'' Hughes asked rhetorically. ``We know beyond a shadow of a doubt that Fioretti died of AIDS. We know that AIDS does not kill you immediately so he had to have had it before his death. And we know that in January 1987 his blood tested positive for HIV.'' If the company knew he had the AIDS virus, Massachusetts General would have never issued the policy, he said. The suit argues that because of alleged fraudulent acts by Fioretti, his application was void before it was accepted.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Circus Files For U.S. Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet circus stranded outside Atlanta since May has filed for protection from its creditors under U.S. bankruptcy laws. The Great Circus Bim Bom filed for Chapter 11 protection Friday in Bankruptcy Court in Atlanta, said lawyer Richard Keck, who is donating his services. The circus, named for two turn-of-the-century Russian clowns, has been stranded in Marietta, northwest of Atlanta, when its planned two-year goodwill tour of the United States was canceled after investors withdrew support. Circus members have been forced to live on charity, unable to restart their tour because they can't pay the companies holding their performing animals, costumes and equipment. They blame a Florida company, International Showbusiness Inc., for improperly managing their tour. The bankruptcy action would consolidate claims and lawsuits against the circus so it can straighten out its finances, Keck said. Two lawsuits have been filed against the circus in New York and Georgia by the equipment companies, he said. ``Instead of having to defend it on a lot of battlefronts, this consolidates it down to one,'' Keck said. ``The situation right now is very optimistic for us,'' said circus managing director Yuri Turkin. About 70 circus members remain in the Atlanta area. Some 30 others stayed with International Showbusiness and traveled to West Virginia to look for work.

DOC.HEAD: United States Would Consider Role for Afghan Leader
DOC.TEXT: The United States is willing to consider a role for Afghanistan's Soviet-backed leader in a settlement to end the nation's 10-year-old war, diplomatic sources said Saturday. Diplomatic formulas recently drafted by Washington could provide the United States and the Soviet Union with a face-saving exit from war between Moslem rebels and the Afghan government, the sources said. The options include what a year ago would have been out of the question for the United States _ allowing President Najibullah to remain in office while transferring control of the armed forces, the intelligence agencies and the state-run media to a broad-based interim council, the sources said. The options also include internationally supervised elections and a cutoff of weapons supplied by the United States to the rebels and by the Soviet Union to the government in Kabul. The proposed compromise comes as the Soviet Union is tiring of its costly involvement in Afghanistan and the United States becoming increasingly frustrated by internal bickering that has sapped the Moslem resistance of its political and military cohesion. ``We believe the Soviets are seriously interested in reaching a political solution. We certainly are. So there are a lot of forces moving, and we have made a lot of progress,'' said a senior U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Although the mechanics have yet to be worked out, the emergence of independent Afghan groups could provide the springboard for an interim council. The council would most likely include Najibullah's ruling Hezb-e-Watan, or Party of the Homeland, which until last month had been known for a quarter century as the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. The major obstacle to a settlement has been Najibullah, the 44-year-old ruler and former head of the feared Afghan secret police who has been trying to distance himself and his party from the Communist past. Until recently, Washington had insisted that Najibullah and ``less than a planeload'' of people had to leave. But Najibullah has proven a formidable politician and refused to step aside. Moscow has said it cannot remove him. ``He can stay and sign the checks. He can call himself by whatever title he wishes. He can run in an election and if he wins, he can return to power,'' said one Western diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He just can't have the advantages of incumbency _ control of the military, the police and the media _ before or during an election, because he would probably cheat,'' the diplomat said. Rebel leaders said thay have been informed of the U.S. proposal. ``If Najib stays as president _ if only in title _ then symbolically and psychologically he has won,'' said one guerrilla leader, also speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But if the Soviets and the Americans come to any agreement, then it's settled.'' When the last Soviet soldiers left Afghanistan in February 1989 after nine years of direct involvement, Western leaders confidently predicted that the government would quickly fall and the resistance would take command. However, neither side has achieved any significant military victory. Government troops control the cities, and the guerrillas remain in control of the countryside.

DOC.HEAD: Three Great Opera Tenors Declare Ego Timeout for Soccer, Charity
DOC.TEXT: Three of the greatest tenors in opera _ Luciano Pavarotti Placido Domingo and Jose Carreras _ proved they are also good sports Saturday by taking the stage together to sing during World Cup soccer festivities. The booming voices of the trio _ perhaps the world's most famous tenors _ echoed amid the brick ruins of Rome's Baths of Caracalla on the eve of World Cup championship. Argentina and West Germany will play the final match Sunday in Rome. A golden full moon rose as the charity concert was put on hold until the last kick in Saturday evening's consolation match between Italy and England. Italy won, helping the great Italian tenor Pavarotti get keyed up for singing. ``Vincero, vincero, vincero,'' (I shall win), sang Pavarotti, the final line of Nessun Dorma from ``Turandot,'' ending his last solo. Any rivalries among the tenors, however, were declared out-of-bounds for the evening. To avoid bruising egos, they came on the stage in alphabetical order and took turns singing opera arias. They then joined together at the end for a 20-minute medly of popular songs, including ``Maria'' from ``West Side Story,'' ``Memory'' from the musical ``Cats,'' ``La Vie en Rose'' and ``O Sole Mio.'' The trio then broke into a second round of the same medley for an encore. ``Now we're warmed up,'' joked Domingo. However, the singers and maestro Zubin Mehta, who led the two orchestras, had been basking all evening in mutual admiration and the cheers of the audience. When the concert ended, Mehta stepped off the podium to embrace Carreras and Domingo together. Then he gave Pavarotti a bear hug. The concert organizers had promised that air traffic from nearby Leonardo da Vinci Airport would be diverted from above the 1,800-year-old baths, which were built by Emperor Marcus Aurelius Antoninus. But Carreras had just begun the first aria _ Francesco Cilea's ``Lamento di Federico'' _ when the first jet roared overhead. When another jet gave him some competition, Carreras looked up and blew it a kiss. Pavarotti said he was donating his share of proceeds to several charities to fight diseases. Domingo, who grew up in Mexico, will give his share to Mexican villages devastated in an 1985 earthquake. Carreras, who was cured of leukemia, will donate his proceeds toward work on that disease. With only 6,000 seats, opera lovers vied with VIPs for tickets. The Italian news agency AGI reported Queen Beatrice of the Netherlands and Sofia of Spain, Carreras' home country, were among the lucky ones. Former Premier Giovanni Spadolini, now Senate president, reportedly left in a huff because he didn't like his third-row seat. A helicopter carried Rome Mayor Franco Carraro to the capital from Bari, where he had watched the Italy-England match with Premier Giulio Andreotti. Also attending were Henry Kissinger, the former U.S. secretary of state; and U.S. Ambassador to Italy Peter Secchia.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Die in New Guinea Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A domestic flight with 12 people aboard crashed into a mountain on this South Pacific island nation, killing eight people, officials said Saturday. Officials for Douglas Airways said the plane was on a regular flight from Port Moresby to Woitape when it crashed Thursday. They said details of the accident were not released until the crash site was found Saturday morning. Heavy rains in the area had hampered search efforts, they said. A man, two women and a child who survived the crash were found Saturday by rescuers dropped from a helicopter, said Leith Anderson, director of the National Disaster Center. Officials did not release a list of the dead. No other details on the crash or the type of aircraft involved were available.

DOC.HEAD: Two Lutheran Congregations On Trial Over Gay Ordinations
DOC.TEXT: Two Lutheran pastors and their congregations went on trial before an ecclesiastical panel Saturday for defying church rules and ordaining a gay man and a lesbian couple. The hearing, the first of its kind for the fledgling Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, could result in the expulsion of the local churches from the 5.3 million-member denomination. But the Rev. John Frykman of First United Lutheran Church and the Rev. James DeLange of St. Francis Lutheran Church say they and their flocks are willing to be ousted to prove their support of the civil and religious rights of homosexuals. ``Gays and lesbians are the largest oppressed minority in this country,'' Frykman said. ``The church for too long has betrayed gay and lesbian people and forced them to live as alienated people.'' The three-day hearing before a 14-member committee marks the first time the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America has sought to discipline a pastor or congregation, church officials said. The church was formed in a merger of three major Lutheran groups in January 1988. The panel on Monday may impose a penalty ranging from censure to suspension to expulsion. ``That is a very painful kind of possibility to contemplate,'' said Sierra Pacific Synod Bishop Lyle Miller, who heads the church in Northern California. The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, like most other mainstream churches, forbids the ordination of sexually active gay men and lesbians. ``We have standards for the ordained, and one of them is that sexual activity is only to be practiced within the bonds of marriage,'' said Charles Ruthroff, Miller's assistant. Miller filed the charges against St. Francis and First United after Jeff Johnson, Ruth Frost and Phyllis Zillhart were anointed ``messengers of Jesus Christ'' and installed as assistant pastors in January. The three, who were grand marshals in last month's Gay and Lesbian Freedom Day Parade, had refused to take a church vow of celibacy. Johnson, 28, is assistant pastor of United Lutheran, a predominantly heterosexual congregation of about 100 in the city's Richmond district. Frost, 42, and Zillhart, 32, a couple for five years, are at St. Francis, a largely gay congregation in the Castro district. At a news conference Friday, the two pastors and their assistants said they in turn would put the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America on trial for violating its own promise to be ``inclusive,'' to work for social justice and fight oppression. Frykman, recalling how his church was founded in the 16th century when Martin Luther broke away from the Roman Catholic Church, accused denomination leaders of ``acting like Roman bishops'' in attempting to control ordinations. DeLange said other Lutheran churches here have adopted a resolution of support but that his congregation and Frykman's did not intend to break away from the church. ``We are not trying to lead an exodus,'' he said. ``We hope ... the disciplinary committee will dismiss charges. But we are prepared to suffer the consequences.'' Church officials, on the other hand, said the two local churches were pursing the issue the wrong way. ``We don't see this discipline process as a way to change the policies of the church,'' said Ruthroff. The Sierra Pacific Synod, he added, already has asked the national church council to re-examine the ordination of gay men and women. ``That's how the guidelines for ordinations should be changed,'' he said. The prospect of the new Lutheran church allowing the ordination of sexually active homosexuals has prompted a dozen congregations throughout the country to form a conservative ``Great Commission Network'' to monitor liberal trends in the church. ``This is a very painful process for us,'' Ruthroff said. ``Liberals push one way and conservatives push another, and everyone wants the bishop to act unilaterally when he agrees with them. We hope our church is big enough to accommodate diverse viewpoints.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Air Show Crash, 3rd Ld - Writethru, a0631,0316
DOC.HEAD: Death in Air Show Collision with Shuttle Pilot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with age of dead pilot, details on show; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A stunt plane flown by a space shuttle commander collided with another plane during a race at an air show Saturday, sending the second craft hurtling into a cornfield and killing its pilot. The victim was identified as Henry W. Jones Jr., 69, a retired fighter pilot from Newport News, Va. The plane driven by astronaut Robert L. ``Hoot'' Gibson landed safely at the New Braunfels Municipal Airport, 25 miles northeast of San Antonio. No one on the ground was injured, said city fire department spokesman Robert Reed. Jones and Gibson were aboard single-engine airplanes competing in a Formula One air race, part of an air show attended by about 4,000 people. Jones was attempting to pass Gibson when the planes collided at 5 p.m. ``The one that crashed was attempting to pass the one that did not crash as they went around a pylon,'' said Federal Aviation Administration spokesman T.C. Miller. Jones' Mingus Special plane lost a wing in the collision and tumbled through the air, breaking into several sections as it crashed, Miller said. Gibson was aboard a Cassutt plane. The ``midget planes,'' as they are known among aficionados, are specially designed for low-altitude racing. Gibson and Jones were racing at speeds of up to 200 mph in the third lap of a six-lap race that involved circling five large poles with flags on them. The death was at least the seventh at an air show in the United States since May 23. Gibson, 43, flew 56 combat missions in Vietnam and became an astronaut in 1978. He piloted an eight-day Challenger mission in 1984 and commanded the 1986 Columbia mission and the December 1988 Atlantis mission.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Surround Major Rebel Camp in Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Tamil insurgents Saturday battled government soldiers who surrounded an important rebel base in the eastern jungle, military officials said. At least 66 people were reported killed in two days of fighting. At least 39 rebels were killed in other fighting when the navy bombed their boats, the officials said. The latest killings raised to more than 2,080 the number of combatants killed in nearly a month of new fighting in Sri Lanka's north and east, where the rebels seek autonomy from the Sinhalese-dominated government. Many civilians also have died. Military officials said Saturday they had surrounded the rebel stronghold in the Karijikudiaru jungles and cut off sea and land escape routes. Scores of rebels were believed trapped in the base, which they have used as a training center, the officials said. The camp is believed to be the largest rebel base in eastern Sri Lanka. At least 62 rebels and four civilians were killed Saturday and Friday in the fighting between the Tamil Tiger rebels and government security forces, said the military officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Troop reinforcements moved in and naval gunships patrolled the coast to seal off rebel escape routes. In other fighting Friday, at least 39 Tigers were killed when the navy bombed boats carrying the rebels, the military officials said. The bodies of 11 rebels were found near the east coast town of Trincomalee and five guerrillas were killed in Batticialoa, also on the east coast, they said. They gave no details. Two rebels riding on a motorcycle were shot and killed in the eastern district of Ampara, and residents of Batticaloa found the bodies of four men in the city on Friday, the officials said. The four were believed to be civilians who were caught in crossfire, they said. The rebels have suffered heavy losses in the east. But in the north, the Tigers hold most of the territory and have surrounded military installations. The current round of fighting broke out June 11, when the rebels broke a a 13-month cease-fire. Tamil militants have been campaigning for an independent homeland since 1983, claiming their community is discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. The mainly Hindu Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Sinhalese, who are predominantly Buddhist, comprise 75 percent and dominate the military and the government. At least 13,000 people have died in the 7-year-old war.

DOC.HEAD: Ely Welcomes Home Antarctic Explorer
DOC.TEXT: Antarctic explorer Will Steger got a rousing welcome home Saturday from nearly all of the 4,289 residents of his hometown in the north woods. ``Incredible,'' was Steger's only reaction after thousands showered him with confetti and good wishes during a parade through the tiny business district. The 45-year-old explorer left Ely last July to serve as co-leader of the six-member International Trans-Antarctica Expedition, the longest unmechanized passage across the frozen continent. ``He's so modest about everything,'' said longtime Ely resident Dorothy Hutar. ``You'd think with all the attention, he'd get his nose up in the air. But he's just a regular old guy, I mean, young guy.'' Steger, perched between his parents on the back of a convertible, struggled to wave and sign autographs while holding a 3-month-old puppy. The crowd followed him to the end of the parade route, surrounding him on the steps of Ely High School. He posed for pictures and signed autographs _ on paper and on the clothes on some people's backs. Reporters, squeezing in questions between autographs, asked about future plans. ``The expedition isn't over,'' Steger said, noting that he'll begin working Monday on a book about the trip. Then comes a year of lectures. After that? Steger said he wasn't ready to make an official announcement, but plans future journeys, possibly to northern Canada. But Saturday was for celebration. ``This is a big day,'' said Mayor Frank Salerno. ``Things like this don't happen very often, not in a community this size.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bush to Let U.S. Satellites Go Up on Soviet Rockets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Zenit is cq in 7th graf
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will allow U.S. commercial satellites to be launched on Soviet rockets for the first time, The New York Times reported Sunday. An Australian commercial venture, the Cape York Space Agency, will be permitted to hire a U.S. company to run a base in Australia from which Soviet rockets will carry satellites for customers from around the world, the Times reported. The project, which could be in operation by 1995, would provide a major opportunity for the Soviet Union to expand its international space business and would increase competitive pressures on the American rocket industry, the Times said. The National Space Council, an interagency committee headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, met last week and completed a broad set of recommendations on the international launching business, the newspaper said, quoting unnamed government and industry officials. The Times said the decision to approve the Cape York project was ``among the thorniest issues involved in the council's policy review.'' A spokesman for the space council declined to comment on the report Saturday. The newspaper said the State Department intends to grant an export license to the USBI division of the United Technologies Corp. to operate the Cape York station, where Soviet Zenit rockets could be launched. The project, estimated to cost nearly $500 million, is backed by an Australian real estate development company and would not receive any Australian government funds, the newspaper said. The Soviet space agency, Glavkosmos, would supply rockets and engineers but would not own a share in the venture. The Times said Australia and the Soviet Union would have to comply with conditions laid out by the United States, including a Soviet promise to limit its overseas launching to a single site and to abide by an international agreement controlling the export of ballistic missile technologies, which have commercial and military uses. U.S. rocket manufacturers fear they will suffer unfairly in a head-to-head competition with Soviet suppliers. But, the paper said, U.S. satellite companies have warned that, if they are prevented from putting their payloads on the cheapest available rockets, they will lose business to foreign satellite makers.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Fundamentalists Clash with Militia
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian fundamentalists clashed with secular militiamen in this southern port city Saturday. Police said at least one person was killed and five wounded. A police spokesman said the two-hour clash with automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenades pitted the Moslem fundamentalists against the Nasserite Popular Organization. The fundamentalist Ansarullah faction _ Ansarullah is Arabic for ``God's partisans'' _ was formed recently in the Palestinian refugee camp of Ein El-Hilweh on the edge of Sidon. The Nasserite Popular Organization, led by Mustafa Saad, is the dominant Sunni Moslem militia in Sidon and maintains close ties with Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with regulations, said the clash broke out when Nasserite militiamen manning a checkpoint prevented five armed members of the Ansarullah faction from entering the city. The spokeman said the Palestinians opened fire and the Nasserite militiamen responded in kind, with each side sending reinforcements. He said the clash lasted for two hours. The firefight came a few days after the PLO harshly criticized Hamas, a fundamentalist organization active in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. The Ansarullah faction closely identifies with Hamas, which has been challenging the pro-PLO leadership of the 30-month Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. The Palestine Al-Thawra magazine, mouthpiece of the PLO, launched the attack against Hamas in a commentary in its latest edition. The article accused Hamas of trying to ``break away from the rules and regulations of the (Palestinian) house.'' The commentary said such attempts by Hamas ``will only serve the intrigues of the Zionist enemies and their American masters.''

DOC.HEAD: Police arrest 44 for Blocking Baltimore Clinic
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 44 anti-abortion protesters Saturday after they rushed into a Planned Parenthood clinic, sat down in the hallways and refused to leave. If was the first such action in Baltimore by Operation Rescue, said James Guest, Planned Parenthood director for Maryland. The group has blockaded abortion clinics around the country in recent years; 133 people were arrested in Philadelphia on Saturday in the second day of protests outside the Northeast Women's Clinic. There were 124 arrests at the clinic Friday. The Baltimore protesters, from the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, entered the clinic at about 8:30 a.m., said police spokesman Dennis Hill. It took about 75 police officers five hours to remove the protesters, six of whom had locked themselves together or to objects. The 38 adults face misdemeanor charges of trespassing, blocking access to a medical facility and disobeying police orders, police said. Six juveniles face similar charges under juvenile laws. Maryland Planned Parenthood Director James Guest said three employees of the center plan to file assault charges. ``One person was tackled, then they trampled over him coming in. A security guard was pushed to the ground and another person was pinned up against a wall,'' Guest said. One of the protesters, who would identify herself only as Mary, denied any assaults took place during the occupation. Guest said the scheduled abortions went on as planned after police escorted or carried the protesters out on stretchers.

DOC.HEAD: Report: West German Firms Built Iraqi Supergun Plant
DOC.TEXT: A West German conglomerate has built a steel plant in Iraq capable of constructing a giant cannon that could hurl artillery shells at Israel, a West German magazine reported Saturday. Der Spiegel, West Germany's leading news magazine, reported the conglomerate, led by the Ferrostaal AG steel firm, built a ``universally capable foundry'' near the Iraqi capital of Baghdad. Senior Ferrostaal executives said the plant would be used to manufacture more than 1,000 small and medium-caliber artillery pieces for the Iraqi army, Der Spiegel said. Experts believe the plant will ultimately be used to make a ``super cannon'' with which Iraq could fire huge artillery shells into Israel, the magazine said. Last spring, customs authorities in Britain, West Germany and other nations confiscated sections of steel tubing they claimed could be used as part of such a weapon. Almost a dozen smaller West German firms, in addition to Ferrostaal, supplied components and equipment for the Iraqi plant, Der Spiegel reported. The article on the Iraqi plant is to appear in Monday's edition of Der Spiegel, but an advance copy was obtained by The Associated Press. The magazine said it had obtained its information from West German customs officials in the city of Duesseldorf. Despite several attempts by The Associated Press, the company could not be reached by telephone for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor to Keep Title to Pennsylvania House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT that girlfriend gave birth in January, sted February.
DOC.TEXT: A doctor imprisoned for killing his wife gets to keep the house in Pennsylvania where he buried her in the basement, according to a settlement of a wrongful-death lawsuit filed on behalf of their children. Dr. John Boyle Jr. also will keep $20,000, according to the agreement. It was filed Thursday and Richland County Probate Judge Richard Christiansen said Friday that he approved it. The settlement means that the estate of murder victim Noreen Boyle gets the remainder of the assets she and the doctor accumulated. Boyle agreed to a judgment of $500,000 in response to the lawsuit filed by attorney Dane Arlen Bonecutter on behalf of the Boyles' children _ Collier, 12, and Elizabeth, 3. The courts appointed the attorney because Boyle's assets were frozen after his arrest, and the murder left it unclear who would take care of the children. Mrs. Boyle's estate can try to collect by pursuing any future income Boyle may earn, such as by selling the rights to his story to book publishers or movie producers, Bonecutter said. The judgment also settles a paternity suit against Boyle by his girlfriend, Sherri Campbell, who gave birth to a girl in January. Ms. Campbell settled for $67,500. Boyle, 47, was convicted June 29 of aggravated murder and abuse of a corpse, and was sentenced to life in prison with no possibility of parole for at least 20 years. Prosecutors alleged he suffocated his wife in their Mansfield home on Dec. 31 and buried her under the basement floor of a house he had just bought in suburban Erie, Pa., for $299,900. Investigators dug up her body on Jan. 25. Boyle planned to live in the house with his children and Ms. Campbell, according to testimony. Juvenile Court Judge Paul Christ is to decide who will gain custody of the children.

President Bush is sharing credit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev for NATO's decision to tone down its war-fighting doctrine, saying the embattled Soviet leader is entitled to declare ``I've been right'' in dealing with the West. Bush said Gorbachev can boast that the 16-nation NATO alliance agreed to overhaul its strategy in direct response to Soviet-sanctioned democratic changes in Eastern Europe. At the same time, Bush observed, ``It was the United States' draft that shaped the new direction for NATO.'' Gorbachev ``should get on the offensive'' against Soviet critics who are angry over the collapse of the Warsaw Pact and the pullback of Red Army troops, Bush suggested Friday at the conclusion of NATO's two-day summit.

Bearing the offer of a non-aggression pact and a pledge to cut German forces, NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner is heading for Moscow on the alliance's most hopeful mission yet for allaying Soviet fears about German unification and decades of East-West enmity. A day after Woerner arrives in the Soviet capital on July 14, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl will also meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The visits reflect a stepped-up drive by the Western allies to develop new ties and pacts with the Soviet Union following NATO's dramatic revamping of its longstanding military strategy at a summit which ended Friday in London. ``The London Declaration transforms our relationship with old adversaries,'' declared President Bush, who drafted the new doctrine. ``To those governments who confronted us in the Cold War, our alliance extends the hand of friendship.''

Abortion foes stepped up pressure on the Louisiana Senate to follow the House lead and override Gov. Buddy Roemer's veto of the toughest state abortion bill in the nation. The House voted 73-31 late Friday to reject Roemer's veto. It was the first time even one chamber of the Legislature had overridden a veto this century. But the outcome of the Senate vote was in doubt. Anti-abortion forces have only until midnight Monday to line up the necessary 26 votes. Sen. Allen Bares, a supporter of the bill, acknowledged to his colleagues Friday night that abortion foes do not have the necessary two-thirds majority of the 39-member Senate. The Senate voted to adjourn the session.

Federal investigators were sent to examine the wreckage of a chemical plant today to find the cause of a thunderous explosion that killed 17 workers and sent dozens of employees scrambling for safety. Two tanks that collected waste water and flammable hydrocarbons exploded at the Arco Chemical Co. plant about 15 miles east of Houston late Thursday. The blast could be heard 20 miles away. ``When I heard it, I knew what had happened,'' said employee Kathryn Cox. ``I hollered to my people, `Y'all run, run as fast as you can!' I looked back twice and then I just kept running because I knew if it went again, we'd probably get blown up.'' The explosion leveled an area the size of a city block. Five people, including two people living near the complex, suffered minor injuries.

Critical tests to ferret out the mysterious hydrogen leak that has grounded America's space shuttle fleet are starting this weekend. Rockwell International, the contractor that built the space shuttles, will test pipes and valves from space shuttle Columbia today and Sunday at the company plant in Downey, Calif. Engineers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, meanwhile, are preparing a leak test on Atlantis, a space shuttle on a launch pad. William Lenoir, NASA associate administrator for space flight, said Friday the goal of the tests is to find where a leak developed in the maze of pipes and valves used to load liquid hydrogen aboard the shuttles.

To F. Scott Fitzgerald, they were ``breathlessly aristocratic'' clubs frequented by ``an impressive melange of brilliant adventurers and well-dressed philanderers.'' To Sally Frank, Princeton University's men-only eating clubs are part of an old-boy network that discriminates against women. Fitzgerald venerated the Tiger Inn and the Ivy and Cottage clubs in the 1920 novel ``This Side of Paradise.'' Almost 60 years later, Ms. Frank sued the three organizations, seeking membership in the Ivy League school's men-only clubs. After an 11-year battle during which she was vilified by other students, Ms. Frank, a 1980 Princeton graduate, prevailed last week when the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered the clubs to open their doors to the opposite sex.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv09
For release Mon PMs, July 09, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Senators Turn Their Attention to Defense Spending
DOC.TEXT: Military spending in a post-Cold War era as well as the fate of the B-2 stealth bomber and Osprey aircraft top the agenda this week as the Senate finally begins working on a 1991 defense budget. White House and congressional negotiators still haven't agreed on how to reduce the federal budget deficit by $50 billion for fiscal 1991. And that has delayed action on the $307-billion military budget that President Bush unveiled in January. But the Senate Armed Services Committee has decided it can wait no longer. Committee members, working behind closed doors, will draw up a defense blueprint for full Senate consideration just prior to the August recess. In fact, they'll be giving senators two different budgets to mull over. Committee chairman Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said one bill will allocate $286 billion for defense _ the figure proposed by the Senate Budget Committee. The other will use Nunn's own budget range of $289 billion to $291 billion. Nunn said the process will be an ``educational effort'' that will show ``the difficulty in making the kinds of cuts'' lawmakers have called for since the collapse of the Warsaw Pact. It's a given on Capitol Hill that Bush's $307 billion proposal will be cut. The question is only by how much. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the panel, said the $286 billion budget will prove that ``the only bank from which those dollars can flow would be unacceptable cuts in personnel and maintenance accounts.'' In another break with tradition, the Senate Armed Services Committee will craft defense legislation ahead of the House Armed Services Committee. The Democratic leadership had wanted the House to complete a military budget before August. But the House is behind schedule and probably won't even start working on a bill until September, according to congressional sources who requested anonymity. The House is behind, in part, because there still isn't agreement on an overall budget figure for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. But another factor, the sources said, is the trouble committee chairman Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., has had getting House members to let go of their pet defense issues and work on drafting a bill. The major issue facing Congress is the B-2 stealth bomber, the bat-winged plane that according to the latest Congressional Budget Office report will cost $860 million a copy. Faced with increasing budget constraints and a diminished Soviet threat to the West, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has suggested buying only 75 stealth bombers, instead of 132. He also suggested buying only two of the bombers in fiscal 1991, instead of five. But the Air Force has told Congress that buying three fewer bombers would only save about $900 million of the $5.5 billion for the B-2 program. ``The sticker price is driving that decision,'' Warner said in an interview last week. In the House, sponsors of a bill to kill the program after the 15 planes now in production say they are just a handful of votes away from approval. ``Not yet, but we're close, real close,'' said Rep. John Rowland, R-Conn., a member of the House Armed Services Committee. Rowland acknowledged that he faces a formidable task because Northrop Corp., the bomber's manufacturer, is lobbying hard to keep it and the Air Force is willing to give up the once-crucial MX nuclear missile on railroad cars in exchange for the B-2. On the Senate side, Nunn and Warner remain strong supporters of the stealth bomber and comparable legislation to kill the program has not made significant progress. Support has increased, however, for the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft that takes off like a helicopter and can fly like a plane. Cheney wants to cancel the $27 billion program, arguing that a mix of helicopters is cheaper than building the Osprey. But lawmakers from Texas and Pennsylvania, where the aircraft is built, have touted a recent internal Pentagon report that says the Osprey is cost-effective. Warner also said that as the nation turns its attention from weapons used to fight the Soviet Union and focuses on limited conflicts and Third World threats ``that's where the V-22 has begun to gain added significance.'' Elsewhere on Capitol Hill this week, congressional budget negotiators plan to meet with White House counterparts in search of an agreement to cut the federal budget deficit. Agreement has been elusive after nearly two months of talks but the bargaining intensified after Bush eased his position against taxes on June 26 _ saying he now believes they must be included in any budget pact. The Senate also is expected to approve an omnibus crime bill that calls for curbs on nine semiautomatic assault weapons, plus capital punishment for 30 federal crimes ranging from presidential assassination to espionage. One possible amendment to the bill is a controversial plan that would allow private citizens frustrated by the pace of prosecution in the $325 billion savings and loan mess to sue alleged defrauders and pocket some of the damages.

$adv09
For Release PMs Monday, July 9
DOC.HEAD: When Will The Big Zero Show Up?
DOC.TEXT: Alan Greenspan looks for zeros as patiently as a guy with a handful of quarters stationed in front of a slot machine, but the combination he wants just doesn't come up. Greenspan wants zero inflation in the American economy, and he is willing to battle the odds and take big risks in order to get it. A lot of people think he'll bust the economy in seeking that goal. So be it, Chairman Greenspan seems to say, contending that if inflation isn't drawn out of the economy now it will simply reappear and scuttle the next economic advance. Deny it fuel, suffocate the fires. As head of the Federal Reserve Board, Greenspan is effectively in charge of monetary policy. His hands control the money supply, the fuel, and by keeping a firm hand on those levers he can force his will on the economy. That is, in pursuit of zero inflation he can slow the economy to the point where consumer willingness and ability to buy will diminish, where producers will cut output, where borrowing and lending will wane. The big risk in seeking zero inflation is recession, and many relatively well-informed people think the economy is on the brink of it. Gross national product is barely growing. Job growth is down sharply. Manufacturing is weak. True, the service sector _ as opposed to the goods-producing sector _ shows a moderate amount of vitality, but those who worry about inflation observe that this same sector is where prices are still continuing to rise. Nobody really wants to see an economy declining; everyone benefits from an economy that grows without inflation. But too often, Greenspan supporters say, growth has been diminished and then halted by inflation. Broadly speaking, those who support the chairman in his war on inflation, who encourage him to hold fast against pressures to lower interest rates _ which would spur economic activity _ have some solid grounds for so thinking. In their view, the coals of demand-pull inflation still smolder. That type of inflation occurs when easy money allows people to demand goods and services at a rate that cannot be sustained. Eventually, the glowing coals flame up. The zero inflationists believe the country may not be able to stand such an excess of activity, given its inability to solve existing debt problems _ a consequence, it should be noted, of earlier excesses. Among the existing excesses are the federal budget deficit, (a consequence of excessive government spending), the foreign trade deficit, municipal and state debt, taxpayer debt incurred in collapses of savings and loans, unpaid foreign debt to U.S. banks, high mortgage debt, real estate development debt, consumer installment debt. ... Let's get some of the excesses reduced before we try another expansion, say Fed defenders. But what appears to be a growing number of critics contends that in waiting for that time, the Fed might waste the economy. Stakes like that make penny arcades of the biggest casinos, and they put pressures on the monetary players that are inconceivable in a gambling casino. What this country needs is some flashing zeros. End Adv PMs Monday, July 9

DOC.NOTE: $adv09
For Release Monday, July 9, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Rally Missing Some Traditional Trimmings
DOC.TEXT: If the rise of the stock market to record highs this year has produced a new wave of optimism in the business world, you can't tell it by the level of activity in stock splits and dividend increases. In textbook bull markets, corporate boards of directors act in large numbers to celebrate the upward course of prosperity by voting a split, or a higher dividend payout, or both at the same time. Right now, figures compiled by Standard & Poor's Corp. attest, they are doing neither at anything like the rate of boom years in the past. Through the first half of 1990 S&P tallied 48 splits of at least three shares for two among the 1,600-plus companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange. At that rate, the total for the year might fall short of matching the 105 splits recorded in 1989 _ mounting no threat at all to the record of 225 set in 1983. The story on dividends from all the public companies reporting to S&P is even less impressive. The firm counted 868 ``favorable'' dividend actions _ increases, resumptions of suspended dividends and declarations of extra or special payouts _ in the first half of this year, down from 1,155 in the comparable period of 1989. On the other side of the coin, the number of unfavorable changes, including reductions and omissions, swelled to 187 in this year's first half from 109 over the like period last year. These figures point up two of the most common complaints voiced by Wall Streeters and their customers about the ``bull market,'' 1990-style. The paucity of splits demonstrates ``the narrowness of the recent market rally,'' in the words of S&P analysts, with much of the gains concentrated in a few dozen big-name blue chips and growth stocks. Sluggish dividend activity, meanwhile, spotlights persistent weakness in corporate earnings, which has led to much doubt and skepticism about the staying power of the advance in stock prices. A stock split represents a gesture by a company's directors with more symbolic than tangible value. In a 2-for-1 split, for example, the number of shares outstanding is doubled, cutting earnings per share in half and producing no change in the total market value of an investor's holdings. ``It's comparable to receiving two $10 bills for a $20,'' S&P notes. Splits can, however, broaden enthusiasm for a stock in the marketplace by making 100-share round lots easier for small investors to buy. Furthermore, the stamp of optimism they register is quite often reinforced with an accompanying increase in the dividend. When such dividend increases are scarce, as they are right now, the bottom-line impact is felt directly in calculations of investors' total return _ capital appreciation plus current income. At midyear, the dividend yield on the 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 3.74 percent, compared with 9.19 percent for a sampling of top-grade corporate bonds tracked by Barron's magazine. Analysts say that wide competitive disparity helps put stock prices largely at the mercy of changes in interest-rate expectations. One note of consolation: Both stock splits and dividends right now show very little sign of the kind of speculative enthusiasm that is often cited as a warning of an impending top in stock prices. So if you buy the optimistic view, the current dearth of splits and dividend increases holds out hope that the best is yet to come for stocks. End Adv for Monday, July 9

DOC.NOTE: $Adv16
For Release Monday AMs, July 16, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Secrecy, Security Replace Festive Mood for Japan's Coronation
DOC.TEXT: Secrecy and security have become the watchwords in thwarting the plans of radical leftists to disrupt Japan's first coronation in more than six decades. In 1928, tens of thousands of cheering, flag-waving Japanese joined in the fun when rice was planted for the late Emperor Hirohito's coronation. Drummers, traditional dancers, government dignitaries, even stunt planes participated in a rice-planting festival that lasted all day. Times have changed. This year, there will be no disclosure of the two ``sacred'' paddies used to grow the rice Emperor Akihito will offer the gods after his enthronement in November. The government says only that the rice is being grown in two states with countless rice paddies, Akita in the north and Oita in the west. Masataka Otomo, a spokesman for the Akita state government, said: ``The final word on exactly whose paddy and where won't be made public until after the rice is harvested.'' Even moving two thrones from western Japan to Tokyo in May became a major tactical operation. Military helicopters and a convoy of disguised police trucks were involved in transporting the disassembled, crated thrones under cover of darkness. Authorities say tight security is needed to guard against attacks from the radical leftists. ``Secrecy is not the wish of the government or the imperial family,'' said Nobuo Ishihara, deputy chief Cabinet secretary. ``We want to hold the ceremonies in the most open manner possible. The reason is the attitude of the radicals.'' A spokesman for the ultraleft Chukaku-ha (Middle Core Faction) said: ``That's just an excuse for them to carry out their oppression to protect that anti-people institution.'' He said in an interview, on condition of anonymity, that his often-violent group would ``continue the struggle to crush the coronation.'' Radical leftists number in the thousands, but represent only a tiny minority of Japanese, who generally either support or accept the imperial household. During the mystical rice ritual, to be held after Akihito is formally enthroned Nov. 12, the emperor is believed to commune with the sun goddess and other Shinto deities. The Daijosai, or Great Food Offering Ritual, will take place in two specially built halls on the Imperial Palace grounds in Tokyo, beginning late at night and lasting several hours. Although it has been part of coronations for more than 1,000 years, the Daijosai's religious nature has prompted intense debate of whether government plans to provide funds for it violate the postwar constitution. The budget for the entire coronation is 8.11 billion yen ($55.6 million). More than 30,000 police are expected to protect the guests expected to attend the coronation, who include Prince Charles and Princess Diana of Britain and President Fidel Castro of Cuba. That number of police officers would be equal to about three of four in Tokyo and one of every 10 nationwide. About the same number helped guard Hirohito's funeral in February. President George Bush and representatives of more than 160 other nations attended the funeral. Once a precedent has been set for security arrangements, ``it is very hard to propose a lower level,'' a police source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``If something goes wrong, you will always be remembered as the one who let it happen.'' The visibility of police in the weeks before the funeral, coupled with spot checks of cars and ``interviews'' of residents living in strategic areas led to many complaints that human rights were being violated. Police vigilance did not, however, stop leftist radicals from setting fire to a shrine near the funeral site and planting a bomb along the funeral procession route. No one was injured by the bomb.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, July 16
$adv09
For release Monday, July 9
DOC.HEAD: Fed Flirts With Danger by Delaying Effort to Boost Growth
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve's reluctance to reinvigorate the flagging economy means consumers could soon feel the pinch that already has squeezed many manufacturers and builders, a growing chorus of analysts say. Confidence among consumers in their financial well-being lags, partly due to months of disappointing economic news. Reports of factory layoffs, slumping house prices and business belt-tightening have shaken faith in continuing prosperity. ``It's time to get interest rates lower,'' says Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. ``I think the Fed should ease. But I think the Fed looks at the word ease like a four-letter word.'' The central bank has resisted altering policy despite ample evidence that a change is warranted, Brusca says. The June unemployment data, released Friday, furnished more proof that the economy is dangerously debilitated and in need of urgent attention. ``As I read the numbers, real problems have already started,'' Brusca says, noting that recessionary conditions aren't confined to factories and building sites anymore. Stores, for instance, particularly ones that supply expensive, long-lasting merchandise such as home appliances, have had weak sales for months. The contraction in total retail sales has produced the worst period for consumer spending in nine years, economists say. Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Securities Inc., says: ``I think over the next couple of months we'll continue to see rather sluggish spending on the part of the consumer reflecting his waning confidence.'' The Labor Department's monthly assessment showed private, non-farm businesses created 92,000 new jobs in June, a weaker number than the 125,000 payroll additions private analysts had expected. Private industry has added only about 100,000 new jobs a month so far in 1990, after subtracting the government's once-a-decade hiring of census workers. At mid-year in 1989, private payrolls were growing about 200,000 a month. This year's weak job growth has coincided with slumps in manufacturing and construction. At the same time, the civilian jobless rate has stayed stuck at about the same plateau. It dipped to 5.2 percent in June from May's 5.3 percent largely because fewer people were looking for work, pushing down the labor force tally. Bond traders were frustrated by the widely awaited report because it lacked any compelling reason for the Fed to do anything other than what it has been doing. Part of the Fed's stubborness in sticking to current policy stems from an unwillingness to jeopardize its credibility by appearing to bow to the Bush administration's badgering. Administration officials have been pressuring the Fed to pursue a more generous credit posture and nudge interest rates lower. David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International Inc., says the latest unemployment news gave the Fed support for its argument against easing. He said the Fed can point to the figures and ask: ``If our policies are so bad, how come unemployment is falling?'' Central bank policymakers also can claim some credit in the fight against inflation, the Fed's chief mission. Resler says he believes a standoff situation has developed between the Fed on the one side and the markets and the administration on the other. The markets and the adminstration want the Fed to enable interest rates to fall by making credit cheaper to come by in the banking system. The Fed would prefer to have its key lending rates it directly controls follow, rather than precede, market rates down. ``The Fed doesn't want to lead the charge. The market, though, is looking for the Fed to make the first step. Neither one is budging,'' Resler says. Agreement on a plan to cut the federal deficit at the budget summit in Washington will probably be the catalyst that causes the Fed finally to budge, economists expect.
DOC.HEAD: End of Advance Monday, July 9

For release weekend editions July 7-8
DOC.HEAD: Growth Stocks Back On Top
DOC.TEXT: The economy may be barely maintaining headway right now in the midst of recession fears, but growth is a hot commodity on Wall Street anyway. Some analysts say its popularity may be reviving a set of financial principles that fell out of favor for much of the past decade. In the stock market's rally to record highs over the past couple of months, many of the standout performers have been shares of large companies with long records of consistent, above-average earnings growth. When the typical money manager picks stocks these days, the emphasis is on high quality and stability, an international presence, and an ability to ride out recessions as well as the shock of any debt crisis that might arise. The growth-stock theory of investing enjoyed a long vogue a generation or more ago. It flourished in the strong expansion of the 1950s and 1960s, exemplified by the successes of such hardy growth enterprises as International Business Machines Corp. The fashion reached the point of frenzy in the early 1970s, when investors poured almost limitless amounts of money into the so-called ``favorite 50'' growth companies, which were billed as good buys at any price. A severe bear market punctured that bubble, however, and even when stocks began a subsequent recovery investors looked elsewhere for inspiration. When the boom of the '80s got rolling, the watchword was ``value,'' rather than growth. Investors sought companies with assets whose market values might blossom in a hothouse of takeovers, buyouts and corporate restructurings. Now, many analysts say, as the cleanup continues from that binge of borrowing and speculation, growth stocks may be getting another chance to shine. ``The stock market is nowhere near as outrageously overpriced as a lot of other things,'' says Barton Biggs, investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Co. ``As money flees the carnage, why won't it run to high quality bonds and equities? It has to go somewhere, and if money begins to worry seriously about the safety of banks and money market funds, the shares of real growth companies with global franchises may look as good as anything.'' The growth-stock theme manifested itself clearly in the second quarter, when prominent companies in industries like pharmaceuticals and food posted some of the best gains. It remained in evidence this past week as the market got off to a quiet start on the third quarter. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,904.95, up 24.26 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 0.30 to 195.78; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 1.75 to 460.54, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 2.44 at 358.87. Volume on the Big Board averaged 125.07 million shares a day, against 140.55 million the week before. Investment themes have come and gone with stunning speed on Wall Street in the past few years. So few analysts are ready to declare with any certainty that the growth stocks' comeback is booked for a long run. When and if interest rates fall further and the economy shows signs of picking up momentum, the search for bargains in the market could well shift to industrial and other cyclical companies with close ties to the business cycle. In any event, nobody claims it's easy to pick winning growth stocks that can sustain their performance over periods of years rather than weeks. A single quarterly earnings disappointment has been enough to knock many a glamour stock off its perch of late. But for the moment at least, the trend seems indisputable. ``We are in a growth stock market,'' said John Connolly at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``Our strategy continues to have consumer growth issues at the core of our portfolio.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Industry Shows More of Its Pulpy Side
DOC.TEXT: A slow economy, pressing debts and fewer readers have combined to demonstrate vividly the growing vulnerability among American newspaper publishers. Two of the most prominent names in newspapering, Ralph M. Ingersoll II and the Gannett Co., emerged this past week as the latest sufferers from a slowdown in what historically has been a highly profitable industry. Ingersoll, the ambitious publishing executive who financed a U.S. expansion partly through high-interest junk bond credit and unsuccessfully launched a new St. Louis paper earlier this year, relinquished control of his American newspaper interests to an investment partner, E.M. Warburg Pincus & Co. In the same transaction, Ingersoll acquired Warburg's half-interest in a European newspaper publisher. He thereby extricated himself from the debt burden of his three U.S. publishing companies, which owe about $700 million. Ingersoll said his primary motive was to exploit what he believed to be a vibrant market for newspapers in Europe, which has become the most economically dynamic part of the world. But industry analysts said the high debt load Ingersoll amassed in this country clearly was a key reason for the move, which seemed to shatter his desire to become one of the biggest newspaper owners in the United States. He had controlled 10 dailies and more than 120 weeklies. Sheer size, however, does not necessarily make a newspaper empire invulnerable. Gannett, the current No. 1 newspaper company in the country, disclosed its own form of financial distress this past week. The 82-daily newspaper giant, which also publishes USA Today nationally, said it expected second-quarter earnings to fall. That would mark the first time since Gannett went public 22 years ago that quarterly earnings have declined from a year earlier. The company is due to issue second-quarter earnings later this month. As one of the most financially stable newspaper companies, Gannett does not have the debt problem Ingersoll faced. But both have been affected by what industry strategists have called some common underlying trends. ``The newspaper industry has been suffering a slowdown for the last three years as advertising revenues have slowed,'' said Susan Putnam, who follows the newspaper business for Moran & Associates Inc., an investment firm in Greenwich, Conn. ``They've cut costs and got operations down to a lean level. But revenue growth hasn't picked up. So they're suffering earnings declines.'' The sluggishness rippling through the economy has complicated the outlook for newspapers, which generally derive most of their revenue from retail, automobile and classified advertising. Many retailers, hurt by high debt levels of their own, have cut back drastically on ads, although publicizing sales in newspapers historically has been considered the cheapest and most effective way to attract customers. Automakers, which also are slumping, haven't been aggressively offering rebates this year, which in turn tends to reduce the amount of newspaper advertising by dealers. Within the classified ad category, the most prevalent ads _ real estate and employment _ also have fallen, analysts say. In some economically depressed parts of the country where many properties are for sale, for example, owners and brokers simply have given up advertising in newspapers because of poor response. This past week the Conference Board, a New York-based business research group that tracks the volume of employment advertising, said its help-wanted index dropped in May to the lowest level in four years. In recession-battered New England, the level was off by nearly a third from a year earlier. Many newspapers have responded to their slump partly by aggressive drives to increase circulation. This gives newspapers the justification to charge more for ads, because presumably they are seen by more readers. But this strategy has been been undermined by another problem that the newspaper industry increasingly is confronting: Many people, particularly the young, aren't reading the papers. Some studies show, for example, that only 30 percent of Americans under age 35 read a paper regularly, about half the percentage of two decades ago. Perhaps the most troubling study was released recently by the Times Mirror Center for the People & the Press, which shows the younger generation ``knows less, cares less and reads newspapers less'' than any generation in the past 50 years. In other business and economic news this past week: _More evidence emerged of softness in the economy. The unemployment rate fell slightly to 5.2 percent, but that was due to fewer people looking for work. New job growth remained weak. _Boeing Co. received a jumbo-jet order potentially worth $6.9 billion from British Airways PLC, but will have to wait for word on whether it receives an order from UAL Corp. that could be worth $20 billion. Unions trying to buy UAL delayed negotiations on their potentially record jetliner order until they secure financing for their acquisition of the airline company. _Brokers who belly up to the bar could be in for a doubly unpleasant tax surprise. The federal government, seeking ways to raise tax revenues to close the federal budget deficit, is considering a 0.5 percent levy on securities sales and may seek to sharply raise the excise tax on alcohol.
